Travelers to Andorra planning on staying longer than three nights are required to provide evidence of negative diagnostic test (PCR or TMA) taken at least 72 hours prior to arrival in Andorra. Visitors from Spain, France, Portugal and countries designated as 'green zones' are exempt.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210314142108/https://www.govern.ad/covid19/     Travelers from Brazil, South Africa, and designated countries will also be required to quarantine for fourteen days upon arrival in Andorra.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210314142823/https://www.govern.ad/comunicats/item/12471-les-persones-que-arribin-a-andorra-procedents-de-brasil-i-sudafrica-hauran-de-fer-quarantena-preventiva

No policy change. Salaried and self-employed workers who have had to suspend work due to Covid-19 are entitled to an economic benefit - health professionals are entitled to 100% of their salary, general workers are entitled to 66% of their salary. Paid leave of absence from work to take care of children when schools or extracurriculars cannot conduct activity as usual. ""Hermagor: Due to the current exit regulations for the Hermagor district, distance learning applies to students commuting in and out from March 9 to March 18. This does not apply to pupils in classes with final exams (see Ordinance Sheet of the Education Directorate )."" --> note that this has more to do with internal travel rather than school closure, since the school levels remain open to students in Hermagor  https://archive.ph/5nz5W#selection-1567.0-1591.3

Schools  Schools are returning to face-to-face teaching. Primary schools resume regular operations. For secondary levels I and II, face-to-face lessons apply in 2-day shifts. Kindergartens resume normal operations.  A negative corona rapid test, carried out at the school, is required to participate in classroom-based lessons. Face masks are mandatory at school.    Universities  ""Most universities and colleges currently hold their teaching and examination operations predominantly digitally . This does not apply to courses and examinations that are difficult or impossible to substitute and where distance learning is difficult or impossible to implement or makes no sense for technical or didactic reasons. This can be, for example, laboratory exercises or artistic or medical or technical-practical seminars.    ""For the remainder of the summer semester 2021, especially the period after Easter, universities and colleges are planning to bring more students back to the universities or colleges. This is especially true for first-year students who have so far only gotten to know little of classic university or college life. This also applies, for example, to students who are about to graduate or who have taken special subjects where attendance phases are important for technical or didactic reasons. Ultimately, this also applies to students who work as tutors, mentors, consultants or as Buddies support other students.    ""If the infection situation allows, carefully considered opening steps are planned at most universities after Easter , which allow hybrid operation with digital and analog teaching and learning formats that are held in person. This should be made possible, among other things, by the corona tests, which university and college management can provide for participation in a classroom course, a classroom test or an entrance test after Easter . The BMBWF has drawn up a corresponding legal basis that is to apply for the entire summer semester of 2021, but has yet to be passed by parliament.""    Sources:   https://archive.vn/6OGnu    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322211545/https://www.bmbwf.gv.at/Themen/HS-Uni/Aktuelles/corona/corona_faq.html

Work guidelines recommend working from home where possible. Several sectors are still prohibited from opening.    Nationwide work guidelines:  	• Wherever possible, you should switch to home office.    	• A distance of at least two meters must be maintained at the workplace and an MNS must be worn as soon as two or more people who do not live in the same household are in a room without protective devices (e.g. partition walls). An exception to this applies if the work would be impossible (e.g. actors). Organizational measures, such as the formation of permanent teams, must be taken here.    	• Employees of the following occupational groups are now obliged to undergo a PCR or antigen test at least every seven days:  	   - Teachers with direct contact with students,  	   - Employees in childcare facilities with direct contact with the children,  	   - Employees in the field of warehouse logistics, if the distance rule cannot be consistently adhered to,  	   - Employees with direct customer contact and  	   - Persons who are involved in party relations in administrative authorities and administrative courts.  	• The negative test result must be presented to the employer and kept available for a period of seven days. If proof cannot be provided, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn.    Source: https://archive.vn/A3gpC    Sectors still closed include leisure and cultural facilities.    ""Entering leisure and cultural facilities for the purpose of using the services of these facilities is prohibited.""    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210307231328/https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/GeltendeFassung.wxe?Abfrage=Bundesnormen&Gesetzesnummer=20011470

Several sectors, particularly in leisure and cultural pursuits, are closed.  Working from home recommended where possible.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308103040/https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/GeltendeFassung.wxe?Abfrage=Bundesnormen&Gesetzesnummer=20011470  https://archive.vn/awSEe

Some sectors still remain closed (separate regulations apply to Vorarlberg).  The recommendation to work at home if possible is still active in the latest version of the regulations.    The new regulations note a change - ""Mandatory prevention concept for companies with 51 or more employees"" - from 1 April.    Source: https://archive.ph/SfEt9

Some sectors are still closed including several leisure and cultural activities. The recommendation to work at home remains in place.       Separate regulations apply to Vorarlberg which, with lower cases, has begun a controlled reopening some shuttered businesses and facilities.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210321110229/https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/GeltendeFassung.wxe?Abfrage=Bundesnormen&Gesetzesnummer=20011470    https://archive.vn/A8Coh

""Events are still prohibited (e.g. birthday parties, wedding celebrations, cultural events, sporting events).    ""Exceptions to this are rehearsals and artistic performances without an audience that take place for professional purposes, as well as professional sports. Professional meetings that cannot be postponed and meetings for absolutely necessary professional training and further education purposes are possible. Funerals can take place with a maximum of 50 people. Demonstrations are allowed.    ""The minimum distance and the FFP2 obligation must be observed at all events.""    Sources:   https://archive.vn/A3gpC    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307231328/https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/GeltendeFassung.wxe?Abfrage=Bundesnormen&Gesetzesnummer=20011470

Events are still prohibited (e.g. birthday parties, wedding celebrations, cultural events, sporting events).    Exceptions to this are rehearsals and artistic performances without an audience that take place for professional purposes, as well as professional sports. Professional meetings that cannot be postponed and meetings for absolutely necessary professional training and further education purposes are possible. Funerals can take place with a maximum of 50 people. Demonstrations are allowed.    The minimum distance and the FFP2 obligation must be observed at all events. ***Recoded from 2G to 2T     Targeted opening in Vorarlberg. Events allowed under the following restrictions:   Can take place indoors and outdoors. Test compulsory and FFP2 compulsory at all events.  Assigned and labeled seating.  The upper limit for visitors is 100 people and a maximum of 50% occupancy.  There is a registration requirement for visitors.  The administration of food and drinks at events is not permitted.  The organizer has to appoint a COVID-19 officer and work out and adhere to a mandatory prevention concept.    Events banned elsewhere in Austria.     https://archive.is/CmA25    Previous coding note:   Events still prohibited except in Vorarlberg where separate regulations apply.     Sources:   https://archive.ph/SfEt9  https://archive.ph/OlX2D

This also applies to private areas outside the living area (e.g. gardens, barns, sheds, garages).""    Sources:   https://archive.vn/A3gpC    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307231328/https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/GeltendeFassung.wxe?Abfrage=Bundesnormen&Gesetzesnummer=20011470

Some restrictions around passenger capacity on public transport apply.    ""In motor vehicles (private car, taxi, Uber) a maximum of two people per row of seats may be transported (exception: shared household). In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn.    ""Cable cars, gondolas & ascent aids: With closed and covered vehicles, only 50% of the transport capacity may be used, ie only half as many people may be transported. In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn. Operators have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.""    Source: https://archive.vn/A3gpC#selection-1505.0-1541.112

Limitations on capacity in public transport in effect, including:    In motor vehicles (private car, taxi, Uber) a maximum of two people per row of seats may be transported (exception: shared household). In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn.    Cable cars, gondolas & ascent aids: With closed and covered vehicles, only 50% of the transport capacity may be used, ie only half as many people may be transported. In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn. Operators have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308103040/https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/GeltendeFassung.wxe?Abfrage=Bundesnormen&Gesetzesnummer=20011470  https://archive.vn/awSEe

A stay at home order is in place from 8pm to 6am. Exceptions include:    	• Avoidance of an immediate danger to life, limb and property  	• Care and assistance for people in need of support as well as the fulfillment of family obligations  	• Covering the necessary basic needs of daily life, such as  	  - contact with the partner who does not live in the same household or contact with individual close relatives or individual important caregivers, with whom physical or non-physical contact is usually maintained several times a week  	  - the supply of basic goods of daily life  	  - the use of health services  	  - the coverage of a need for housing  	  - the satisfaction of basic religious needs, such as visits to cemeteries and individual visits to places of worship, as well as  	  - the care of animals.  	• Professional and educational purposes  	• Physical and mental recovery (e.g. individual sports, walks)  	• Official and judicial appointments that cannot be postponed    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308103040/https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/GeltendeFassung.wxe?Abfrage=Bundesnormen&Gesetzesnummer=20011470  https://archive.vn/awSEe

In public, closed rooms, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) without an exhalation valve must also be worn. Among other things, this applies to:  	• Public transport (and the associated underground stations, platforms, stops, train stations and airports),  	• Carpooling,  	• Cable cars and cog railways,  	• Customer areas of commercial establishments as well as of service establishments,  	• Party traffic by administrative authorities and administrative courts,  	• Gastronomy - if open (e.g. when collecting food and in company canteens),  	• Accommodation establishments - if open (in generally accessible areas such as the lobby or at the reception, does not apply in the room); Entry continues only for exceptional reasons such as for urgent professional purposes,  	• currently permitted events (e.g. funerals),  	• currently open cultural institutions (e.g. museums, art halls, libraries).    The FFP2 mask requirement also applies to people who have recovered from COVID-19 and who have been vaccinated against COVID-19. An exception to the FFP2 mask requirement applies to  	• Children and adolescents under 14 years of age,  	• Pregnant women and  	• People who cannot be expected to wear an FFP2 mask for health reasons (medical certificate required).  Instead, a tight-fitting MNS should be worn.    A general exception to the MNS obligation applies to   	• Deaf and severely hearing impaired people and their communication partners during communication,  	• Children under six years and  	• People who cannot be expected to wear an MNS for health reasons (medical certificate required).    Source: https://archive.vn/A3gpC

Austria approves use of AstraZeneca vaccine for over 65s.    Translation: The National Vaccination Committee recommends the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine without an upper age limit in accordance with the approval of the European authorities.  This also applies without restriction to all persons over 65 years of age, high-risk and high-risk persons, according to specialist information.  Due to limited data, a recommendation wa made in many countries to vaccinate people under 65 years of age in particular.  This was also the previous recommendation of the NG. Due to the new data now available from large application studies over the past few days, such a restriction is no longer necessary.     Source: https://archive.vn/2oiod

Change in legislation come into force around number of visitors - residents may only be visited twice a week by a maximum of two visitors per resident (except for palliative and hospice support and pastoral care).    ""two visits with a maximum of two people per resident per week, ""    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308103040/https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/GeltendeFassung.wxe?Abfrage=Bundesnormen&Gesetzesnummer=20011470

• To protect retirement and nursing homes, employees must be tested at least every three days.  	• Employees must wear an MNS. If there is direct contact with the resident, a respirator of protection class FFP2 (FFP2 mask) without an exhalation valve or an equivalent or higher standard corresponding mask must be worn.  	• Residents of old people's and nursing homes may be visited a maximum of twice a week by a maximum of two people each. Additional visits are permitted for the following exceptions:  	  - Residents in need of support (no more than two people to accompany them),  	  - Visits as part of palliative and hospice support, pastoral care and support during critical life events,  	  - Resident representatives in accordance with the Residence Act (HeimAufG), Federal Law Gazette I No. 11/2004, patient and nursing lawyers as well as bodies of nursing supervision for the performance of the tasks stipulated by state law as well as commissions established for the protection and promotion of human rights (optional protocol to the convention against torture and others cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, Federal Law Gazette III No. 190/2012).  	• Visitors must show a negative PCR or antigen test result. In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn.  	• The residents must be provided with an antigen or PCR test twice a week, provided they have left the retirement and nursing home within this period.  	• Operators have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.    Source: https://archive.vn/awSEe    NB some areas (such as the Tyrol) have additional protections in place for the protection of elderly people.  See https://archive.vn/V7hGu

To protect retirement and nursing homes, employees must be tested at least every three days.    Employees must wear an MNS. If there is direct contact with the resident, a respiratory protection mask of protection class FFP2 (FFP2 mask) without exhalation valve or an equivalent or higher standard corresponding mask must be worn.    Residents of old people's and nursing homes may be visited a maximum of twice a week by a maximum of two people each. Additional visits are permitted for limited exceptions.    Visitors must show a negative PCR or antigen test result. In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn.    The residents must be provided with an antigen or PCR test twice a week, provided they have left the retirement and nursing home within this period.    Operators have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.    Source: https://archive.ph/AOMOR

General measures  To protect retirement and nursing homes, employees must be tested at least every three days.    Employees must wear an MNS. If there is direct contact with the resident, a respirator of protection class FFP2 (FFP2 mask) without exhalation valve or an equivalent or higher standard corresponding mask must be worn.    Residents of old people's and nursing homes may be visited a maximum of twice a week by a maximum of two people each. Additional visits are permitted for limited exceptions    Visitors must show a negative PCR or antigen test result. In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn.    The residents must be provided with an antigen or PCR test twice a week, provided they have left the retirement and nursing home within this period.    Operators have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.    Source: https://archive.vn/A8Coh    Tyrol  On February 13, 2021 (extended to March 19, 2021), the state of Tyrol stipulates additional measures for retirement and nursing homes (see corresponding ordinance ):      - When returning to a home after staying outdoors for more than 6 hours, residents must be offered a molecular biological test no later than the day after their return.    - Employees must present a test that is not older than 48 hours.    - There is an FFP2 mask requirement for employees for all personal contact (not only with residents).    - Stricter rules apply to the prevention concepts, e.g. restriction to a maximum of five participants for group offers.    - In addition, for the Schwaz district, residents in old people's and nursing homes must be offered a daily test option.

As of 14 March, discos, bars, and clubs are closed.     Fitness centers and group gyms are allowed with a 50% capacity limit. A distance of at least 2 meters between visitors must be maintained.    Restaurants are allowed with a 50% capacity limit and not more than 6 people per table. Staff are required to wear protective masks and hours are limited to between 06:00 and 23:00.    Gaming halls and casinos are allowed with a 50% capacity limit. Staff and visitors are required to wear protective masks and hours are limited to between 06:00 and 23:00.    Visits to shopping centers, including malls, are allowed. Minors may only visit them if they are accompanied by their parent, guardian, or another adult.    Markets and bazaars must be organized for one-way movement of visitors and must provide a distance of at least 1.5m between visitors. Workers and visitors are required to wear a face mask.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314183013/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

A negative COVID-19 PCR test is required for entry in Bulgaria. There are in place health screening procedures at airports and other ports of entry. All persons exempted from entry restrictions are also allowed to transit the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria.  Link: https://archive.fo/YeOeq

As of 14 March, the ban on entry into the Republic of Bulgaria remains in effect, with certain exceptions.    Current exceptions include:  Bulgarian citizens, citizens of Member States of the European Union (EU), Schengen Parties (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and their family members (including persons in actual residence with them); citizens of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, the Union of Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, the Republic of Rwanda, the Republic of Korea, the Kingdom of Thailand, the Republic of Tunisia, the Oriental Republic of Uruguay, the United Arab Emirates, Ukraine, the Republic of Northern Macedonia The Republic of Albania, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, the Republic of Moldova, Israel, the State of Kuwait, the Republic of Belarus and the Republic of Turkey; persons with permanent status, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and the members of their families; persons holding a Bulgarian long-stay visa type ""D"", as well as persons holding a residence permit in a Member State of the European Union or in a Schengen country (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the City State Vatican) and members of their families.    All persons who are allowed to enter the country are admitted to the Republic of Bulgaria upon submission of a document showing a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction test conducted up to 72 hours before entry.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210314183013/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

A negative COVID-19 PCR test is required for entry in Bulgaria. There are in place health screening procedures at airports and other ports of entry. All persons exempted from entry restrictions are also allowed to transit the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria. All persons arriving from Africa will be quarantined for a period of 10 days and the quarantine can not be revoked by presenting a negative PCR test.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210317062836/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of 14 March, the unified information portal remains the official source of information on measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Bulgaria (https://coronavirus.bg). The portal provides statistics, news, press briefings, video materials, information about vaccines, and answers to frequently asked questions.     An official chatbot of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Bulgaria is available, which provides real-time official information and news about COVID-19 through Viber.     The ViruSafe mobile app is available, which gives users the ability to track their symptoms and health status daily. This information gives the Ministry of Health a good overview of the spread of the pandemic. Users can also voluntarily share their location to enable institutions to act accordingly, in case of an emergency.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210314185439/https://coronavirus.bg/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209054901/https://virusafe.info/

On 12 March, executive director Bogdan Kirilov issued an order which temporarily suspended immunizations with the AstraZeneca vaccine.     The order is in connection with the information received in the period 8-12 March about the occurrence of unacceptable side effects with proper use of the vaccine and the ongoing inspection of the European Medicines Agency.    AstraZeneca vaccines will remain blocked until circumstances are established and recommendations are received from the EMA's Pharmacovigilance Committee.      Also on 12 March, registration on the electronic COVID-19 vaccination portal was suspended. This was due to the temporary suspension of the AstraZeneca vaccine.     Users registered in the portal will automatically receive a new immunization hour, after analyzing the number of people registered for vaccination and the availability of the other two vaccines against COVID-19 approved in our country.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210315172006/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1508    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315172518/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1511

On Saturday, 20th of February, began a mass-vaccination campaign, as Bulgarian Prime Minister Boiko Borisov announced. “Green corridors” were created, where any Bulgarian resident could line up for the vaccine. On 12th of March, the vaccination with AstraZeneca vaccines was temporarily suspended.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210321201430/https://archive.fo/P1ZWv, https://web.archive.org/web/20210315172006/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1508 and https://web.archive.org/web/20210315172518/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1511

511 doses of vaccine against COVID-19 were given in Dobrich district for a week, mainly immunizations and re-immunizations of the persons from the first, second and third phases of the plan, as well as re-immunizations of the persons directly involved in the election process.    All persons who have registered in the electronic register and have been officially re-registered are called to be invited for immunization. At present, anyone who registers in the electronic register can be immunized with AstraZeneca vaccine.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210330053030/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1587

Still current     Recreational schools and courses: Face-to-face teaching is prohibited in courses for adults (born 2000 or earlier). One-to-one tuition, such as in music schools or for the skipper’s licence examination, for example, is permitted.      Tertiary level (e.g. universities and other higher education institutions): Face-to-face teaching is permitted only if the students absolutely need to be on site (e.g. instruction on operating a particular machine, dissection during medical studies) and if the teaching forms an essential part of the course of study. Otherwise, a switch to remote learning is required. Examinations linked to study courses or higher vocational training and the examinations necessary for obtaining an official certificate may be held on site provided that the precautionary measures are observed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210306151722/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

""Swiss museums are permitted to reopen from 1 March in a cautious easing of the second pandemic lockdown imposed in mid-January, as the country’s rate of new infections continues to decline gradually.    The reopening of museums, shops, zoos, botanical gardens and sports facilities is the first stage in a gradual loosening of restrictions approved by the government this month. Still current: ""The number of people allowed to attend events among friends and family (for example gatherings and parties) is limited. The numbers include children. Recommendation: Only get together with a few households at the same time.    Rule indoors: A maximum of 10 people is allowed.  Rule outdoors: A maximum of 15 people is allowed.    These rules only apply to gatherings of family and friends. Events such as club gatherings, a meeting or event in the parish community are still prohibited.""     http://web.archive.org/web/20210328192013/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

The reopening of school units with the physical presence of students will take  place in two phases:  1. As of 1 March the first and second grades of public and private  Lyceums and Technical Schools are reopening, while upholding the  relevant health protocol.  2. As of 8 March, all grades of public and private Gymnasiums are  reopening, while upholding the relevant health protocol.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308092102/https://publications.gov.cy/assets/user/publications/2021/2021_995/8/index.html

No change in policy.    High schools are operating through online education until 16 March 2021, and public and private Higher and Tertiary Education Institutions continue to operate through online education.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315150959/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/02032021_Decree%20n.10_EN.pdf

Private and public schools of primary education, as well as private and public nurseries and kindergartens, including pre-primary schools, special schools and special units of public schools shall operate with physical attendance, save for the private and public schools of primary education in Limassol District, which shall operate through online education.    High schools and the respective classes of private schools of secondary education; public and private Higher and Tertiary Education Institutions shall operate through  online education.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210323142558/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/12032021_DECREE%20No%2011%20EN.pdf

Movement continues to be prohibited from 9 in the evening until 5 in the morning  of the following day.  2. Under which circumstances is one allowed to move during curfew  hours (9 in the evening to 5 in the morning of the next day)?  The movement of persons during curfew hours continues to be permitted for  the following reasons:  • For purposes of moving to and from workplaces, with the  presentation of Form A, completed and signed by the employer, which  certifies the necessity for the movement during the aforementioned  hours.  , such as to go to a medical centre or a hospital or  • For urgent purposes  a pharmacy or a veterinarian for medical emergencies and to render  assistance to people who are unable to care for themselves or who need  to self -isolate.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308092102/https://publications.gov.cy/assets/user/publications/2021/2021_995/8/index.html

No change in policy.    Museums, galleries, and archaeological sites are open.  Nature trails and beaches are open for exercise only. Conferences, demonstrations, and exhibitions are prohibited.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315152727/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of 16 March, catering establishments are allowed to operate only outdoors, according to the health protocol and the relevant guidelines.     Private companies providing services (e.g. law offices, accounting offices, insurance companies, business service providers etc), except from the essential services determined in the Decree, may operate via telework.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315155431/https://pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/pdf/15032021_metraEN.pdf

No change in policy. C4 = 4, so no public events are allowed.    Conferences, demonstrations, and exhibitions are prohibited. Church gatherings are limited to 50 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315152727/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The maximum number of persons at church services and/or other forms of religious worship is 50 people, in compliance with the health guidelines.  Weddings, christenings and funerals with a maximum number of 10 persons are allowed. The holding of luncheons and/or dinners that are related to weddings and christenings, is prohibited.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210323141223/https://www.pio.gov.cy/en/press-releases-article.html?id=19146#flat

Physical exercise/personal training is permitted in areas where access is  allowed in accordance with the Decree in force. Specifically, access is allowed  to parks, linear parks, nature trails and beaches only for the purposes of  physical exercise/personal training.  Persons are allowed to move to the aforementioned areas only for  physical exercise or personal training, provided that they send a text  message to 8998 while selecting the option number 6, comply with the  maximum timeframe allowed (3 hours), and ensure that participants in the  exercise/training do not exceed two persons, excluding underage children.  As regards parks, linear parks, nature trails and beaches, it is noted that  people are allowed to be present there for no other reason besides  exercise.  It is underlined that in areas where people are present in order to work out, no  socialization is allowed with other persons who do not reside in the same  residence as them.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308092102/https://publications.gov.cy/assets/user/publications/2021/2021_995/8/index.html

No change in policy.    Gatherings of more than four people in residences or outdoors are prohibited, except for minors accompanying their parents in public places.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315152727/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Access to squares is allowed, as of 15 March, for gatherings of up to six (6) persons, irrespective of age, provided that a text message is sent to 8998 (category number 6 selected) and that the reasonable timeframe of three (3) hours is upheld    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315155431/https://pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/pdf/15032021_metraEN.pdf

Not updating indicator, but noting that public transportation is operating with face coverings required.    Leaving indicator as 1G due to other movement restrictions, noted below, which would inherently limit the public's use of available means of transit.    A strict island-wide curfew is in effect from 09:00pm to 05:00am with the exceptions of emergency medical reasons and employees with a letter from their employer.    Approval by sending an SMS to 8998 is required to leave one’s residence (people over 65 can use a printed form). Each resident is allowed two permissions a day. Exceptions are made for dog-walking, taking children to school, and employment.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315152727/https:/cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The maximum number of passengers allowed to travel in all regular buses with a fare per passenger, as well as in all public and/or private transport means, depending on their capacity, is defined in accordance with the guidelines issued by the Ministry of Transport, Communications and Works    https://web.archive.org/web/20210323142558/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/12032021_DECREE%20No%2011%20EN.pdf

Movement by exception will be permitted twice a day by sending a text  message to 8998 for the reasons cited in Form B. Persons over the age of  65 may use Form B twice per day for their movement by exception. There are  nine (9) categories for movement by exception via a text message.  It is clarified that for purposes of moving to and from the workplace for work  purposes, no text message is required, but the employee must present Form  A, signed by his/her employer.  Moreover, parents/legal guardians are not required to send a text message for  the purposes of transporting a minor or a disabled person to school or a day  care center.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308092102/https://publications.gov.cy/assets/user/publications/2021/2021_995/8/index.html

No change in policy.    A strict island-wide curfew is in effect from 09:00pm to 05:00am with the exceptions of emergency medical reasons and employees with a letter from their employer.    Approval by sending an SMS to 8998 is required to leave one’s residence (people over 65 can use a printed form). Each resident is allowed two permissions a day. Exceptions are made for dog-walking, taking children to school, and employment.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315152727/https:/cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

What are the curfew hours?  Movement is prohibited from 11 o’clock at night until 5 o’clock in the morning of  the following day.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210315155431/https://pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/pdf/15032021_metraEN.pdf

movement between Districts is permitted provided that the purpose for  which the movement takes place falls within the Categories referred to in the  text message, which normally does not exceed three (3) hours.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308092102/https://publications.gov.cy/assets/user/publications/2021/2021_995/8/index.html

No change in policy.    Movement between Districts is permitted provided that the purpose for which the movement takes place falls within the Categories referred to in the text message, which normally does not exceed three (3) hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315155431/https://pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/pdf/15032021_metraEN.pdf

Yes, movement between Districts is permitted provided that the purpose for which the movement takes place falls within the Categories referred to in the text message    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315155431/https://pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/pdf/15032021_metraEN.pdf

No change in policy.    Until at least 1 April 2021, U.S. citizen tourists will not be able to travel to the Republic of Cyprus if they have been in the United States, or any other country not classed as a “Green,” “Orange,” or “Red” category country, in the two weeks before travel to Cyprus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315152727/https:/cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Color-coded system explained here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210310162247/https://www.visitcyprus.com/files/COVID-19_Destination_Protocol_Cyprus-1_March_2021b.pdf    Current list of countries in each color category listed here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210311212637/https://cyprusflightpass.gov.cy/en/country-categories

The entry into the Republic is permitted to persons, regardless of nationality, from  countries of “Green”, “Orange” and “Red” category according to the categorisation of countries  based on the risk estimate.    Passengers from countries of Green category need not present a proof of molecular  Covid-19 test before their arrival in the Republic.    Passengers from countries of Orange category should hold a certificate of negative molecular COVID-19 test from a certified laboratory, performed 72 hours before departure.    Passengers from countries of Red category:  (i) should produce a certificate of negative molecular COVID-19 test from a certified  laboratory, performed 72 hours before departure;  (ii) should undergo a molecular Covid-19 test immediately after arriving in the Republic  at their own expenses and remain in compulsory confinement until they receive the  result    The entry into the Republic from countries of Grey category is only permitted for citizens and other exceptions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210323142558/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/12032021_DECREE%20No%2011%20EN.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210323143547/https://cyprusflightpass.gov.cy/en/country-categories

Policy: According to the 8th point, the government of the Czech Republic prohibits:    operation of the school and educative facilities and provide accommodation for the students with another residence within the Czech Republic. There is a valid exception for students attending presence education. The government also bans outdoor schools and school trips.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315200133/https://covid.gov.cz/en/measures/education/prohibition-outdoor-schools-and-school-trips

As part of a new range of lockdown measures, beginning 27 February to 11 April, ""According to the 4th point, the government of the Czech Republic restricts the operation of primary schools according to the law defining rules for this area. Specifically, the government bans attendance on presence education with a valid exception.""   https://archive.vn/EqpDD    ""According to the 3rd point, the government of the Czech Republic restricts: operation of secondary/grammar schools, higher vocational schools and conservatories according to the law no. 561/2004 Coll., defining rules for educational institutions. Personal attendance in presence lectures is prohibited with valid exceptions.""  https://archive.vn/oa2kw

Policy: All shops and services are closed, except for pharmacies and grocery stores, which are operating with social distancing measures in place. Restaurants and bars are closed, but some offer a takeaway service. Drinking alcohol in public spaces is forbidden. All cultural venues, including museums, galleries, theatres and attractions such as zoos, are closed.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315200623/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/czech-republic/coronavirus

""All retail is generally closed. However, the sale of the basic goods is permitted.  The government of the Czech Republic prohibits retail sales and the sale and provision of services at establishments,"" with exceptions including essential workplaces, flower shops, shops selling newspapers and magazines, shops selling spare parts for vehicles and production technologies.     https://archive.vn/C8HbT    ""The retail sale of standard Easter products and items is allowed. (link in Czech language) These products usually fall into the category of food, Easter decorative items into the category of household goods, and other items, such as traditional pomlázky, which are made of wicker, fall into the category of plants of the type that can be offered in florists.""

Restrictions still in effect and extended until after Easter.   ""The Czech government said late Thursday it was extending the country’s tight lockdown till after Easter, as infection and death rates remain at high levels. The measures had been due to expire Sunday but will now last until at least April 5, which is Easter Monday and a national holiday.""  https://archive.ph/jKDKZ

Policy: You should not leave your place of residence between 9pm and 5am unless you are travelling to, or from work, or making an essential trip.  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210315200623/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/czech-republic/coronavirus

""Currently, a ban on leaving the (permanent) residence district (or, in case of the capital city of Prague as a place of [permanent] residence, the city) applies to all persons. Additionally, a ban on entering a district or the capital city of Prague as well as on free movement and dwelling therein applies to all persons without (permanent) residence in that district or in the capital city of Prague, respectively...You can also leave your residence between 11 o'clock in the evening and 5 o'clock in the morning for urgent reasons (e.g. a visit to a hospital, floods, etc.).    In the period from 5:00am to 8:59pm, free movement is allowed in several cases. These are, for example, work commuting,  provision of basic needs (e. g. buying food, medicine or pet supplies), post office and relevant authorities' visit. You can also go for a nature walk, but only within your (permanent) residence municipality.""  https://archive.vn/GBRQ8  ""The Czech Government has banned contact between people from different households. You should not leave your place of residence between 9pm and 5am unless you are traveling to, or from work, or making an essential trip.""  https://archive.vn/pjPxk

Restrictions still in effect and extended until after Easter.   ""The Czech government said late Thursday it was extending the country’s tight lockdown till after Easter, as infection and death rates remain at high levels. The measures had been due to expire Sunday but will now last until at least April 5, which is Easter Monday and a national holiday.""  https://archive.ph/jKDKZ

Policy: From 1 March, there are restrictions on freedom of movement. You must avoid all non-essential movement. Shopping and exercise are only permitted within your municipality (‘obec’). You must not travel outside of your district (‘okres’ in Czech) unless this is for a permitted exceptional reason. Exceptions are permitted for essential travel to work, to the airport, to attend a medical appointment, or to care for an infirm relative, but you may be asked to provide written evidence of the need for your journey.  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210315200623/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/czech-republic/coronavirus

No change in policy; ""From 1 March, there are restrictions on freedom of movement. You must avoid all non-essential movement.. Essential shopping, exercise and travel to work are permitted within your district (‘okres’). You must not travel outside of your district (‘okres’ in Czech) unless this is for a permitted exceptional reason. Exceptions are permitted for essential travel to work, to the airport, to attend a medical appointment, or to care for an infirm relative, but you may be asked to provide written evidence of the need for your journey. Please note that the size of districts varies: the city of Prague is classed as one district.""  https://archive.vn/pjPxk

Policy: Entry is allowed from a wide range of countries but depending on how high-risk the country one is travelling from, there is a requirement for  PCR test as well as high-level face-mask wearing for the 14 days following arrival. No changes, it appears as though the government is tracing all primary contacts of cases:  ""An employee of the health Authority or tracing center will call you and ask for your tracing information (prepare it in advance). Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315205034/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/infection-and-general-measures/how-does-tracing-work Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315205034/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/infection-and-general-measures/how-does-tracing-work

No apparent change in policy    ""After receiving the results of the positive test, you will also receive a link to the self-tracing form to your telephone number, where you can fill in the tracing data. Self-tracing forms are processed as a priority by the Regional Health Authority (KHS or Krajská hygienická stanice in Czech). An employee of the health Authority or tracing center will call you and ask for your tracing information (prepare it in advance).    Prepare the following data for tracing:    name and surname of the contact  their telephone number  the day of the last contact with this person (if you are in the same household, the day of the last contact is the day of the positive PCR test).""    ""If you use the eRouška application, you will receive an SMS code to your telephone number after the results of the positive test have been received. By entering the SMS code into the application, the people who the application has evaluated as your risky contacts will be automatically informed. The data is anonymous, so you don't have to be afraid to insert it in eRouška. Even one code can prevent dozens from getting infected.""  https://archive.ph/U1uyH

Policy: It is mandatory to cover your mouth and nose in all indoor and outdoor public spaces in built up areas with a face covering of surgical mask standard or higher. In places with a high number of people, such as public transport, shopping centres and medical facilities, you are required to wear a face covering of FFP2 standard or higher (in Czech known as ‘respirátor’). The Czech government advises that people adhere to social distancing of 2m where possible when in public.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315200623/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/czech-republic/coronavirus
No change in policy  https://archive.vn/pjPxk

(persons living in the same household do not count).""    https://archive.vn/womBe

Policy:  esidents of the Czech Republic, including British nationals, are eligible to receive the vaccine through the Czech national vaccination programme in accordance with their rollout plan. If you are currently eligible for a vaccine, i.e. you have residency in the Czech Republic and are 70+ or work as a health professional, you can now register for a vaccine. Details of the national vaccination programme and the online booking  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210315200623/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/czech-republic/coronavirus

Vaccinations are available for groups A(paramedics, healthcare workers, critical infrastructure workers), B (people with chronic conditions), C (elderly 70+). Current vaccines used are BioNTech/Pfizer, Moderna, Astra Zeneca. (Orders & negotiations for other vaccines are ongoing.)  ""The central registration system is available for groups: persons older than 70 and 80 years of age, paramedics, people with chronic diseases, critical infrastructure. These categories are sorted by age, not by order of registration. Registration through GPs and specialist care centers:  persons older than 70 and 80 years of age who are not registered at vaccination sites and persons with serious chronic diseases who do not meet the age conditions.""  https://archive.vn/SKvll   https://archive.vn/DGgQy

No change of policy.  Reopening of schools are decided by the State Government, and within each state, decided by the District Government. No change of policy. Reopening of schools are decided by the State Government, and within each state, decided by the District Government based on the number of cases. Some states have reopened schools, although some remain closed. In Thüringen, schools must close if the 7-day incidence per 100,000 people is over 200, and is recommended to close if over 150 (Source: https://archive.ph/VE2WE). Since there are some districts within Thüringen (e.g. Wartburgkreis, which has a 7-day incidence of 305.9 per 100,000) with a 7-day incidence per 100,000 of over 150-200 (Source: https://archive.fo/HGmMG), I have coded this as 3T. ***These measures released March 3:  “Bookshops, florists and garden centres will be treated uniformly as retail for daily needs in all Länder” and can reopen.  They are subject to appropriate hygiene concepts and a limit of one customer per 10 square metres for the first 800 square metres of retail space, plus one customer for each additional 20 square metres.  “The remaining personal care service providers as well as driving schools and flight schools can also reopen with appropriate hygiene concepts, whereby a COVID-19 rapid test or self-administered test by the customer performed that day and a testing concept for the staff are required for the use of services in which a mask cannot be worn permanently - such as for cosmetics or shaving.”   Regulations for remaining sectors will be extended until 30 April 2021: “Employers must enable employees to work from home, provided that their work tasks permit this.”  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210307092502/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1873218/700fb03e258c9bdd15e80a69c7ad3dfe/2021-03-03-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

“The possibilities for private gatherings with friends and relatives will be expanded again from 8 March: private gatherings of one’s own household and another household will be possible, but limited to a maximum of five people. Children up to the age of 14 are not included in this limit. Couples are considered to be one household.”    Depending on the number of infections in each region, the restrictions for private gatherings can be further expanded or tightened.  -	In regions with a 7-day incidence of less than 35 new infections per week, the possibilities for private gatherings can be expanded to one’s own household and two additional households, with a maximum total of ten people. Children up to the age of 14 are not counted as part of this figure.  -	If the 7-day incidence per 100,000 inhabitants increases to more than 100 on three consecutive days in any Land or region, the rules that applied until 7 March will come into force again there from the second following working day (emergency brake). Afterwards, the possibility for private gatherings will once again be restricted to one's own household and one other person. Children up to the age of 14 are not included in this limit.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210307092502/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1873218/700fb03e258c9bdd15e80a69c7ad3dfe/2021-03-03-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

Lockdown extended to 28 March although restrictions have eased.  Some states are still enforcing a curfew from 10 pm – 5 am depending on the number of infections.  E.g., Bavaria is extending the current lockdown until March 7 for the time being. However, as of next Monday, February 15, the night curfew will be loosened: It will then only apply in cities and districts with a 7-day incidence above 100 and will then be in effect between 10 pm and 5 am. Where the incidence has been below 100 for seven days, a night curfew will no longer apply.  According to the data from RKI, there are still some cities in Bavaria where the 7-day incidence is above 100, hence I have coded it as 2T.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210312093847if_/https://www.br.de/nachrichten/deutschland-welt/coronavirus-in-bavaria-assistance-in-english,RtO8eS2  https://archive.fo/6V1yn

***Recoded from 3 to 1. While expansions of testing were announced, they will not be implemented until April meaning coding stays how it is currently.     Previous coding note:   Rapid tests will be made available for the general public.  The national testing strategy will therefore be supplemented by the following measures, which are to be implemented step by step by the beginning of April:   -	In order to ensure safe school operations and safe childcare, the Länder will ensure that staff in schools and childcare facilities as well as all pupils receive the offer of at least one free rapid test per week of attendance as part of their testing concepts. A certificate of the test result shall be issued where possible.   -	For comprehensive protection against infection, it is necessary that companies in Germany offer at least one free rapid test per week to their employees who are present at work, as part of their overall contribution to society. A certificate of the test result shall be issued where possible. The Federal Government will discuss this with the business community later this week.   -	All asymptomatic citizens will be allowed a free rapid test at least once a week, including a certificate of the test result, at a testing centre operated by the respective Land or municipality, at third parties commissioned by the respective Land or municipality or at GPs’ surgeries. The Federal Government will cover the costs from 8 March onwards.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210307092502/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1873218/700fb03e258c9bdd15e80a69c7ad3dfe/2021-03-03-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

No policy change – measured will only be implemented in April.  Some states have implemented a voluntary testing strategy for schoolchildren, but this will be formalized after Easter break.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210307092502/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1873218/700fb03e258c9bdd15e80a69c7ad3dfe/2021-03-03-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1   https://archive.fo/XDi5E   https://archive.fo/L6QzG

Since 8 March 2021, the Federal Government has been covering the cost of at least one free rapid test per week (public testing).  With the increasing availability of rapid tests and self-administered tests, comprehensive testing in schools and daycare centres is currently being introduced in the Länder."" Rigorous implementation of hygiene measures and testing will initially remain necessary. Two weeks after the second  vaccination, institutions which do not have any outbreaks of infection can loosen restrictions on visitors and reintroduce activities involving different groups of residents. From this point onwards, there will not be any need for measures which differentiate between vaccinated and unvaccinated residents. The institutions involved are required to promptly offer any unvaccinated people, such as new residents, the opportunity to be vaccinated.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326145328/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1881470/f0922369004c03634f34e502e79490b2/2021-03-24-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

""The coordinated measures came into force on March 17 and will remain in place until March 21 in the regions where Friday is a holiday: Madrid, Valencia, the Basque Country, Extremadura, Murcia, Navarre and Galicia. Madrid and Extremadura, the only regions that were still open to movement, will be subject to perimetral lockdowns. What’s more, these regions are limiting social meetings to a maximum of six people in open public spaces, four in closed areas and just those who live together in a private environment. There is also a curfew from 11pm to 6am, although the regions can bring this forward to 10pm if they wish. The same measures will be applied across Spain from March 26 to April 9, when all regions will be subject to a perimetral lockdown apart from the Canary and Balearic islands. Here is a region-by-region breakdown of the current restrictions across Spain.""     Targeted measures in Madrid and Extremadura between lockdowns.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210320001750/https://english.elpais.com/society/2021-03-18/coronavirus-in-spain-all-the-latest-restrictions-ahead-of-fathers-day-and-easter-week.html

From March 26: ""The coordinated measures came into force on March 17 and will remain in place until March 21 in the regions where Friday is a holiday: Madrid, Valencia, the Basque Country, Extremadura, Murcia, Navarre and Galicia. Madrid and Extremadura, the only regions that were still open to movement, will be subject to perimetral lockdowns. What’s more, these regions are limiting social meetings to a maximum of six people in open public spaces, four in closed areas and just those who live together in a private environment. There is also a curfew from 11pm to 6am, although the regions can bring this forward to 10pm if they wish. The same measures will be applied across Spain from March 26 to April 9, when all regions will be subject to a perimetral lockdown apart from the Canary and Balearic islands. Here is a region-by-region breakdown of the current restrictions across Spain.""     https://web.archive.org/web/20210320001750/https://english.elpais.com/society/2021-03-18/coronavirus-in-spain-all-the-latest-restrictions-ahead-of-fathers-day-and-easter-week.html

* Restrictions on flights from Brazil and South Africa will be extended until 13 April. Additionally, the land border between Spain and Portugal will remain closed until at least 6 April to fight the spread of the virus.   * Ban on travel from the UK has been lifted.  * Passengers arriving by sea and air must show a negative PCR test.    Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20210228153701/https://travelbans.org/europe/spain/ *** https://web.archive.org/web/20210324135338/https://english.elpais.com/spanish_news/2021-03-23/spain-to-lift-ban-on-travel-from-the-uk.html

Regional authorities have administered 5.7 million doses and fully vaccinated nearly 1.7 million people, but the jabs for essential workers have been put on hold due to the decision to halt the AstraZeneca vaccine. Starting from March 11, all students of general schools, vocational schools and institutions of higher education are doing distance learning. Being on the school premises is allowed for a student who requires educational support services, consultations to achieve learning results, or is taking exams or tests.    https://archive.is/lfaTP

From the 6th of March, customers are only permitted in catering establishments from 6am to 6pm and the room may not exceed 25%. On weekends, catering establishments will closed to customers for eating and drinking. Takeaway is allowed at any rime    From 6th of March, shops must be closed on weekends. On these days, sales may only take place outdoors or via delivery pick up. This does not apply to essential vendors.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210307180353/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/government-approved-introduction-new-restrictions-prevent-spread-coronavirus

Starting from March 11, only stores selling essential goods may stay open, meaning grocery stores, pharmacies, stores selling aid equipment and medical devices, the sales points of the representations of telecommunications enterprises, optics stores, pet stores and filling stations.    https://archive.is/lfaTP

The public indoor spaces of all theatres, cinemas, museums, exhibition and conference facilities, children’s playrooms, bowling and pool halls, night clubs, casinos etc must be closed for visitors until April 11.  Religious and church services are prohibited.  Organising outdoor public meetings and public religious services will remain allowed but no more than ten people may participate in them.    https://archive.is/lfaTP

The 2+2 rule must be followed in all public spaces, meaning that up to two people can move around together, keeping a distance of two metres from others. The restriction does not apply to a family moving around together, or if what it prescribes cannot be ensured reasonably.    Organising outdoor public meetings and public religious services will remain allowed but no more than ten people may participate in them.    https://archive.is/lfaTP
Is public transportation operating?  Yes.    https://archive.is/R9mUW
Interpreted from closure of non-essential shops and other restrictions for gatherings.
Is a curfew in place?  No.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  No.    https://archive.is/R9mUW

Estonian citizens and residents are allowed into the country regardless of whether they are symptomatic or not. Citizens and residents of the Schengen area are allowed to enter the country if they are not symptomatic.     Entering Estonia from outside the European Union, European Economic Area or Schengen area, for tourism, among other things, is only allowed from countries listed in Annex 1 of the recommendation enacted by the Council of the European Union. The movement restriction applies if the infection indicator of a country listed in Annex 1 is higher than 16.    https://archive.is/lfaTP

The March wage compensation approved by the Government today is intended only to pay wages to those employees whose workloads or wages have decreased significantly.     Self-employed people will also receive support. The support is paid only to employees who have not been employed in the agreed volume or whose wages have been reduced. The Estonian Unemployment Insurance Fund reimburses the employer for 60 percent of the employee’s previous average wages, but not more than 1,000 euros per month (gross).    https://archive.ph/a7hRf
No new policies found  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307193705/https://www.kriis.ee/en
Dedicated website and hotline for COVID information.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307193705/https://www.kriis.ee/en

Coronavirus test will be done for:  people at any age with symptoms  people at any age with any medical indication  people receiving hospital in-patient care with virus symptoms    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316105511/https://www.kriis.ee/en/testing-virus

All people who have been in close contact with the confirmed sick person must remain at home in isolation. This is also the case where exposure to the coronavirus has occurred through the surrounding environment (contaminated surfaces, buildings, etc.).    Due to the maximum incubation period for COVID-19 infectious disease, we ask you to stay at home for 10 days from close contact and monitor your health.     The Health Board recommends that close contacts undergo a test to detect possible asymptomatic illness at the end of the 10-calendar-day quarantine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316114058/https://kkk.kriis.ee/et/kkk/koroonaviirus-tervis/haigusnahud-nakatumiskahtlus-ja-terviseseisundi-jalgimine

Masks or mouth/nose coverings are mandatory in all public indoor places.? Children up to age 12 and those with medical conditions are exempt as long as the 2+2 rule is observed.    https://archive.is/R9mUW

A,B,C:  AstraZeneca, Pfizer, Moderna  On 27 December, the process of vaccination against COVID-19 was launched in Estonia with the vaccination of healthcare workers. The vaccination process has been launched for those individuals who are over seventy years of age and who are included in a risk group based on their diagnosis.   In the week of 15 February, vaccination centres commenced the vaccination of the employees of educational institutions.  On 16 February, vaccination commenced against COVID-19 for frontline workers who are responsible for ensuring internal security    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208230159/https://www.vaktsineeri.ee/en/covid19

Visitations are allowed in hospitals, care homes, shelters and safe houses. You can get more information on the visitation requirements from the social welfare institutions.    People staying in general and special care homes are allowed to leave the territory of the care home, provided that they are wearing personal protective equipment if necessary.    https://archive.is/lfaTP    Among other things, it is necessary to ensure that: (a) the visitor, the visitor and / or staff use personal protective equipment (masks, etc.) where appropriate ; (b) the  meeting shall be held outdoors or in special rooms , if possible ; (c) the visitor submits a health declaration in advance ; (d) the disinfection requirements have been met in accordance with the instructions for the visit .    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316113849/https://www.kriis.ee/et/eriolukord-koroonaviirus

The regional administrative agencies of Southern Finland, Southwest Finland and Western and Inner Finland have ordered the closure of school premises in their respective territories until 28 March 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210303031435/https://avi.fi/usein-kysyttya-koronaviruksesta       Decision with diary number LSAVI / 2188/2021, applies to the municipalities of Southwest Finland and Satakunta. When a person is diagnosed with a coronavirus infection, the municipality of residence carries out contract tracing, on the basis of which nearby contacts are quarantined. If a person is not considered a close contact, they can continue their life as normal.    Contact tracing can take some time, especially if there are many exposed persons. If you do not know what to do, contact health care to check the situation.    https://archive.vn/PacWd

The nationwide night-time curfew remains in place, with modified hours (7pm to 6am).     From midnight on 19 March, containment measures have been implemented in 16 departments (Aisne, Alpes-Maritimes, Essonne, Eure, Hauts-de-Seine, Nord, Oise, Paris, Pas-de-Calais, Seine-et-Marne, Seine-Saint-Denis, Seine-Maritime, Somme, Val-de-Marne, Val-d'Oise and Yvelines) recommending that people stay at home. They are allowed to be outside within a 10km radius of their home between the hours of 6am and 7pm with proof of residence, but must produce a certificate explaining the essential nature of their travel if further than 10km from their residence.     These measures will be in place for at least 4 weeks.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210319145818/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
No change, https://web.archive.org/web/20210319145818/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

The nationwide night-time curfew remains in place, people must remain at home between 7pm and 6am with limited exceptions & self-certification required for those outside the home during these hours.     From 26 March, the containment measures implemented in 16 departments have been extended to an additional 3; Aube, Nièvre, and Rhône. In these 19 departments people allowed to be outside within a 10km radius of their home between the hours of 6am and 7pm with proof of residence, but must produce a certificate explaining the essential nature of their travel if further than 10km from their residence.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210326033004/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
The internal movement restrictions announced for the Alpes-Maritimes and Dunkirk regions are not applied from the morning of 1 March through 5 March.

From February 26 through March 1, and again from March 5 through March 8th, travel into and within the Alpes-Maritimes region will be restricted. Extracts from the requirements published by the Alpes-Maritimes Department follow:     - Partial containment will be implemented from Friday, February 26 at 6 p.m. to Monday, March 1 at 6 a.m. and Friday, March 5 at 6 p.m. to Monday, March 8 at 6 a.m. During these periods, travel not justified by one of the derogatory reasons will be prohibited. These derogatory reasons, which will be certified, relate to travel related to a professional activity or the purchase of supplies related to the exercise of a professional activity; travel related to the purchase of basic necessities; Travel for medical reasons Travel motivated by compelling family motives; travel related to individual physical activity and the exit of pets for up to one hour and within a 5 km radius around the home.  - The area affected by this measure extends over the coastal area of the Alpes-Maritimes  - As for the conditions of entry into the territory, they will be subject to strengthened controls, at the Franco-Italian border (road and rail lanes) as well as at Nice Côte d'Azur and Cannes-Mandelieu airports with the completion of PCR tests on all passengers of randomly selected flights.  - The internal security forces are fully mobilized to ensure compliance with these measures, as are the state services in charge of the control of trades.    Full details at https://web.archive.org/web/20210227042501/https://www.alpes-maritimes.gouv.fr/Actualites/COVID-19-Point-sur-la-situation-dans-les-Alpes-Maritimes/COVID-19-Adoptions-de-mesures-complementaires    ***Updated to add targeted weekend lockdown in Dunkirk: http://web.archive.org/web/20210314142725/https://www.connexionfrance.com/French-news/Covid-Weekend-lockdown-in-Dunkirk-as-UK-variant-spreads

You should not have any visitors during this time, and you should not go shopping or do other errands. You may go for a drive in your own car and take a walk outdoors, but only where you do not come into contact with other people. You should have no direct contact with anyone considered to be in a vulnerable group:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308225436/https://blog.wego.com/faroe-islands-travel-restrictions-and-quarantine-requirements/

You should not have any visitors during this time, and you should not go shopping or do other errands. You may go for a drive in your own car and take a walk outdoors, but only where you do not come into contact with other people. You should have no direct contact with anyone considered to be in a vulnerable group:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308225436/https://blog.wego.com/faroe-islands-travel-restrictions-and-quarantine-requirements/

All people travelling to the Faroe Islands must be tested for COVID-19. This requirement also applies to Faroese citizens and residents who have been travelling abroad. Children younger than 12 do not need to be tested. This will be mandatory until 1.April 2021. Hospital test centres are set up where travellers can get tested free of charge or travellers can pay to get tested at a private laboratory (Thetis):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308225436/https://blog.wego.com/faroe-islands-travel-restrictions-and-quarantine-requirements/

PCR tests are required on the border until 30. June, until further notice. (Travellers pay for the test).  From 1st April all vaccinated travellers to the Faroe Islands, who have been vaccinated at least eight days prior will not need to self-isolate for six days after arrival. For everyone else, the recommendation to quarantine at home for six days and to test again after the sixth day after arrival will be in effect until 1st June. Children under 12 years will now be offered a PCR test for free at the border. Limited international travel is recommended for citizens and internationals.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210321111941/https://corona.fo/news/887/government-eases-covid-19-restrictions?_l=en

campaign to raise awareness, as well as information on government website:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308225510/https://dk.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/

Starting with 1st of March, the citizens from Armenia, Azerbaijan, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Russia, and Belarus are allowed to arrive in country by plane with a negative PCR-test result. There are in place health screening procedures at airports and other ports of entry. All passengers, who have travelled to the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland within the last 14 days will be placed in mandatory quarantine at personal expense for 12 days upon entry.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/f971x and https://archive.fo/FJtFx

There are in place health screening procedures at airports and other ports of entry. All passengers, who have travelled to the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland within the last 14 days will be placed in mandatory quarantine at personal expense for 12 days upon entry. Passengers arriving in Georgia without proof of vaccination, or a proof of a recent negative COVID-19 test may be placed in mandatory quarantine or a Georgian medical facility, each at personal expense, for an undetermined period of time. Face masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, including taxis and public transportation. Violators of face musk rules are subject to a 20 GEL (about 6 USD) fine. There are some exceptions for children under 6, people with disabilities, or who have health problems that prevent them from wearing a face covering.  Link: https://archive.fo/FJtFx

Georgian Health Minister stated that 43200 doses of the AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine will arrive in Georgia at the end of the week (12-14th of March). She stated that medical personnel and risk groups will be vaccinated first. Also, Georgia will receive 29250 doses of Pfizer vaccine by the end of March. DE Malesinas is declared a Civil Protection Emergency from Sunday 28-02-2021 at 06:00 until Monday 08-03-2021 at 06:00.    Restrictions include: Suspension of the lifelong educational function of primary and secondary school units (kindergartens, primary, all-day schools, high schools and general and vocational schools), as well as all other educational structures (excluding special education schools). Courses will be conducted through distance learning (tele-education).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227213715/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/kiryxi-se-katastasi-ektaktis-anagkis-politikis-prostasias-tis-de-malesinas

Extending the code based on prevailing policy till March 8 2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316130010/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/kiryxi-se-katastasi-ektaktis-anagkis-politikis-prostasias-tis-de-malesinas

""Suspension of the lifelong educational function of primary and secondary school units (kindergartens, primary, all-day schools, high schools and secondary schools of general and vocational education), as well as all other educational structures of the joint ministerial decision under items D1a/G.O.P.69543/ 31.10.2020 (B' 4810), as extended and amended by the Joint Ministerial Decision under D1a/G.O.P.969/7.1.2021 (B' 23). Exceptionally, the living educational function is allowed (a) of primary schools and kindergartens in the Municipality of Mykonos of the Regional Unit of Mykonos of the South Aegean Region and in the Municipality of Thira of the Regional Unit of Thira of the South Aegean Region, (b) of the special education and education units of all levels."" - https://web.archive.org/web/20210316131804/https://covid19.gov.gr/covid-map    ""After an emergency meeting at the Centre for Civil Protection Operations, taking into account the epidemiological data that have emerged in the settlement of Dafnoula of the Local Community of New Argyri Municipality of Agrafa of the Evritania IP, at the behest of the Deputy Minister of Civil Protection and Crisis Management, Nikos Chardalias and a decision of the Secretary General of Civil Protection, Vasilios Papageorgiou, on the recommendation of the National Committee for the Protection of Public Health against Koronoi Covid-19 and the Mayor of Agrafa, for urgent reasons of addressing a serious public health risk and in particular to limit the spread of the effects of Covid-19 disease, additional restrictive measures are applied in the settlement of Dafnoula from Wednesday 10-03-2021 at 06:00 until Tuesday 16-03-2021 at 06:00 for public health reasons.    The suspension of the lifelong educational function of primary school units (kindergartens, primary schools). Courses will be conducted through distance learning (tele-education).""   - https://web.archive.org/web/20210316133113/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/efarmogi-prostheton-perioristikon-metron-ston-oikismo-dafnoyla-eyrytanias

Schools are closed as part of the lockdown restrictions. Greek Education Minister Niki Kerameos said all efforts were being made to re-open primary and high schools sometime during the week beginning April 5. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210330080943/https://news.gtp.gr/2021/03/29/opening-retail-crucial-for-greeces-post-covid-recovery/

DE Malesinas is declared a Civil Protection Emergency from Sunday 28-02-2021 at 06:00 until Monday 08-03-2021 at 06:00.    Restrictions include: The temporary imposition of a house restriction on residents and the 24-hour curfew, with the exception of pet traffic, individually and around the permanent residence (sms code 6) or for health reasons (sms code 1) or for catering purposes (sms 2- and with the exception of the period between 18:00 and 06:00 of the following) or for work purposes only (within the DE Malesina , for services which remain open and with the relevant certificate).    Although not explicitly stated as required to close, aligning indicator with movement restrictions, assuming that citizens under a total lockdown cannot use public transportation options.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227213715/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/kiryxi-se-katastasi-ektaktis-anagkis-politikis-prostasias-tis-de-malesinas

In general, travel outside the home should be avoided, but is permitted for work and for a limited number of reasons between the hours of 5:00am and 9:00pm. These reasons include health, to  buy essential supplies if delivery is not possible in time, and for essential banking or urgent appointments for public services (e.g., electricity), within an individual's municipality or 2km from their home. https://web.archive.org/web/20210330075700/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

""Is a curfew in place? Yes  A nationwide lockdown is in effect 24 hours per day.  A nighttime curfew is additionally in effect from 9:00pm to 5:00am throughout the country.  As of March 4, 2021, the weekend curfew is expanded in Athens, Thessaloniki and other high COVID areas, in effect from 7:00pm to 5:00am.  Athens will continue to observe an expanded weekend curfew through at least March 16.  Other “deep red” areas as of March 4 include Achaia, Arcadia, Larissa, Lefkada (except Meganisi), Fthiotida, Argolida, Corinth, Thesprotia, Arta, Samos, Boeotia, Chios, Etoloakarnania, Rhodes, Heraklion, Evia (except Skyros), and the Municipality of Kalymnos.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316130829/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
