Authorities announced 24-hour movement restrictions, including an extended night-time curfew. https://web.archive.org/web/20210330075700/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

https://web.archive.org/web/20210316130829/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    ""US citizens residing in the United States are banned from entering Greece per details above under Entry and Exit Requirements.  All travelers entering Greece through March 8, 2021 are subject to a mandatory seven-day preventive quarantine, as announced January 8, 2021.  In addition, travelers who entered Greece from the United Kingdom must take a PCR test at the end of the quarantine period with negative results in order to be released from preventive quarantine, according to the airport website.  Travelers are advised to check with Greek authorities regarding any quarantine restrictions in effect at the time of entry into Greece.  On July 9, 2020, the Greek Ministry of Foreign Affairs posted procedures for international arrivals.  See the airport website for additional details.  If you are tested for COVID-19, you are permitted to travel to your final destination where you must self quarantine for 24 hours (or longer as described above).  If positive, you will be notified and quarantined for 14 days.  If negative, you will not be notified.""

The Greek Ministry of Health has developed a priority system for COVID-19 vaccination and system for appointments, available on the Greek government webpage at https://emvolio.gov.gr/. The current phase of vaccination is for individuals age 75 and above, individuals age 60-65, and individuals with certain high-risk health conditions, according to announcements by the National Public Health Organization.  The vaccination phase for individuals age 70-74 opened as of March 26, 2021. So, priority groups currently are the elderly and those with co-morbidities. https://web.archive.org/web/20210330075700/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Croatia tightens entry regulations from mutation areas.   People entering Croatia from these regions, need a negative PCR test that is max. 48 hours old and must also undergo 14 days of self-isolation (at their own expense), from which they can free themselves on the 7th day at the earliest by means of a negative PCR test (at their own expense).   Entry to Croatia is restricted until 15.3.2021.   From EU/Schengen countries that are NOT on the ""green list"" of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), entry is only possible with a negative PCR test that is max. 48 hours old. Details and exceptions see below.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210228192050/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronoavirus-update-kroatien.html

The measures in place initially until 1 March 2021 remain in force until 15 March 2021.  All teaching above the eighth grade, i.e. higher education, is online.  Nurseries, kindergartens, and primary schools will remain open to those under 14.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227105017/https://hungarytoday.hu/coronavirus-hungary-restrictions-extended-march-15/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210301211044/http://abouthungary.hu/news-in-brief/coronavirus-heres-the-latest/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301202233/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

From 08 March to 22 March, additional restrictions are in place and include the closure of shops and services. Kindergartens and primary schools will be closed until 7 April.    - Kindergartens and primary schools are not allowed to open until the end of spring break, and the content of digital education is determined by the ministers concerned. Digital education in secondary schools and higher education will continue.    The Ministry said there would be an extraordinary break in kindergartens, with the first working day after that on April 7. Education in schools will take place on a digital work schedule outside the classroom until 31 March, with the first day of school after the spring break there after 7 April. All public education institutions have been informed of the measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314200716/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/emmi-hetfotol-hatalyosak-az-uj-intezkedesek-koznevelesi-intezmenyekben  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314200812/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/ket-het-szigoritasrol-dontott-kormany-abban-remenyben-hogy-husvetkor-ujra-tudjuk-inditani-az  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314195209/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/kormanyinfo-szigoritasokrol-dontott-kormany  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314193404/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/
Higher education is still online.  Kindergartens, primary, and secondary schools will be closed until April 7.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210321201621/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

Current restrictions remain in place and the government has indicated that there will be no changes until 2.5 million people have received their first dose of the vaccine.    Schools are not expected to open until April 12 or 19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210327212343/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/kormanyhu-megjelent-kozlonyben-vedelmi-intezkedesek-lepcsozetes-feloldasanak-elso-fokozatarol  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327212207/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/orszagos-tisztifoorvos-jarvanyugyi-adatok-indokoljak-szigoru-vedelmi-intezkedesek  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327205211/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

The measures in place initially until 1 March 2021 remain in force until 15 March 2021.    All shops and services, with the exception of pharmacies and petrol stations, must close at 7 p.m.  Restaurants, cafés, bars, and clubs are closed. Only take-out and delivery service is permitted.  Leisure facilities are closed, including museums, theatres, gyms, swimming pools, cinemas and zoos.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227105017/https://hungarytoday.hu/coronavirus-hungary-restrictions-extended-march-15/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210301211044/http://abouthungary.hu/news-in-brief/coronavirus-heres-the-latest/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301202233/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

From 08 March to 22 March, additional restrictions are in place and include the closure of shops and services. Kindergartens and primary schools will be closed until 7 April.    - Shops must be closed. Exception: grocery stores, pharmacies, petrol stations, drugstores, tobacco shops, shops selling materials and equipment essential for economic, agricultural and forestry activities, as well as pet food and feed shops, the market and the farmers' market.  - All services are suspended, except for private health, social, financial, postal and vehicle service services. In view of Women's Day, flower shops can remain open on Monday 8 March, but then they have to close.  - Restaurants will still be able to buy takeaways.  - Kindergartens and primary schools are not allowed to open until the end of spring break, and the content of digital education is determined by the ministers concerned. Digital education in secondary schools and higher education will continue.  - Given the low infection rates, daycares do not close.  - The evening curfew will remain in effect.  - Masking is mandatory on all streets and public areas within the populated area.  - If possible, keep a protective distance of at least 1.5 metres from the other person.  - Work is possible, but we recommend working from home where possible. In the administration, work at home may be ordered, except in the case of those involved in the defence.  - Outdoor sports activities are possible, where a distance of 1.5 meters can be maintained. Training of certified athletes is permitted, matches are only possible behind closed gates.  - Parks, arboretums and forests remain open.  - We're tightening up border crossings, but we're not restricting transit and freight traffic.  - We are extending wage subsidies and tax breaks to sectors that need to close.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314200812/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/ket-het-szigoritasrol-dontott-kormany-abban-remenyben-hogy-husvetkor-ujra-tudjuk-inditani-az  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314195209/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/kormanyinfo-szigoritasokrol-dontott-kormany  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314193404/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

Non-essential shops and services are closed.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210321201621/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210321205445/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/galgoczi-meg-mindig-emelkedo-fazisban-van-harmadik-hullam

Current restrictions remain in place and the government has indicated that there will be no changes until 2.5 million people have received their first dose of the vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210327212343/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/kormanyhu-megjelent-kozlonyben-vedelmi-intezkedesek-lepcsozetes-feloldasanak-elso-fokozatarol  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327212207/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/orszagos-tisztifoorvos-jarvanyugyi-adatok-indokoljak-szigoru-vedelmi-intezkedesek  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327205211/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

Training of certified athletes is permitted, matches are only possible behind closed gates.  - Parks, arboretums and forests remain open.  - We're tightening up border crossings, but we're not restricting transit and freight traffic.  - We are extending wage subsidies and tax breaks to sectors that need to close.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314200812/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/ket-het-szigoritasrol-dontott-kormany-abban-remenyben-hogy-husvetkor-ujra-tudjuk-inditani-az  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314195209/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/kormanyinfo-szigoritasokrol-dontott-kormany  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314193404/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

Training of certified athletes is permitted, matches are only possible behind closed gates.  - Parks, arboretums and forests remain open.  - We're tightening up border crossings, but we're not restricting transit and freight traffic.  - We are extending wage subsidies and tax breaks to sectors that need to close.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314200812/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/ket-het-szigoritasrol-dontott-kormany-abban-remenyben-hogy-husvetkor-ujra-tudjuk-inditani-az  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314195209/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/kormanyinfo-szigoritasokrol-dontott-kormany  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314193404/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

""Half of primary school students – junior infants, senior infants, first class and second class – and sixth years returned to school today for the first time since before Christmas. Schools for children with special needs also reopened at full capacity.""     https://www.thejournal.ie/schools-reopen-students-return-5368172-Mar2021/ [link not archiving]

From 8 March, there will be resumption of Early Childhood Care and Education. One week later on 15 March, it is planned that 3rd, 4th, 5th and 6th classes at primary level can get back to school along with 5th year students in post-primary schools.  From 29 March, it is envisaged to resume early learning and care and school age childcare. It is then planned that remaining post-primary school students will return on 12 April, post the Easter break.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210309085831/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/0843e-briefing-on-government-measures-in-response-to-covid-19-wednesday-3-march-2021/

No policy change. No closures, but 2-metre social distancing requirement must be observed. Restaurants, bars, and nightclubs can remain open until 23:00, but must comply with social distancing rules and 50 person limit. Pharmacies and stores may accept 5 persons for each 10 m2 of space and may have up to 200 customers in their premises, as long as it is possible to ensure at least 2 metres between persons who are unrelated. Health and physical fitness centres may remain open at 75% capacity.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210321223753/https://www.covid.is/categories/effective-restrictions-on-gatherings
Nightclubs and bars are closed.  Arcades and gambling machines are closed.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210330102259/https://www.covid.is/categories/effective-restrictions-on-gatherings

No policy change. Travel restrictions apply to all third-country citizens. Citizens of Iceland,  EEA/EFTA citizens, or relatives of Icelandic/EEA/EFTA citizens are exempt. Further exemptions are granted for essential travel.    Third-country nationals traveling to Iceland are required to pre-register before departure; provide proof of a negative PCR test; take two tests to screen for the presence of COVID-19 after arrival in Iceland, with a mandatory 5-6 day quarantine between each test.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322092330/https://www.logreglan.is/english/regarding-travel-restrictions-to-iceland-as-a-result-of-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322092500/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/visiting-iceland

On March 25, a new decree was signed by the head of the chief sanitary doctor of Kazakhstan.   permission in the fourth quarter of the 2020-2021 academic year:  - in all regions of the republic: teaching in a traditional format in urban and rural schools with a contingent of up to 300 students, with a number of children in classes of no more than 25 people;  individual teaching of students after school hours in groups of no more than 15 people by decision of the administration of the educational organization;  - in regions located in low and moderate-risk zones (green and yellow zones), teaching in a combined format in general education schools for students of all grades, with the number of children in classes no more than 25 people;  - in regions located in the high-risk zone (red zone):  teaching in a combined format in general education schools for students of preschool classes, from grades 1 to 5 inclusive, in international schools - from grades 1 to 7 inclusive, with the number of children in classes no more than 25 people;  teaching in a combined format for 6 days of the week for graduation classes (grades 9, 11 (12)): 70% of subjects in the regular mode, 30% - in distance (no more than 15 people in a class, training according to the principle ""1 grade - 1 cabinet "", compliance with sanitary-disinfection and mask regimes);"";  Link: https://archive.vn/ahzKe

A wide variety of businesses – including gyms and fitness centers, pools, beaches, cultural facilities, museums, exhibits, entertainment centers, religious facilities, some movie theaters, food courts, and recreational facilities – are open,  in some cases subject to restrictions on hours of operation subject to capacity limitations.   However, some regional and local governments periodically impose restrictions in response to increases in the infection rate.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210314173918/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

An enhanced public health measures in Almaty city extended until 12 April 2021. An operation of museums, libraries, shopping centers, educational centers, wholesale/retail outdoor and indoor non-grocery markets, spa centers, swimming pools, public baths, theaters, cinemas, concert halls, fitness centers, mass skating on ""Medeo"", Shymbulak, religious objects, cultural facilities, a circus, computer clubs, bowling, banquet halls, night, gaming and lotto clubs, karaoke have been suspended.     Nur-Sultan city also strengthened public health measures as of 30 March 2021:  working hours of shopping/entertainment center reduced on weekdays until 17:00 hours, with a ban on weekends; fitness centers work only on weekdays, with ban on weekends; students/schoolchildren except for 9, 11 (12) grades students are switching to distance learning; saunas, SPA centers are prohibited; catering facilities are prohibited on weekends, except for delivery work and take-out orders. Cinemas, bowling centers, children entertainment centers remain suspended.  Links: https://archive.vn/CIKb4 https://archive.vn/hyMTQ

Uilsky district of Aktobe region entered the ""red zone"" for the spread of coronavirus. Sanitary posts have been established there.   ""Everyone who enters or leaves the district center will have their temperature measured and data recorded. Those who have symptoms of COVID-19 will be isolated for two days in a quarantine hospital for PCR testing.  Link: https://archive.vn/6iATq

Due to deterioration of the epidemiological situation, the East Kazakhstan region has strengthen public health restrictions, including entry and exit restrictions out and into the region starting from April 02, 2021.   A number of road sanitary control posts have been deployed for vehicle and pedestrian crossings.     The both entry and exit of people to and from the territory (s) of the region will be prohibited except for limited individuals upon prior presentation of supporting/approving documents from the local authorities.  Each authorized traveler must undergo a temperature check and fill out a questionnaire on prior travel, potential Covid-19 exposure, and contact information.   Those who have symptoms of Covid-19 are isolated for up to 2 days in a local quarantine hospital for PCR testing. If the result is positive, they will be sent to the infectious diseases hospital.      In addition, the authorized travelers coming from “red zones” of Kazakhstan (as of April 2 they are: Nur-Sultan city, Almaty city, Atyrau, Aktobe, Almaty, and West Kazakhstan regions) will be required to provide a negative result of PCR test for Covid-19 for a period of no more than 3 days (72 hours). If they are unable to provide negative PCR test results, they will be denied entry.   Link: https://archive.vn/WaHQQ

Sputnik V consists of 2 stages. Currently, about 28,388 people received the vaccine stage 1, and about 14933 people received the vaccine stage 2. Now, only key workers are receiving vaccines. It is planned to vaccinate vulnerable people from April 1.  Link: https://archive.vn/VpOYW

As of March 31, more than 173 thousand people in Kazakhstan received at least one dose of the Russian Sputnik V vaccine. First of all, doctors, key workers - police officers, teachers, who are in contact with a large number of people, have been vaccinated. From April, the government is planning to start vaccinating elderly people.     Kazakhstan launched local production of the Russia-developed vaccine (Sputnik V) in December 2020 and started voluntary vaccination of the local population on February 1. The authorities plan to vaccinate six million people (about one third of the population) free of charge by end-2021. The first stage vaccination is expected to cover groups with high risk exposure, including doctors, teachers, and law enforcement workers. In addition, a locally developed vaccine (QazCovid-in) and the vaccine developed by Pfizer/BioNTech are expected to be available later in the year. Mass vaccination is expected to start after priority groups complete vaccination, likely in May. The authorities are also conducting an awareness campaign about vaccination, including recent statements by the President to counter misinformation about the vaccines.  Links: https://archive.vn/W1l7I https://archive.vn/Eau3N https://archive.vn/IG3zg

Although international flights are operating, all persons entering Kyrgyzstan by air must produce proof of a negative COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival; exceptions will be made for passengers on flights that become delayed due to weather. Travelers without a negative test certificate will be tested at the border; those who test positive will be placed in a government quarantine facility for up to 14 days. Travelers entering the country through land border checkpoints are also required to produce a negative test certificate. Diplomats, international transport crews, freight drivers, and infants are exempt from this requirement."" Evidence of limited contact tracing seen as it is done in some cases but is not mandatory. A voluntary app was introduced in May 2020, but has not been made mandatory.  _____________________________________________________    Quote from linked article 1:  ""Contact tracing is being implemented. So far, the Ministry of Health is able to trace all cases to several clusters. The Ministry of Health is using event and indicator-based surveillance.    On 8 December 2020, the Ministry of Health representative provided an update on the situation with COVID-19 cases among school children. 48 cases of COVID-19 among children aged 7-17 years were registered in September, whereas in October this number increased 6.5 times, reaching a total number of 315 cases. According to data available on 1 December, there were 320 registered cases. The Ministry of Health official emphasized that all of these cases are not related to school attendance but associated with household outbreaks."" Speaking on state radio, the minister said that 504,000 doses of AstraZeneca vaccine will arrive in Kyrgyzstan in late February under COVAX, a global initiative to ensure quick and equal access to vaccines against COVID-19.    Beishenaliev said that in order for life to return to normal, it is necessary to vaccinate at least 70-80 percent of the population.    ""We have developed a national vaccination program. According to the program, first of all, doctors, teachers, border guards will be vaccinated, that is, those persons who are in direct contact with large masses of people,"" Beishenaliev noted.    The minister also said that negotiations are underway to secure Russian and Chinese vaccines.    ""To date, we have ordered 500,000 doses of the Russian vaccine. The Foreign Ministry is also working with China on the supply of vaccines,""    Web archived link 1:  http://archive.today/2021.03.07-142344/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2021-02/10/c_139735603.htm

Beginning March 1, public events of up to 10 people will be allowed, but no food or drink are allowed to be served. Up to 10 people will also be allowed for gatherings in public areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315080200/http://www.liechtensteinusa.org/article/measures-taken-in-liechtenstein-in-response-to-the-coronavirus-pandemic

In Liechtenstein, due to the customs treaty with Switzerland, the same regulations apply as in Switzerland. Here you will find a very good overview. Please read carefully!    Fill out the  electronic registration form  on the platform of the Swiss Federal Office of Public Health (FOPH) before entering the country . For the canton, enter:  Liechtenstein As soon as you have filled out the form, you will receive a QR code by email as confirmation. Have this code ready for entry controls.  On arrival you must be able to show a negative PCR test that is not older than 72 hours (does not apply to children up to 12 years of age! ).  People who cannot present a test with a negative result upon arrival must have themselves tested at their own expense immediately after entering the test street (Marktplatzgarage Vaduz, daily 2:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m.)  A negative test result does not exempt you from the quarantine obligation.  You go into a 10-day quarantine immediately upon arrival.  Quarantine leaflet  Report your entry to   the Office of Public Health within two days using the Return journey from risk countries form . [Open the form, save it on the computer, fill it in, save it again and send it] ( german version )  Due to the current situation with the spread of the various virus mutations, no shortening of the entry quarantine can be approved in Liechtenstein until further notice.  If there are no symptoms of the disease, you can end the quarantine after 10 days. The day of entry is considered the first day. On the eleventh day you can participate in public life again.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210330123957if_/https://www.llv.li/inhalt/118975/amtsstellen/einreise-und-quarantane

Beginning March 1,  For all gatherings and establishments, strict protective procedures must be maintained. As of Monday, Sweden, Hungary and Jordan have been added to the list of countries whence arrivals fall subject to enhanced communicable disease control measures, while arrivals from Ireland, Denmark, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Monaco, Turks and Caicos will be subject to the usual self-isolation requirements.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210324174101/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/updated-list-of-affected-countries-changes-in-self-isolation-requirements-for-arrivals-from-nine-countries

Following the Friday update, the Republic of Cyprus, Palestine and the Republic of Poland have been added to the list of countries whence arrivals fall subject to tighter self-isolation requirements; the State of Israel and the Republic of Slovenia have been removed from the list. From now on, travellers who qualify for self-isolation exemption will be required to provide documented evidence to this effect.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210324174000/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/updated-list-of-affected-countries-travellers-will-be-required-to-prove-that-they-qualify-for-self-isolation-exemption

Following the Friday update, the Principality of Andorra, Aruba, the Republic of Bulgaria, Kosovo, the French Republic, the Italian Republic, the Republic of Slovenia, the Republic of North Macedonia and the Oriental Republic of Uruguay have been added to the list of countries whence arrivals fall subject to tighter self-isolation requirements; the Republic of Slovenia has been removed from the list. There is a new requirement for crew members who plan to stay in Lithuania longer than 72 hours to bring in a negative COVID-19 test or get tested in Lithuania.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329065537/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/updated-list-of-affected-countries-a-new-requirement-for-carriers
A,B:
No updated policy measure.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210315095120/https://covid19.public.lu/en/news-covid19/communiques/2021/02-fevrier/05-education.html
No updates.

No updated policy measures. Restaurants, bars, and cafes are closed to the public. However, take-out, drive-in, and home delivery services remain open.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210315203047/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/restaurants-bars.html

Policy: Restaurants, bars and cafes are closed to the public. Indeed, these places give rise to important social interactions and, by the very nature of these places dedicated to the consumption of food and / or drinks, wearing a mask is not always possible.    However, this closure does not concern school and university canteens.    Take-out, drive-through and door-to-door delivery services are also possible.    Hotels and other accommodation establishments remain open. Their restaurants and bars, however, are closed to the public, while room service and take-out service are available.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329224527/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/restaurants-bars.html

No updated policy changes. Sporting events are not open to the public. The cultural institutions are open to the public, but subject to strict health rules (limited number of spectators, face mask-wearing, etc.)  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315211420/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/sports-cultes-culture.html

Policy: It seems like public events are possible for up to 100 people on the condition that they are assigned a seat and maintain an interpersonal distance of 2 metres.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210330215253/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/sport-religion-culture.html

No updated policy measures. Both indoor and outdoor gatherings are permitted. Nevertheless, in order to limit the risks associated with the spread of the virus, any gathering exceeding 100 people is prohibited. Children are counted, regardless of their age.  The general restrictions on the number of people allowed to take part in sports activities and the restrictions on the number of people allowed per locker room and per collective shower area remain in place.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315211420/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/sports-cultes-culture.html

Policy: In all circumstances for activities open to the public that are circulating and which are taking place in a closed place (e.g. in administrations open to the public, shops and supermarkets), as well as on public transport.  for any gathering of more than 4 and up to 10 people included.  In addition to wearing a mask, a physical distance of at least 2 metres is compulsory for gatherings of more than 4 and up to 10 people included. The obligation of wearing a mask and maintaining a physical distance of at least 2 metres does not apply to people who are part of the same household or who live together.    In addition to the obligation of wearing a mask and maintaining a physical distance of at least 2 metres, the assignment of seats is compulsory for gatherings involving between 11 and 100 people included. The obligation of maintaining a physical distance of at least 2 metres does not apply to people who are part of the same household or who live together  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210330221253/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html

No updated policy measures. Wearing masks is compulsory, and keeping a distance of 2m between passengers is required.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315212440/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/transports-publics.html

Policy:   Given the following rules, it seems likely that public transport is widely available.  The wearing of a mask is mandatory in all circumstances in public transport, except for the driver when interpersonal distance of two meters is respected or partition panel separates passengers.    The front door of the bus remains closed . Travelers are asked to get on and off through the rear doors.    The 1st row of passenger seats should be left unoccupied whenever possible.    The driver does not sell tickets (RegioZone).    Travelers are asked to keep their distance.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315212440/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/transports-publics.html

Between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m., movements of people in the public space are prohibited, with some exceptions.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315213340/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/couvre-feu.html

Policy: Between 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., the movement of people on public roads is prohibited.    Exceptions to this rule: travel     with a view to their professional activity or training or education;   for medical consultations or dispensations of health care that cannot be postponed or provided at a distance;   for the purchase of medicines or health products;   for compelling family reasons, for assistance and care for vulnerable or precarious persons or for the custody of children;   responding to a judicial, police or administrative summons;    to or from a station or an airport as part of a trip abroad;   linked to transits on the motorway network;  briefs within a radius of one kilometer around the place of residence for the needs of pets;   in case of force majeure or situation of necessity.      Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315212440/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/transports-publics.html
No policy measures
No evidence of specific policies. Drawing from C5, it is likely that restrictions on internal movement is at strictest, recommended.

From January 29, 2021 ""any person, regardless of their nationality, aged 6 or over, wishing to travel by air transport to the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, must present a negative result upon boarding. All departures to Luxembourg are therefore concerned, including those from member states of the European Union or the Schengen area.""    Third-country nationals cannot enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until March 31, 2021 inclusive, except for the categories of exempt persons and residents of the following third countries: Australia,  China, Hong Kong, and Macao (subject to reciprocity at European Union level), New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Singapore, Thailand    http://web.archive.org/web/20210315215848/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/voyageurs/visiter-luxembourg.htmlhttp://web.archive.org/web/20210315215848/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/voyageurs/visiter-luxembourg.html

Policy: There is leniency for entry and exit for certain travellers and a ban on others, hence this is coded as a Ban. See below.  Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area, as well as citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican/Saint See, are free to enter the territory of the European Union, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to return to their homes.     Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until 31 March 2021 (inclusive).    Additionally, ""there is an obligation to present a negative COVID-19 test result (not older than 72 hours) before boarding any flight to Luxembourg.""    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208183329/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

Policy: Appointments for tests can be made by invitation only with a one-time use code valid for 2 weeks, according to this distribution:    Continuous sampling tests of the population  Tests of particularly exposed individuals  Tests of incoming travellers  Reactive tests  Serological tests    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208230908/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing.html

People who tested positive are to provide the Health Inspectorate with the contact details of all close contacts they have had in the days prior to the test or before the onset of symptoms. so that the identified people are informed that they have been in contact with a sick person.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210208180127/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/sante-protection/contact-transmission.html

Wearing a mask is mandatory in all circumstances for activities open to the public (e.g. in administrations open to the public, shops and supermarkets), as well as on public transport. Also for any gathering of people that brings together more than 4 people at the same time, either in a closed area or in the open air.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210315231035/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/sante-protection/gestes-barriere.html

Policy: Wearing a mask is mandatory:    in all circumstances for activities open to the public that are circulating and which are taking place in a closed place (e.g. in administrations open to the public, shops and supermarkets), as well as on public transport.  for any gathering of people that brings together more than 4 people at the same time, either in a closed area or in the open air.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329224134/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/protective-measures.html

A,B,C: The Government is launching an anticipated campaign for phase 5, for people between 55 and 65 years old. For those over 65 years old, BioNTech/Pfizer and Moderna are preferred, but the government has doses from AstraZeneca to be administered to those under 65 years old.    https://lequotidien.lu/a-la-une/vaccination-au-luxembourg-au-tour-des-moins-de-65-ans/

A, C: As of the 14th of March 2021, 59,048 doses of the vaccines have been administered.  web.archive.org/web/20210315233045/https://www.covid19-vaccine.live/en/covid-19-vaccines-administration-in-luxembourg/46/29df7   BioNtech/Pfizer vaccine and Moderna Vaccines are being administered   web.archive.org/save/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination/infovaxx.html

Policy: In an initial phase, the vaccine is not available in sufficient doses for everyone to be vaccinated at the same time. It is therefore necessary and legitimate to prioritise according to the objectives of the immunisation strategy, i.e.    protect the most vulnerable people (based on their age or health status) from the risk of complications from the disease and from the risk of death, and  protect the capacity of our health care system.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210209004900/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html

There are recommendations in place to protect vulnerable/elderly people. For the purpose of clarity, vulnerable/elderly persons are those above 65 years, or pregnant, or have any of the following conditions: Diabetes, Cardiovascular diseases, Chronic diseases of the respiratory tract, Cancer, an immune deficiency due to a condition or therapy, morbid obesity (body mass index > 40 kg/m2).  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315233448/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/vulnerable-persons.html
Curfew also applies to the elderly.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315212440/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/transports-publics.html

The Prince’s Government has decided to introduce an Exceptional Minimum Income for self-employed workers which applies from 1 March 2020. The purpose of this financial assistance is to offer economic support to self-employed workers by providing a minimum monthly income of EUR 1,800 per month. Employers and self-employed workers in the Principality who are experiencing a significant drop in activity due to the Coronavirus epidemic can contact the Social Security Contributions Collection Office to request staggered payment of their contributions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329164543/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/monaco-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html

Employers and self-employed workers in the Principality who are experiencing a significant drop in business as a result of the coronavirus epidemic and are unable to make the next payments due are eligible for this measure. However, employers must, in all cases, complete the usual declarations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329164543/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/monaco-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html

Parce que le Coronavirus peut avoir des conséquences plus graves sur les aînés et les personnes plus fragiles, il est primordial d’être particulièrement vigilant dans le respect des consignes. La Mairie et les commerçants monégasques ont mis en place des actions spécifiques pour améliorer ma qualité de vie durant toute la durée des mesures de lutte contre le coronavirus.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329164858/https://covid19.mc/seniors-personnes-isolees/#:~:text=La%20distance%20de%20s%C3%A9curit%C3%A9%20sanitaire,des%20acc%C3%A8s%20par%20rendez%2Dvous

Due to an increase in the epidemiologic situation, restrictions are in place 01 March through 15 March, inclusively.  This includes:  Thus, the education will be held online in the primary education institutions, gymnasiums, lyceums, extra-school institutions and vocational schools and higher schools, private and public institutions. The school Olympiads will no longer be able to be held with the physical presence of people.  Spring break was extended from 05 March to 08 March to add 09 March through 15 March.  At the same time, the presence of spectators in the work of the theatre and concert institutions, as well as community centres is banned and the public transport will be ceased on Saturday and Sunday in the Chisinau city. The Chisinau municipality’s national extraordinary public health commission will establish a limited regime of movement of the public transport in the area of the Chisinau city.     The public institutions and the private ones will ensure a special working regime, through attracting of the strictly needed staff to work and the distance work will be instructed for the other employees.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308020813/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/03/21001628  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308020043/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-establishes-special-activity-regime  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308013930/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/social  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308013505/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

On 05 March, commercial centers were allowed to re-open on weekends.  In addition, the decision was made to increase restrictions in “red” districts:    In the eastern districts, where the red code of alert is established, measures of preventing the infection with Covid-19 infection will be implemented, such as:    1. restricting residents’ movement and isolation at home;    2. banning the mass meetings, including of the kind of cultural, scientific, artistic, sports or entertainment activities with people’s physical participation;  3. providing of only the essential (vital) services;    4. prohibition of non-essential visits to public interests units (bank, post office, etc.) ;  5. adjusted and only essential medical assistance services;  6. establishment of the online education.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314214933/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-commercial-centres-resume-working-saturdays-sundays  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314220013/https://gov.md/sites/default/files/postanovlenie_no_49_ot_5_marta_2021_g._nacionalnoy_chrezvychaynoy_komissii_obshchestvennogo_zdorovya.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314221448/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/05/21001722  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314220811/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314214534/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

On 16 March, a red, orange, yellow, green coding system will be implemented by territory to determine how students will return to physical classrooms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314223226/https://gov.md/sites/default/files/postanovlenie_nchkoz_no_50_ot_12.03.2021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314223116/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/12/21001905  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314220811/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314214534/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Almost all districts in the country are under the Red Code. Therefore a state of public health emergency was declared throughout the Republic of Moldova from March 19 to April 18, 2021, inclusive. Education in the country will be organized according to the epidemiological indicators in the locality. It will remain at the discretion of local authorities, educational institutions, and early education institutions to stop the educational process, including for primary classes, or continue their studies:  - Green or Yellow Code: pre-school children, pupils and students can go to school  - Orange Code: pre-school children, pupils of the elementary school, pupils from the graduate forms (9th, 12th, 13th of the evening school), pupils from vocational schools involved in the probations and in graduate groups, and students from graduate years of the higher education in practical classes can go to school; pupils and students from other forms and education years are on distance education.   - Red Code: distance education is recommended. Depending on the epidemiological situation at the institution, the education process can be organized as follows: (i) Daily participation of the pre-school children and elementary school pupils in the education institutions with physical presence. (ii) Daily participation with physical presence in the education institutions of a contingent of 50 per cent of all the number of pupils of the graduate forms (9th, 12th, 13th of the evening school), as well as of the pupils from the vocational education involved in probations and in the graduate groups and of the students from graduate years from the higher education, with the strict observance of the public health norms as to the prevention and spread of COVID-19.   (iii) Daily participation of the pupils and students from other forms and education years in the distance education.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210322194909/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/20/21002116  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322191211/https://gov.md/ro/content/aureliu-ciocoi-dupa-sedinta-cnesp-venit-timpul-ca-fiecare-ramura-puterii-din-republica

Due to an increase in the epidemiologic situation, restrictions are in place 01 March through 15 March, inclusively.  This includes:  Thus, the education will be held online in the primary education institutions, gymnasiums, lyceums, extra-school institutions and vocational schools and higher schools, private and public institutions. The school Olympiads will no longer be able to be held with the physical presence of people.      At the same time, the presence of spectators in the work of the theatre and concert institutions, as well as community centres is banned and the public transport will be ceased on Saturday and Sunday in the Chisinau city. The Chisinau municipality’s national extraordinary public health commission will establish a limited regime of movement of the public transport in the area of the Chisinau city.     The public institutions and the private ones will ensure a special working regime, through attracting of the strictly needed staff to work and the distance work will be instructed for the other employees.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308020043/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-establishes-special-activity-regime  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308013930/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/social  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308013505/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

On 05 March, commercial centers were allowed to re-open on weekends.  In addition, the decision was made to increase restrictions in “red” districts:    In the eastern districts, where the red code of alert is established, measures of preventing the infection with Covid-19 infection will be implemented, such as:    1. restricting residents’ movement and isolation at home;    2. banning the mass meetings, including of the kind of cultural, scientific, artistic, sports or entertainment activities with people’s physical participation;  3. providing of only the essential (vital) services;    4. prohibition of non-essential visits to public interests units (bank, post office, etc.) ;  5. adjusted and only essential medical assistance services;  6. establishment of the online education.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314214933/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-commercial-centres-resume-working-saturdays-sundays  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314220013/https://gov.md/sites/default/files/postanovlenie_no_49_ot_5_marta_2021_g._nacionalnoy_chrezvychaynoy_komissii_obshchestvennogo_zdorovya.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314221448/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/05/21001722  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314220811/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314214534/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Almost all districts in the country are under the Red Code. Therefore a state of public health emergency was declared throughout the Republic of Moldova from March 19 to April 18, 2021, inclusive.  A number of restrictive measures will be in place nation-wide during this period:  - Only groups of up to 3 persons (except for the family members) are allowed in public places. People older than 63 years must stay at home except for essential trips. Children cannot stay on playgrounds without parents/guardians. Protection masks must be used in all common use open and close public spaces. The physical distance between people should be at least 1 metre (if other rules are not applied, e.g. in the public transport). Shopping centers and non-food shops will be open until 18:00. Agri-food and non-food markets are allowed from 7:00 to 15:00h. Restaurants and pubs can receive visitors until 20:00h (after 20:00h take-away services are allowed). Weddings, celebrations, anniversaries, and other events in public catering establishments are prohibited. It is forbidden to organize with the physical presence of persons in scientific meetings, Olympics or sports competitions. Festivals, exhibitions, specialized agricultural fairs, and trade events will not be allowed in open and closed spaces. Night clubs, discos etc. are closed. Distance working is required whenever possible. Work hours were adjusted in government institutions.    For areas under the Red Code, the following restrictions apply:  Restricting of the residents’ movement and isolation at home. Banning of mass rallies, including the cultural, scientific, artistic, sports and entertainment activities. Providing of only essential (vital) services. Prohibition of non-essential visits to public interest units (bank, post office, etc.). Adjusting of the medical assistance services and providing of only the essential ones. Establishment of the distance education.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210322194909/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/20/21002116  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322184956/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322191211/https://gov.md/ro/content/aureliu-ciocoi-dupa-sedinta-cnesp-venit-timpul-ca-fiecare-ramura-puterii-din-republica

Almost all districts in the country are under the Red Code. Therefore a state of public health emergency was declared throughout the Republic of Moldova from March 19 to April 18, 2021, inclusive.  A number of restrictive measures will be in place nation-wide during this period:  - Only groups of up to 3 persons (except for the family members) are allowed in public places. People older than 63 years must stay at home except for essential trips. Children cannot stay on playgrounds without parents/guardians. Protection masks must be used in all common use open and close public spaces. The physical distance between people should be at least 1 metre (if other rules are not applied, e.g. in the public transport). Shopping centers and non-food shops will be open until 18:00. Agri-food and non-food markets are allowed from 7:00 to 15:00h. Restaurants and pubs can receive visitors until 20:00h (after 20:00h take-away services are allowed). Weddings, celebrations, anniversaries, and other events in public catering establishments are prohibited. It is forbidden to organize with the physical presence of persons in scientific meetings, Olympics or sports competitions. Festivals, exhibitions, specialized agricultural fairs, and trade events will not be allowed in open and closed spaces. Night clubs, discos etc. are closed. Distance working is required whenever possible. Work hours were adjusted in government institutions.    For areas under the Red Code, the following restrictions apply:  Restricting of the residents’ movement and isolation at home. Banning of mass rallies, including the cultural, scientific, artistic, sports and entertainment activities. Providing of only essential (vital) services. Prohibition of non-essential visits to public interest units (bank, post office, etc.). Adjusting of the medical assistance services and providing of only the essential ones. Establishment of the distance education.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210322194909/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/20/21002116  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322184956/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322191211/https://gov.md/ro/content/aureliu-ciocoi-dupa-sedinta-cnesp-venit-timpul-ca-fiecare-ramura-puterii-din-republica

On 27 February, the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine arrived in Moldova from a donation from Romania.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210227195631/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/02/24/21001437  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227195358/https://www.moldpres.md/en/photoshop/view/id/1891/

A:  AstraZeneca    On 02 March, the first person was vaccinated with the AstraZeneca vaccine, donated by Romania to Moldova. According to the Ministry of Health, Labor and Social Protection, the first will be vaccinated doctors from intensive care and COVID departments. Subsequently, all employees in the medical system will benefit from the vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308021525/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/02/21001591

The Pfizer vaccine is expected to arrive in mid-March to Moldova via COVAX.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308022834/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovan-government-holds-meeting-6 https://web.archive.org/web/20210308022524/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/03/21001643

In addition, the decision was made to increase restrictions in “red” districts:    In the eastern districts, where the red code of alert is established, measures of preventing the infection with Covid-19 infection will be implemented, such as:    1. restricting residents’ movement and isolation at home;    2. banning the mass meetings, including of the kind of cultural, scientific, artistic, sports or entertainment activities with people’s physical participation;  3. providing of only the essential (vital) services;    4. prohibition of non-essential visits to public interests units (bank, post office, etc.) ;  5. adjusted and only essential medical assistance services;  6. establishment of the online education.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314214933/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-commercial-centres-resume-working-saturdays-sundays  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314220013/https://gov.md/sites/default/files/postanovlenie_no_49_ot_5_marta_2021_g._nacionalnoy_chrezvychaynoy_komissii_obshchestvennogo_zdorovya.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314221448/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/05/21001722  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314220811/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314214534/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Almost all districts in the country are under the Red Code. Therefore a state of public health emergency was declared throughout the Republic of Moldova from March 19 to April 18, 2021, inclusive.  A number of restrictive measures will be in place nation-wide during this period:  - Only groups of up to 3 persons (except for the family members) are allowed in public places. People older than 63 years must stay at home except for essential trips. Children cannot stay on playgrounds without parents/guardians. Protection masks must be used in all common use open and close public spaces. The physical distance between people should be at least 1 metre (if other rules are not applied, e.g. in the public transport). Shopping centers and non-food shops will be open until 18:00. Agri-food and non-food markets are allowed from 7:00 to 15:00h. Restaurants and pubs can receive visitors until 20:00h (after 20:00h take-away services are allowed). Weddings, celebrations, anniversaries, and other events in public catering establishments are prohibited. It is forbidden to organize with the physical presence of persons in scientific meetings, Olympics or sports competitions. Festivals, exhibitions, specialized agricultural fairs, and trade events will not be allowed in open and closed spaces. Night clubs, discos etc. are closed. Distance working is required whenever possible. Work hours were adjusted in government institutions.    For areas under the Red Code, the following restrictions apply:  Restricting of the residents’ movement and isolation at home. Banning of mass rallies, including the cultural, scientific, artistic, sports and entertainment activities. Providing of only essential (vital) services. Prohibition of non-essential visits to public interest units (bank, post office, etc.). Adjusting of the medical assistance services and providing of only the essential ones. Establishment of the distance education.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210322194909/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/20/21002116  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322184956/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322191211/https://gov.md/ro/content/aureliu-ciocoi-dupa-sedinta-cnesp-venit-timpul-ca-fiecare-ramura-puterii-din-republica
No policy change    https://web.archive.org/web/20210224181133/https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2021/02/23/more-breathing-space-in-lockdown-but-caution-remains

""From 1 March, secondary schools and institutions of secondary vocational education (MBO) will partially reopen. In practice, this means that all secondary school pupils will attend school at least one day a week, subject to certain conditions. For now, MBO students will attend one day a week. As with primary schools, the government wants to avoid a situation in which secondary schools and MBO institutions need to close again in the future.  It is vital that schools and parents do everything possible to limit the number of contacts as much as possible. For some time now, anyone working in the education sector has been able to get tested with priority status, and that will not change.  Centres for out-of-school care (BSO) must stay closed, as opening them would lead to extra contact between pupils from different schools. ""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224181133/https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2021/02/23/more-breathing-space-in-lockdown-but-caution-remains  ***Updated to add link on universities, as it appears universities are still closed thus keeping the code at 2G rather than 1G: http://web.archive.org/web/20210312105506/https://www.uva.nl/en/current/coronavirus/updates.html?cb

Educational institutions are mainly offering remote and online learning.  Primary schools and daycare centres for children aged under 4 reopened on 8 February.  Out-of-school care will remain closed.  Secondary schools reopened on 1 March. In principle every pupil will attend in-person lessons at least 1 day per week.  As of 1 March  every student in secondary vocational education (MBO) can attend in-person lessons 1 day per week.  Higher professional education institutions (HBO) and universities can offer exams and practical training on site.  All educational institutions can make exceptions to provide support to vulnerable pupils or students.  For children whose parents work in critical sectors, emergency childcare is available at out-of-school care centres. Parents are urged to use this emergency childcare only if they have no other option.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312175821/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/coronavirus-measures-in-brief

""People performing contact-based professions, such as hairdressers and masseurs, will be able to practise again from 3 March 2021. Customers must make a reservation and must be asked if they have any symptoms that could point to COVID-19. It is also important to wear a face mask and, where possible, to stay 1.5 metres apart.    The relaxation of this measure will also apply to driving instructors. From 3 March, people will be able to take driving lessons again, and the practical driving test will be available to anyone. The government is exploring ways to enable driving students to safely take the theory test at the earliest possible opportunity.    The basic hygiene measures will of course continue to apply, and you must stay at home if you have symptoms of COVID-19.    Sex workers may not practise their profession at this time.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210224181133/https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2021/02/23/more-breathing-space-in-lockdown-but-caution-remains

""Flight ban  To reduce the risk of virus mutations spreading, on 23 January the government announced a flight ban on passenger flights from the United Kingdom, South Africa, the Dominican Republic, Brazil, Argentina, Bolivia, Cabo Verde, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Suriname, Uruguay and Venezuela. This ban will be extended until at least Thursday 4 March. The government has asked the Outbreak Management Team to advise on the partial or full extension of this ban. The current exemptions, affecting a small number of travellers, including medical personnel, are still in effect.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210224181133/https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2021/02/23/more-breathing-space-in-lockdown-but-caution-remains

Restrictions have been extended until March 30th  https://web.archive.org/web/20210318101413/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/452826/netherlands-authorities-maintaining-most-covid-19-related-measures-as-of-march-9-update-30    ""International Entry RestrictionsEffective March 9, authorities have lifted a ban on passenger flights and ferries from the UK. The ban was initially imposed to stem the spread of a variant strain of COVID-19 originally identified in the UK; however, this strain has spread within the Netherlands to such an extent that a travel ban has no added value. Travelers from the UK are still required to present proof of a negative result from a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken no more than 72 hours prior to arrival.    Authorities previously extended the ban on flights with South Africa and many countries in Central and South America until at least April 1 due to concerns related to variant strains of COVID-19 in those countries. The targeted locations in the Americas currently include Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Suriname, Uruguay, and Venezuela. Air freight transport is exempt from the travel ban.    Travel to the Netherlands is generally only permitted for European Economic Area (EEA) residents or Schengen-associated countries and residents of Dutch Caribbean Territories, Australia, China, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand. Officials prohibit most travel from other countries; however, effective March 9, the list of travel exemptions has been expanded to include healthcare workers, people traveling to seek medical attention, persons traveling for urgent family reasons, staff traveling to or from British or Dutch drilling platforms, air or sea crews traveling in the exercise of their work, transiting EEA or Schengen Area residents, and returning Dutch nationals and residents.    All permitted travelers must possess proof of a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test taken no more than 72 hours prior to arrival. All permitted travelers arriving via sea or air must also undergo a rapid COVID-19 test no more than four hours prior to boarding. Authorities will not accept results from self-administered tests. Transit passengers are also subject to this requirement. Aircrews must undergo a rapid antigen test upon disembarking. Other transport sector workers must undergo a rapid antigen test no more than 24 hours prior to departure. Additionally, all travelers must fill out a declaration form prior to entry and self-isolate for 10 days on arrival; this can be shortened by taking a COVID-19 test on or after day five of the self-isolation period. These measures do not apply to individuals arriving from Iceland, the Dutch Caribbean Territories, Australia, China, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand; additional exceptions are possible for individuals with an essential function or need, such as health workers, on-duty security forces, freight workers, and diplomats.""

""International Entry RestrictionsTravel to the Netherlands is generally only permitted for residents of European Economic Area (EEA) or Schengen-associated countries, as well as those of the Dutch Caribbean Territories, Australia, China, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand. Officials prohibit most travel from other countries. Exemptions, however, are in place for healthcare workers, people traveling to seek medical attention, persons traveling for urgent family reasons, staff traveling to or from British or Dutch drilling platforms, air or sea crews traveling in the exercise of their work, transiting EEA or Schengen Area residents, and returning Dutch nationals and residents.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210325102530/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/459391/netherlands-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-restrictions-until-at-least-april-20-plan-to-ease-curfew-hours-starting-march-31-update-31

No policy change found    Previous notes:   ""Advice for people with health issues (at-risk groups)  Coronavirus does not affect everyone in the same way. Some people have hardly any symptoms, while others become seriously ill. However, it is clear that some groups have a higher risk of becoming very ill or even dying.    People aged 70 and over have a higher risk of becoming seriously ill if they get coronavirus. This applies to healthy older people, but particularly to older people who are not fully independent. People with underlying health conditions also have a higher risk of becoming seriously ill with coronavirus. If you have health issues, take extra care and follow the basic rules carefully.    Visits to care homes are allowed as long as this does not hamper efforts to prevent the spread of coronavirus. Residents at the end of their life or in a critical condition are always allowed to have visitors. Care homes will assess the situation and decide when residents can receive more visitors. Guidelines have been drawn up for this purpose.   In the event of an outbreak in a care home, all residents and staff will be tested weekly.  It is especially important to follow the basic rules when visiting people who fall into an at-risk group. This includes staying 1.5 metres apart. Make clear arrangements and check before the visit whether anyone has symptoms. If a visitor or a person they want to visit has cold-like symptoms, a fever or shortness of breath, the visit should be postponed. Visits should take place outdoors, if possible, because this is safer.""    /web/20210226152456/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/basic-rules-for-everyone

""Coronavirus does not affect everyone in the same way. Some people have hardly any symptoms, while others become seriously ill. However, it is clear that some groups have a higher risk of becoming very ill or even dying.    People aged 70 and over have a higher risk of becoming seriously ill if they get coronavirus. This applies to healthy older people, but particularly to older people who are not fully independent. People with underlying health conditions also have a higher risk of becoming seriously ill with coronavirus. If you have health issues, take extra care and follow the basic rules carefully.    Visits to nursing homes are allowed as long as this does not hamper efforts to prevent the spread of coronavirus. Residents at the end of their life or in a critical condition are always allowed to have visitors. Nursing homes will assess the situation and decide when residents can receive more visitors. Guidelines have been drawn up for this purpose.   More and more residents of nursing homes and care homes for people with disabilities are being vaccinated. Because of this the rules for visits can be eased:  If the residents in a home have had both of their vaccine injections, they can receive 2 visitors per day instead of 1.  Residents can receive other visitors than the 2 or 3 people in their ‘visitor bubble’.  In the event of an outbreak in a nursing home, all residents and staff will be tested weekly.  It is especially important to follow the basic rules when visiting people who fall into an at-risk group. This includes staying 1.5 metres apart. Make clear arrangements and check before the visit whether anyone has symptoms. If a visitor or a person they want to visit has cold-like symptoms, a fever or shortness of breath, the visit should be postponed. Visits should take place outdoors, if possible, because this is safer.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210318104343/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/basic-rules-for-everyone

No policy change    ""As of March 16, authorities in Norway have tightened restrictions imposed to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Viken County, including the capital Oslo, due to rising infection rates. All nonessential shops and services must close and catering establishments may only offer carryout services. Individuals must work from home wherever possible. Gatherings and events are prohibited, with the exception of weddings and funerals, and many education services will switch to distance learning. Additionally, protective facemasks are mandatory where social distancing of 1 meter (3 feet) cannot be observed. These measures also apply to the Gran Municipality in Innlandet County and will be in effect until at least April 11.    Elsewhere in Norway, most nonessential businesses and services are open subject to strict social distancing and hygiene measures; however, limitations on the size of private gatherings remain in effect. Individuals are advised to limit their social contacts and avoid all nonessential travel. Protective facemasks are recommended rather than mandatory. Additional municipalities with higher rates of infection may also vary the restrictions imposed in their jurisdiction.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318105607/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/455946/norway-authorities-tighten-covid-19-restrictions-in-viken-county-as-of-march-16-update-35

Red risk level in kindergartens, primary and lower secondary schools in Oslo (years 1 to 4 in all parts of Oslo, and years 5 to 7 in schools in areas without fully digital teaching)  Fully digital teaching in lower and upper secondary schools in all parts of Oslo.  Fully digital teaching for years 5 to 7 in all schools in Grorud, Stovner, Alna, Bjerke, Gamle Oslo, Grünerløkka and Søndre Nordstrand. It may be necessary to introduce fully digital teaching for this age group in other schools or districts depending on future infection levels locally.   All kindergartens and activity schools will be closed during the Easter break.   Vulnerable groups and children whose parents are essential workers will receive adapted programme in schools before the Easter break. Children whose parents are essential workers will also be offered an adapted programme in schools during the Easter break.    ""Kindergartens and schools will be reopened at red risk level on Tuesday 6 April. The other measures will remain in effect until 9 April.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210318112902/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/english/coronavirus/advice-and-rules-in-the-city-of-oslo/

Domestic restrictionsEffective March 25, nationwide bans on serving alcohol, as well as engaging in indoor sports and leisure activities for adults, are in place. Individuals must work from home wherever possible. Authorities are also recommending a maximum of two guests per visit at private homes.    Many nonessential businesses and services remain open subject to strict social distancing and hygiene measures. Indoor gatherings are limited to 20 people, while outdoor gatherings are capped at 50 people. Individuals are advised to limit their social contacts and avoid all nonessential travel. Protective facemasks are recommended rather than mandatory. Municipalities with higher rates of infection may impose stricter measures within their jurisdictions.    Tighter restrictions are in place in Viken County, including the capital Oslo, due to rising infection rates. All nonessential shops and services must close and catering establishments may only offer carryout services. Gatherings and events are prohibited, with the exception of weddings and funerals, and many education services are employing distance learning. Additionally, protective facemasks are mandatory where social distancing of 2 meters (6 feet) cannot be observed. These measures also apply to the Gran Municipality in Innlandet County and will be in effect until at least April 11.    Authorities could reimpose, extend, further ease, or otherwise amend any restrictions with little-to-no notice depending on disease activity over the coming weeks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402075546/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/461236/norway-authorities-tighten-covid-19-quarantine-requirements-for-international-arrivals-from-march-29-update-37

""Authorities in Norway will tighten restrictions imposed to combat the spread of COVID-19 in the capital Oslo from March 2 due to rising infection numbers in the city. All nonessential businesses and services must close, and catering establishments may only offer take-away services. Furthermore, all events are banned with limited exceptions such as weddings and funerals, which may have a maximum of five participants.    Elsewhere in Norway, most nonessential businesses and services are open subject to strict social distancing and hygiene measures; however, limitations on the size of private gatherings remain in effect. Individuals are advised to limit their social contacts and avoid all nonessential travel. Protective facemasks are recommended rather than mandatory. Additional municipalities with higher rates of infection may also vary the restrictions imposed in their jurisdiction.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301135837/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/449236/norway-authorities-to-tighten-covid-19-restrictions-in-oslo-from-march-2-update-34

""Authorities in Norway are continuing to impose restrictions to combat the spread of COVID-19 as of Feb. 26. All international travelers, with the exception of Norwegian citizens and legal residents, are barred from entry. Additional exemptions are in place for close family members of Norwegian residents, transport workers, individuals in transit, journalists, and foreigners who work within critical social functions.    All permitted arrivals from high-risk areas must register with authorities within 72 hours before arrival and present proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken within 24 hours before arrival. Norwegian citizens may instead opt to be tested on arrival. Additionally, all arrivals from high-risk areas are required to isolate for 10 days on arrival. Most travelers without a permanent residence in Norway are required to complete their isolation period in a government-designated hotel. The isolation period can be ended following a negative result for a COVID-19 test taken on or after the seventh day of isolation. As of Feb. 26, only Greenland, Iceland, and the Finnish hospital districts of Central Ostrobothnia, South Ostrobothnia, Kainuu, North-Savo, South-Savo, and North Karelia are not considered high-risk areas.    From March 1, cross-border commuters from Sweden and Finland will again be permitted to enter Norway without the need to isolate provided they take a COVID-19 test every seven days.    Domestic RestrictionsMost nonessential businesses and services are open subject to strict social distancing and hygiene measures; however, limitations on the size of private gatherings remain in effect. Individuals are advised to limit their social contacts and avoid all nonessential travel. Protective facemasks are recommended rather than mandatory. Stricter measures may be in force in municipalities with higher rates of infection.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227011152/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/448331/norway-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-restrictions-as-of-feb-26-update-33

The isolation period can be ended following a negative result for a COVID-19 test taken on or after the seventh day of isolation. From March 1, cross-border commuters from Sweden and Finland will again be permitted to enter Norway without the need to isolate provided they take a COVID-19 test every seven days.    Domestic RestrictionsMost nonessential businesses and services are open subject to strict social distancing and hygiene measures; however, limitations on the size of private gatherings remain in effect. Individuals are advised to limit their social contacts and avoid all nonessential travel. Protective facemasks are recommended rather than mandatory. Stricter measures may be in force in municipalities with higher rates of infection.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227011152/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/448331/norway-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-restrictions-as-of-feb-26-update-33

""As of March 16, authorities in Norway have tightened restrictions imposed to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Viken County, including the capital Oslo, due to rising infection rates. ""International Entry RestrictionsAll international travelers, with the exception of Norwegian citizens and legal residents, are barred from entry. Additional exemptions are in place for close family members of Norwegian residents, transport workers, individuals in transit, and foreigners who work within critical social functions.    All permitted arrivals from high-risk areas must register with authorities within 72 hours before arrival and present a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken within 24 hours before arrival. Norwegian citizens may instead opt to be tested on arrival. Additionally, all arrivals from high-risk areas are required to isolate for 10 days on arrival. Most travelers without a permanent residence in Norway are required to complete their isolation period in a government-designated hotel. The isolation period can be ended following a negative result for a COVID-19 test taken on or after the seventh day of isolation. As of March 16, only Iceland, Greenland the Faroe Islands, and the Finnish hospital districts of Kainuu and Lansi-Pohja are not considered high-risk areas.
