""Authorities in Norway plan to tighten certain COVID-19-related domestic and travel restrictions. Starting March 25, all persons returning to Norway from nonessential trips abroad must quarantine in government-designated hotel for 10 days; there will be no option to end the quarantine early by taking a COVID-19 test and producing a negative result.    Otherwise, existing international travel restrictions remain in effect. Generally, only Norwegian citizens and legal residents are allowed to enter the country; however, exemptions are in place for close family members of Norwegian residents, transport workers, individuals in transit, and foreigners who work within critical social functions.    All permitted travelers from high-risk areas must register with authorities within 72 hours before arrival and present a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken within 24 hours before arrival. Norwegian citizens may instead opt to be tested on arrival. As of March 23, only Iceland, Greenland the Faroe Islands, and the Finnish hospital districts of Kainuu and Lansi-Pohja, are not considered high-risk areas. Cross-border commuters from Sweden and Finland are permitted to enter Norway without the need to isolate provided they take a COVID-19 test every seven days.    ""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210325111141/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/459426/norway-authorities-to-tighten-covid-19-domestic-and-travel-restrictions-from-march-25-update-36

Authorities in Norway are set to tighten quarantine requirements for international arrivals to the country from March 29 due to increasing COVID-19 infection rates. From this date, authorities will require all arrivals, including local nationals and permanent residents, returning from ""travel on an unnecessary trip abroad"" to quarantine at designated hotels for 10 days. The quarantine period may be shortened if a negative COVID-19 test result is received no earlier than seven days after entry into the country. There are a limited number of exceptions where arrivals will not be required to quarantine. In addition, business travelers who are able to document that their employer is able to provide a suitable alternative accommodation may be exempt from the hotel quarantine.    Otherwise, existing international travel restrictions remain in effect. Generally, only Norwegian citizens and legal residents are allowed to enter the country; however, exemptions are in place for close family members of Norwegian residents, transport workers, individuals in transit, and foreigners who work within critical social functions.    All permitted travelers from high-risk areas must register with authorities within 72 hours before arrival and present a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken within 24 hours before arrival. Norwegian citizens may instead opt to be tested on arrival. Effective March 23, only Iceland, Greenland the Faroe Islands, and the Finnish hospital districts of Kainuu and Lansi-Pohja, are not considered high-risk areas. Cross-border commuters from Sweden and Finland are permitted to enter Norway without the need to isolate provided they take a COVID-19 test every seven days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402075546/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/461236/norway-authorities-tighten-covid-19-quarantine-requirements-for-international-arrivals-from-march-29-update-37

""Niedzielski announced earlier that shopping malls, hotels and schools in the Warminsko-Mazurskie region would have to close as it has reported a relatively high number of new coronavirus infections.""     Takes effect from Saturday, Feb 27 for initially two weeks.     https://archive.is/fCphU

""As of 12 February, cinemas, theatres, opera houses and philharmonics resume their operations under a strict sanitary regime – maximum of 50% of seats can be occupied during cultural events. Masks are obligatory. Consumption is prohibited.    The exception is the Warminsko-Mazurskie Voivodeship, where we are tightening safety rules due to the difficult epidemic situation. Cinemas, theatres, museums, and art galleries are to be closed in this voivodeship.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210305010658/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations

From March 20 to April 9, the following restrictions will apply throughout Poland. They must suspend their activities:  hotels (exceptions include workers' hotels, as well as accommodation provided as part of business trips - the exact catalog of exceptions along with the required confirmation of a business trip will be included in the regulation);  shopping malls - with the exception of: grocery stores, pharmacies and drugstores, press salons, bookstores, pet stores and DIY stores. In shopping malls, they will still be able to operate, among others hairdressing, optics, banking, laundry services;  theaters, museums, art galleries (it is possible, however, to organize rehearsals and exercises, as well as online events);  cinemas (the ban on screening films also applies to cultural centers and centers)  swimming pools (except for swimming pools in entities performing medical activity and for members of the national team);  saunas, solariums, Turkish baths, slimming salons, casinos;  ski slopes;  fitness clubs and gyms;  sports facilities (may operate only for the needs of professional sports and without the participation of the public).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322231434/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/od-20-marca-w-calej-polsce-obowiazuja-rozszerzone-zasady-bezpieczenstwa

Large-format furniture and construction stores with an area of ??more than 2,000 m2 will be closed.  Shopping centers and malls - as at present - remain closed, with the exception of: grocery stores, pharmacies and drugstores, press salons, bookstores.  From March 27, the ban will also cover hairdressing, beauty and cosmetic salons all over Poland.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330142225/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/od-27-marca-zmiany-w-zasadach-bezpieczenstwa

Rules for travelers coming to Poland from the Schengen area  Travelers will be quarantined unless they test negative for COVID-19. The test will have to be performed no later than 48 hours before the border is crossed.  Type of test: PCR or antigenic.  The new rules will apply to all means of transport: public and individual transport as well as crossing the border on foot.  Travelers who have been quarantined in Poland will be able to take a test, the negative result of which will release them from quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210402120444/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/od-30-marca-nowe-zasady-dotyczace-kwarantanny-dla-przyjezdzajacych-do-polski3

""In a statement, the Ministry of Home Affairs said that air traffic restrictions remain until 16 March and that flights to and from Brazil and the United Kingdom are suspended.    Flights, to or from mainland Portugal, to and from countries belonging to the European Union and countries associated with the Schengen Area are authorised.    At the same time, “exclusively essential” trips to and from countries that are not part of the European Union or that are not associated with the Schengen Area are also authorised, as well as support for the return of nationals or those legally resident in Portugal.""    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210309222719/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-03-01/uk-and-brazil-flights-remain-suspended/58567

""Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to:  - European Union countries;  - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland;  - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay.  Passengers must present a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before boarding time.      (...) All commercial or private flights between Portugal and the United Kingdom and between Portugal and Brazil are suspended. Except for the right of entry for national citizens and their families and holders of residence permits in Portugal, only on flights of a humanitarian nature for the purpose of repatriation of those citizens. These passengers will have to present, at the time of departure, proof of a RT-PCR test with a negative result, carried out within 72 hours prior to departure time. Upon arriving in the national territory, they must comply with a period of 14 days of quarantine at home, or in a place indicated by the health authorities""    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210316143225/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

Previous measures remain in place.  In addition, ""Police checks at the border between Spain and Portugal will continue until at least April 6th, the Spanish government has confirmed, in a bid to control the spread of coronavirus with only those with justified cause allowed to cross.  The measure published on the Spanish Foreign Ministry’s website on Monday March 15th (and that enters in force at 1am March 16) means people crossing the border between the two Iberian nations will only be able to cross through authorised border check spots and during the opening hours established.  Although there are already regional border closures agreed to by Spain’s autonomous communities for the Easter period, the announcement is further confirmation that holiday travel to Portugal over Semana Santa will not be possible.   (...) The Spain-Portugal border has been closed since January 30th.""  Source: https://archive.vn/6bp3K

Previous restrictions remain in place. In addition, ""in the context of the epidemiological situation caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, the Government decided that the restrictions in force for flights originating in Brazil and the United Kingdom will now apply to passengers on flights originating in South Africa and arriving to Portugal after stopover or transit in third countries, says the Ministry of Internal Administration in a statement. These restrictive measures will remain in effect until 11:59 pm on March 31   (...) passangers from flights originating in South Africa must present proof of having performed a molecular test by RT-PCR to screen for SARS-CoV-2 infection, with a negative result, performed within 72 hours prior to the time of boarding (...) Upon arrival they must also fulfill a period of prophylactic isolation of 14 days (...) On the March 15, the Portuguese Government decided to keep all commercial or private flights from airports or aerodromes in mainland Portugal, with origin or destination in Brazil and the United Kingdom, suspended until March 31.""  Sources:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210326144630/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal http://web.archive.org/web/20210323143032/https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/coronavirus/detalhe/portugal-alarga-aos-passageiros-de-voos-da-africa-do-sul-restricoes-que-ja-tem-para-brasil-e-reino-unido

From March 26 to April 5, all non-essential travel (tourism) to Portugal, including by other EU member residents, is prohibited.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326141317/https://pt.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/   ***Updated to note that land border between Portugal and Spain will remain closed through Easter (until at least April 6th) https://web.archive.org/web/20210329094151/https://travelbans.org/europe/portugal/

""Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to:  - European Union countries;  - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland;  - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay.  All passengers must present proof of a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before boarding time.    Essential travel is allowed only to passengers coming from countries with an incidence rate of 150 cases or more per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days - Germany, Austria, Belgium, Croatia, Denmark, Slovakia, Finland, Greece, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Norway, the Netherlands, Romania, Switzerland.    Essential travellers coming from countries with an incidence rate equal or over 500 cases or more per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days - Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Cyprus, Slovenia, Estonia, France, Hungary, Italy, Malta, Poland and Sweden – must also comply with a prophylactic isolation period of 14 days, after entering mainland Portugal, at home or in a place indicated by the health authorities. The prophylactic isolation does not apply to passengers travelling on essential trips and whose period of stay in national territory, attested by a return ticket, does not exceed 48 hours.    All commercial or private flights between Portugal and the United Kingdom and between Portugal and Brazil are suspended. Except for the right of entry for national citizens and their families and holders of residence permits in Portugal, only on flights of a humanitarian nature for the purpose of repatriation of the said citizens. These passengers must present, at the time of departure, proof of having performed a RT-PCR test with a negative result, carried out within 72 hours prior to the time of departure. When arriving in the national territory, they must comply with a 14-day quarantine period at home or at a location indicated by the health authorities.    Anyone who is obliged to comply with the 14-day prophylactic isolation in Portugal must register with SEF - Foreigners and Borders Service before entering the country (...)     Passengers on commercial flights from South Africa must present proof of a negative RT-PCR test result, carried out within 72 hours prior to departure time and will have to comply with a 14-day quarantine period at home or at a place indicated by the health authorities. This requirement also applies to flights that have stopped over or transited in countries which air traffic with Portugal is authorised, or to passengers registered as having left South Africa in the 14 days prior to their arrival in Portugal.    Flights between Portugal and other destinations not mentioned are suspended.""    Source: https://archive.vn/HNp4O    April 1-The Portuguese Prime-Minister, António Costa, announced that ""There is an agreement with the Kingdom of Spain to keep the borders closed - in terms of the land border - in order to avoid an increase in the pandemic and keep the situation under control. The borders will remain closed with the exceptions that have been previously announced”.    Source: https://archive.vn/nYQRD

No changes in previous policy. Previous measures remain in place.  ""(...) the Energy Services Regulatory Entity (ERSE) established exceptional measures for the provision of energy supply services, as essential public services, that will be in force for the duration of the state of emergency, declared on January 1.  The fractioning of billing amounts to customers affected by the Covid-19 pandemic, in a situation of unemployment, reduction in household income equal to or greater than 20% or those infected by the covid-19 disease, whose annual consumption is equal to or less than 10,000 m3 , covers ""values ??of invoices issued as of January 1, 2021 and of those that may be issued under the state of emergency so declared in legal terms, and in any case may not exceed the date of June 30, 2021"".  Similarly to the measures implemented 2020, the installment payment must be payed in 6 to 12 monthly instalement, or less if agreed with the client, and the value of each installment must observe a minimum value of five euros. The payment of the first installment of the plan can be deferred for a period that cannot exceed 60 days from the payment date that was originally defined in the invoice that originated the payment plan.""  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210323145814/https://www.dinheirovivo.pt/geral/covid-19-pagamento-faseado-de-energia-limitado-a-faturas-ate-30-de-junho-13409907.html

This suspension will remain in place until at least June 30, 2021."" Pharmacies and ‘para-pharmacies’ in Portugal will be able to start selling public rapid Covid tests’ from Saturday.  ""A government dispatch published in Diário da República today green-lights the commercialisation of quickie tests in pharmacies and ‘other outlets that sell medication’ for the next six months.  The dispatch “establishes an exceptional and temporary regime” for these ‘antigen tests’ which can be performed ‘at home’ and do not need a doctor’s prescription.  (...) These tests will not be enough to travel with, in other words. They will simply be an indication which will then need to be verified by health authorities in the case of positive results.  In paving the way for this new diagnostic tool, health minister Marta Temido says Portugal is simply following a strategy already in place in other countries, including Germany and Austria.""   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210316193325/https://www.portugalresident.com/pharmacies-to-start-selling-quickie-covid-tests-from-saturday/

""Rapid antigen tests carried out during the past week in primary and pre-schools detected 80 cases of COVID-19 among teachers and non-teaching staff. After the resumption of face-to-face education, 82 thousand people were tested over four days. In other words, the positivity rate was less than 0.1%, according to the Ministry of Education.  (...) This second testing phase started on Tuesday, the day after the return to face-to-face classes of children from the 1st cycle and pre-school. By the end of last week, all teaching and non-teaching workers at these levels of education were tested, both in the public and private sectors. The testing process also included professionals from the “Full-Time Schools” (...) Last week, in daycare workers under the Ministry of Labor, Solidarity and Social Security responsability, were also tested (...)""  Source: https://archive.vn/is0OQ

Pingo Doce (supermarket) starts this Wednesday, March 31, the sale of self-tests to Covid-19 in 25 Para Wellness pharmacies in the Lisbon region. As of this Thursday, the sale will be extended to the remaining stores across the country, according to the Jerónimo Martins supermarket chain. According to the statement, the tests will be marketed “in this initial phase” in boxes of 25 tests with a cost per test of 6.79 euros.  As of next week, the sale of these tests is expected to be extended “to all Well Being spaces, including those located inside supermarkets and not just parapharmacies with a service counter “. The test results are obtained within 15 to 30 minutes.  (...) “Well’s starts to make available, starting tomorrow, Thursday, in its physical stores from the north to the south of the country, rapid antigen tests of Roche Diagnósticos, in order to anticipate public health care and help to implement the measures of isolation to contain the transmission of the virus in Portugal, “he said in the statement.  (...) Well’s has 280 stores across the country, most of which “will make the tests available this Thursday, and on Friday all other stores in mainland Portugal will make the test available”, adds the official.""  Source: https://archive.vn/fF5uw

The use of masks on the street will continue to be mandatory until at least July. The new diploma determines that the use of a mask is mandatory for those aged 10 or older for access, circulation or permanence in public spaces and roads ""whenever physical distance recommended by health authorities is not possible"".    This obligation may be waived ""in case people belong to the same household and are not in the proximity of third parties"" or by presenting a medical certificate or statement attesting that the clinical condition or cognitive impairment of the individual does not allow the use of masks.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210317144559/https://www.dn.pt/politica/assembleia-da-republica-avanca-com-uso-obrigatorio-de-mascaras-na-rua-ate-julho-13467457.html

""The parliament approved this Wednesday the PSD bill that renews the mandatory use of masks in public spaces for another 70 days , a measure that has been in force in Portugal since 28 October and which would end on 5 April.  (...) In the diploma, the PSD proposes a renewal for 70 days : if the deadline starts counting from next Monday, April 5, this obligation will extend until June 13.  (...) The approved bill prolongs, without changes, the current law, which imposes the mandatory use of masks in public spaces and provides for fines of between 100 and 500 euros for non-compliers .  The diploma determines that the use of a mask ( which cannot be replaced by a visor ) is mandatory for those over ten years of age for access, circulation or permanence in public spaces and roads “whenever the physical distance recommended by health authorities proves to be impractical”.  Sources: https://archive.vn/9G41C#selection-2775.0-2883.188

As of February, people aged 80 and over and those aged 50 and over with more serious pathologies were included.""    Source: https://archive.vn/HUVc3

Still current, vaccinations ongoing:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210314170556/https://graphics.reuters.com/world-coronavirus-tracker-and-maps/countries-and-territories/portugal/  ""The Directorate-General for Health (DGS) included people with trisomy 21, teachers and non-teaching staff in the priority phase 1 vaccine against covid-19. Portugal has announced that it is suspending the inoculation of AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine as a “precaution,” joining other European countries – including France, Germany, Italy and Spain – in halting its use following reports of blood clots post inoculation.    “Portuguese health authorities today decided to suspend the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine against Covid-19 for reasons of precaution and public health,” Portugal’s national health authority said Monday in a statement.     According to the national health authority, the decision was taken “due to reports of the appearance of blood clots in vaccinated people.”    The decision comes despite assertions from the United Kingdom’s Joint Committee on Vaccinations and Immunizations (JCVI) that the vaccine has been “rigorously tested for safety.”     The European Medicines Agency (EMA) also said Monday that the benefits of the AstraZeneca vaccine outweigh the risks, adding that the number of people developing blood clots after vaccination does not seem to be higher than in the general population.    The agency said it would hold an emergency meeting on Thursday to advise on “any further actions that may need to be taken.”    Note: Despite this suspension, the three priority groups continue to be vaccinated.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210316142901/https://edition.cnn.com/world/live-news/coronavirus-pandemic-vaccine-updates-03-16-21/h_4342ae241ec9a83567b7eabedfc3b111

""This Monday, Portugal resumed the vaccination against Covid-19 with the AstraZeneca vaccine. The decision was announced last Thursday at a joint press conference with the director of Infarmed, the DG of the Direção Geral da Saúde (DGS) and the Coordinator of the Vaccination Task Force.  The president of Infarmed, Rui Ivo, started by revealing that the experts made an analysis of the vaccine that shows that ""the benefits are greater than the risks"" (...)"".  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210323143919/https://executivedigest.sapo.pt/covid-19-portugal-retoma-uso-da-astrazeneca-infarmed-pede-atencao-a-sintomas/

On March 10, ""The Directorate-General for Health (DGS) included people with trisomy 21, teachers and non-teaching staff in the priority phase 1 vaccine against covid-19.  According to the updated DGS guidelines, people with trisomy 21 are included in the priority groups ""due to the increased risk of progressing to severe covid-19"".  As for teachers and staff and non-teaching staff, DGS clarifies that those who work in educational establishments and in the social responses to support children in the public, private and social and cooperative sectors are covered, ""according to the logistics plan that will be implemented "".   Source: https://archive.vn/HBKSQ#selection-1399.0-1436.0  The coronavirus vaccination for teachers, school staff, and childcare workers began this Saturday, March 26. Initially, about 80 thousand have been called. It is expected that the group of 280 thousand professionals who are now included in the priority groups list will be vaccinated in April.  Source: https://archive.vn/yPfVj#selection-1441.0-1479.171  Note: The code remains unchanged because these are  now considered key workers and therefore it does not justify an upgrade for a 4 -""Availability for all three plus partial additional availability (select broad groups/ages)"".

The list of priorities for the second phase of the vaccination plan against covid-19 will be changed, if the proposal of the specialist committee of the Directorate-General for Health (DGS) is approved. The plan is to start vaccinating by age, using the criterion of decreasing age groups, but simultaneously including people with diseases associated with increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19, and without age limit. A new “two-legged strategy that will run in parallel”, the DGS said this Thursday.  (...) In the second phase, which begins after the completion of the vaccination of the priority groups of the first phase, on April 11, as announced by the task force coordinator, this new strategy must be “adjusted in order to vaccinate the largest number of people in the smallest period of time ”and taking into account“ an expected increase in the doses of vaccines available."".  Source: https://archive.vn/QtcHO

Foreign citizens entering Kosovo, including those with temporary or permanent residence permits in Kosovo, who come from high-risk countries according to the official ECDC list, should have RT-PCR negative test for Covid-19 made in the last 72 hours, on the basis of the principle of reciprocity.  All citizens of Kosovo (including those with a settlement in another state), during entry into Kosovo must submit proof for negative RT-PCR test made earlier 72 hours before entering Kosovo, otherwise must be self-isolated for 7 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225093028/https://kryeministri-ks.net/qeveria-lehteson-masat-per-mbrojtjen-nga-pandemia-covid-19/

Foreign citizens entering Kosovo, including those with temporary or permanent residence permits in Kosovo, who come from high-risk countries according to the official ECDC list, should have RT-PCR negative test for Covid-19 made in the last 72 hours, on the basis of the principle of reciprocity.  All citizens of Kosovo (including those with a settlement in another state), during entry into Kosovo must submit proof for negative RT-PCR test made earlier 72 hours before entering Kosovo, otherwise must be self-isolated for 7 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210328110833/https://kryeministri-ks.net/qeveria-lehteson-masat-per-mbrojtjen-nga-pandemia-covid-19/

The government has paid a flat sum (€170) to workers who have been laid off. Pension and social taxes are also being paid in full.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210311084512/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-situation-in-kosovo.html

I am in doubt of general availability of public testing:  There are PCR and rapid antigen tests available from several private labs in Pristina for 60-75 Euros; availability outside Pristina is unknown.  The main public hospital in Pristina, the University Clinical Center of Kosovo (UCCK), provides free travel testing without a referral although availability and scheduling depend on demand.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210323003251/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/
See the notes on 12 March for the doubts raised.  No policy change since then  https://web.archive.org/web/20210323003251/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

In public, i.e. at any time outside your own home, there is an obligation to wear a mouth-nose protection. Mass vaccination is excepted to start soon.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210328110805/https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/de/aussenpolitik/laender/kosovo-node/kosovosicherheit/207442

No policy changes noted. Vaccinations will be free of charge and voluntary and will be deployed as soon as they are available from Covax..  The first to be vaccinated will be health system employees and people over 65. Groups A, C (with vaccines supplied via Covax - type TBD).    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210225102430/https://www.ard-wien.de/2021/01/28/corona-impfung-kroatien-serbien-ungarn-oesterreich-rumaenien/

I don't think the previous coders coded correctly - I think we are supposed to only code a non-zero value if mass vaccination has commenced; we are not supposed to code based on policies only.    While Kosovo is expected to receive its first vaccines from the World Health Organization's COVAX program for poorer countries, they are not yet delivered.   The Ministry of Health in Kosovo in early January announced that it had secured 535,000 dosages of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. But Pfizer officials have told RFE/RL that they are still in discussions with the government of Kosovo over the purchase of the supply.  Bosnia, Kosovo remain only countries in the region without vaccines  https://web.archive.org/web/20210323023035/https://www.rferl.org/a/kosovo-albania-covid-vaccines-health-workers/31161362.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210323023216/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/latest-on-coronavirus-outbreak/serbia-outperforms-eu-w-balkans-in-covid-vaccination/2154593

About 250 Kosovo health-care workers traveled from Kosovo to the Albanian city of Kukes on March 20 to get vaccinated against COVID-19.    As mass vaccination programme has not started in Kosovo, I still coded it as 0  https://web.archive.org/web/20210323023035/https://www.rferl.org/a/kosovo-albania-covid-vaccines-health-workers/31161362.html

According to the agenda of 28 March, the first batch of vaccine arrives at the airport on 28 March. They are from the COVAX programme.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210328110833/https://kryeministri-ks.net/qeveria-lehteson-masat-per-mbrojtjen-nga-pandemia-covid-19/

People over 65 can only leave their homes between 06:00 - 10:00 and 16:00 - 19:00.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210311084512/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-situation-in-kosovo.html

According to the ministerial order no.3.235/93/04.02.2021, depending on the incidence rate by localities, the activity of the educational units will be organized, starting with 8th of February, in three scenarios: a) Physical presence for all categories, if the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days in the locality is less or equal to 1/1000 people; b) physical presence for preschool, primary, 8th, 12th and 13th classes, and online presence for the other classes, for a incidence less or equal with 3/1000; c) Online presence for all categories, except preschool and primary units, if incidence is higher than 3/1000.    Links: https://archive.fo/wip/H8lox

According to the ministerial order no.3.459/280/06.03.2021, if the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days of cases is higher than 3/1000 inhabitants, but lower than 6/1000, the participation in classes is with physical presence for all preschoolers and primary school students, students from grades 8th, 12th, and 13th classes. If the threshold of 6/1000 is exceeded, the quarantine will be applied immediately, and all activities will be online.    Links: https://archive.fo/wip/iP5sE

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, fairs, mixed, flying and flea markets will be forbidden. For the economic operators having activities in closed and/or open spaces, (public or private) to organize their activity only between 05:00 and 21:00. According to the Decision 56/4.12.2020, it is proposed to resume the activity of agri-food markets organized in closed spaces. Outdoor cafes and clubs are closed between 11 PM and 6 AM. According to the Decision no.293/10.03.21, the organization and development of activity in cinemas, performance institutions and / or concerts are allowed with the participation of the public up to 50% of the maximum capacity of the space, if the incidence accumulated in the last 14 days of cases in the county / locality is less than or equal to 1.5 / 1,000 inhabitants. Also, the activity of restaurants and cafes inside hotels, boarding houses or other accommodation units is allowed without exceeding 50% of the maximum capacity of the space and in the time interval 6.00-22.00, in the counties / localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is less than or equal to 1.5 / 1,000 inhabitants, not exceeding 30% of the maximum capacity of the space.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322062833/https://archive.fo/TWKy02JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

According to the Decision no.293/10.03.21, the organization and outdoor performance of shows, concerts, public and private festivals, or other cultural events are allowed only with the participation of up to 300 spectators with seats, at a distance of at least 2 meters from each other, as well as wearing a protective mask. Activities are prohibited in counties / localities where the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days of cases is higher than 1.5 / 1,000 inhabitants.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322062833/https://archive.fo/TWKy02JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

According to the Decision no.293/10.03.21, it is forbidden to organize private events (weddings, baptisms, festive meals, etc.) in open spaces, such as, but not limited to, salons, cultural centers, restaurants, terraces, bars, cafes, halls / tents. Additionally, recreational outdoor and sporting activities are prohibited, except for those carried out with the participation of no more than 10 persons not living together.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322062833/https://archive.fo/TWKy0

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201120195835/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

The Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 (extended through the Decision 35/10.02.2021) of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance).   Link: https://archive.fo/cUlEp,  https://archive.fo/T7Aib, https://web.archive.org/web/20201212161456/https://www.gov.ro/fisiere/pagini_fisiere/Hotarare_CNSU_nr._58_din_10.12.2020.pdf, https://archive.fo/4mnCH and https://archive.fo/wip/KFsdV

According to the Decision 20/25.03.21, for localities where cumulative incidence is between 4 and 7,5 per 1000 inhabitants, there is a curfew in place between 8 PM and 5 AM on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday. Also, where the cumulative incidence is higher than 7.5/1000 inhabitants, the curfew (8PM-5AM) is applied during all the days of the week. There are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions) The National Institute of Public Health published a new list of states with high epidemiological risk. The decisions no.6/04.02.2021 and 9/11.02.2021 of National Committee for Emergency Situations contain the required conditions for the passengers coming in Romania from countries with high epidemiological risk. The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315184742/https://archive.fo/FtT0q

The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons. On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers. According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://archive.fo/hVM21

Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”. On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases. Also, the National Information Platform on vaccination against COVID-19 was released.  Links: https://archive.fo/cUlEp, https://archive.fo/klswT , https://archive.fo/Vi0vG and https://archive.fo/O0MTX#selection-697.0-697.76

According to the Ministry of Health, the units that are accredited by the Ministry of Health to perform the diagnosis by RT-PCR have the obligation to provide priority diagnosis for patients in health facilities, suspects in epidemiological investigations, and people at risk, according to the methodology of the National Institute of Public Health – National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases.   Link: https://archive.fo/6K5UM

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 (extended through Decision 58/10.12.2020) of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces, regardless the value of the cumulative incidence rate of cases in the last 14 days (as it previously of this decision was).   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201120195835/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf, https://web.archive.org/web/20201212161456/https://www.gov.ro/fisiere/pagini_fisiere/Hotarare_CNSU_nr._58_din_10.12.2020.pdf and https://archive.fo/4mnCH

Second stage of the vaccination campaign started on 15th of January and is aimed at people over 65 aged, people with chronic diseases (regardless of age) and key staff working in key areas. The coordinator of the National Committee for the Planning of COVID-19 Vaccination in Romania, announced how the appointments of people over 65 years of age and those with chronic diseases can be made. (Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna and AstraZeneca vaccines are used).  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/IzHsa, https://archive.fo/wip/qeZ7F and https://archive.fo/wip/eDFWM

On 15th of March, the third stage of the vaccination program for the general population began. Also, on 15th of March, the National Coordinating Committee for Vaccination Activities against COVID-19 decided to continue the vaccination campaign in Romania will all vaccines against COVID-19, following the analysis of the adverse reaction reports registered in Romania and the recommendations of the European Medicines Agency.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322055714/https://vaccinare-covid.gov.ro/peste-47-000-de-persoane-programate-si-peste-350-000-de-persoane-pe-lista-de-asteptare-pentru-etapa-a-iii-a/  and  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322054356/https://stirioficiale.ro/informatii/precizari-privind-vaccinarea-cu-vaccinul-produs-de-compania-oxford-astrazeneca-15-03-2020

Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322055714/https://vaccinare-covid.gov.ro/peste-47-000-de-persoane-programate-si-peste-350-000-de-persoane-pe-lista-de-asteptare-pentru-etapa-a-iii-a/  and  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322054356/https://stirioficiale.ro/informatii/precizari-privind-vaccinarea-cu-vaccinul-produs-de-compania-oxford-astrazeneca-15-03-2020

According to the Decision 35/10.02.2021, the alert status on the Romanian territory is extended. It is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance). Also, on 15th of January, the second stage of the vaccination campaign started, aiming people over 65 age and people with chronic diseases.   Link: https://archive.fo/4mnCH and https://archive.fo/wip/qeZ7F

Testing in widely available in Russia, both through government healthcare providers and private clinics.  Testing is free at government healthcare providers for those suspected of having coronavirus.  In Moscow, residents of Russia who have mandatory medical insurance may schedule a free test at any time at one of 207 government healthcare providers in Moscow that provide testing.  Private clinics also provide COVID testing on a fee-basis.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210308184707/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Sputnik V most widely administered. EpiVacCorons and KoviVak are approved for widespread use.  In the third week of February, another vaccine against COVID-19- ""KoviliVak"" developed by the Chumakov Ras Center was registered. It was the third vaccine to be approved for widespread use in our country after Sputnik V from the Gamalea Research Center and EpiVacCorons developed by Vector.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227203554/https://xn--80aesfpebagmfblc0a.xn--p1ai/news/20210227-1901.html    Broad availability has not yet been achieved:   However, not all the problems of mass vaccination have been solved so far. The day before, the head of the Ministry of Health Mikhail Murashko said that the regional authorities should actively encourage older citizens to be vaccinated, as in some regions the proportion of vaccinated residents over 60 years remains low.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227202910/https://xn--80aesfpebagmfblc0a.xn--p1ai/news/20210226-1942.html

Mass vaccination that started January 18 is still slow, with 4 million people (2.7 percent of the population) vaccinated as of February 26 – with large regional variation. The authorities have put in place measures to accelerate the pace.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210308121653/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Since there is continued discussion of accelerating vaccination pace, it does not seem broad availability has yet been reached. Therefore, keeping coding as is for now. Since there is continued discussion of accelerating vaccination pace, it does not seem broad availability has yet been reached. Therefore, keeping coding as is for now.    Vaccines used: Sputnik V    Currently, three vaccines for the prevention of COVID-19 are registered in Russia - Sputnik V, EpiVacCoron and KovikAk. The EpiVacoron vaccine was developed by the Vector State Virology and Biotechnology Research Center. Rospotrebnadzor stated the 100% immunological effectiveness of this vaccine during the first or second phase of clinical trials. As it became known in early March, ""EpiVacCorona"" received permission to use and among persons over 60 years.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210327222014/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/03/27/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-march-27-a69117  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327222727/https://xn--80aesfpebagmfblc0a.xn--p1ai/news/20210327-1919.html

""All visitors must comply with social distancing and sanitisation regulations. You will also be required to wear a face mask on public transport, in all indoor public spaces, and in outdoor spaces where it is not possible to maintain 1 metre social distancing.    Bars and restaurants remain open, but must close between the hours of midnight and 4:30am. Only six people may sit together at a table and it is not allowed to consume food standing at the bar.    Theatres and cinemas remain open, and religious ceremonies, including weddings and funerals are allowed.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314135206/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/san-marino/coronavirus

Policy: Bars and restaurants remain open, but must close between the hours of midnight and 4:30am. Theatres and cinemas remain open, and religious ceremonies, including weddings and funerals are allowed.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322152615/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/san-marino/coronavirus

Policy: Given that ""theatres and cinemas remain open, and religious ceremonies, including weddings and funerals are allowed,"" it is logical to deduce that there public event restrictions are recommended and lax.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322152615/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/san-marino/coronavirus

Policy: ""Only six people may sit together at a table and it is not allowed to consume food standing at the bar.""  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322152615/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/san-marino/coronavirus

Policy: No indication that there is any restrictions on public travel specifically with the exception of those due to curfew, internal travel restrictions, and mask wearing requirements.  Some mention of it here: ""All visitors must comply with social distancing and sanitisation regulations. You will also be required to wear a face mask on public transport...""    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322152615/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/san-marino/coronavirus

Policy: ""a curfew is currently in force in the Republic of San Marino from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. Internal travel within San Marino territory are allowed from 5 a.m. to 10 p.m.""  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322151737/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/en/home/right-banners/information-covid-19.html

Policy:   Travel between the Republic of San Marino and the Italian regions, provinces and municipalities where restrictive measures are in force for the containment of a high epidemiological risk (so-called red and orange zones) is forbidden except for proven work needs, health reasons or situations of necessity through self-certification. However, travel for study purposes is allowed for face-face teaching where permitted.    In any case, situations of necessity include cross-border travel:    a) to reach minor children at the other parent's or in any case at the foster parent's home, or to take them to one’s home;    b) to carry out authorized competitive sports activities (training and competitions);    c) to go to owned second homes;    d) for reunification with spouse/partner;    e) to purchase basic goods and/or goods that are not available in the place of residence.  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322151737/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/en/home/right-banners/information-covid-19.html

Policy:   San Marino citizens, people with San Marino residence and people whit a stay permit in San Marino who return to the Republic of San Marino from countries other than Italy and the Vatican City, or who have been outside these two countries in the 14 days preceding their return, are obliged to contact the Single Booking Centre of the Social Security Institute before their return, in order to take a molecular or antigenic swab test within 48 hours from their return, and bear the costs of the test. As an alternative, it is allowed to provide the SSI Laboratory for analysis with a certificate of anti-SARS-CoV-2 injection or attesting to the negative result of a coronavirus molecular or antigenic swab test taken during the last 48 hours before their entry into San Marino, in accordance with the health protocols in force in the Republic of San Marino.   Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322151737/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/en/home/right-banners/information-covid-19.html
No updates  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322153323/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No updates   Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322153323/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
Updates are regularly posted on this site.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322151737/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/en/home/right-banners/information-covid-19.html

Policy: Anyone needing to take a voluntary covid-19 test may contact facilities in San Marino authorised to perform tests.   Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322151737/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/en/home/right-banners/information-covid-19.html
No change  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322151737/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/en/home/right-banners/information-covid-19.html

Policy:  It is compulsory to wear the mask properly, both outdoors and indoors, except when being alone or together with cohabitants.   Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322151737/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/en/home/right-banners/information-covid-19.html

Policy: Curfew rules apply to the elderly.  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322151737/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/en/home/right-banners/information-covid-19.html

On 26 February, weekend restrictions for 27-28 February were introduced:  Bars and restaurants in the entire country will work tomorrow and the day after tomorrow from 6 am to 2 pm, after which time only food delivery will be allowed.  Food stands at ski slopes will also be opened until 2 pm only, whereas the establishments delivering food and drinks can perform that activity 24 hours a day.  Hotels in the entire country can serve food and drinks in their restaurants and café bars until 2 pm to all citizens, whereas from 2 pm to 10 pm this service will be available exclusively to the guests staying in that hotel or in some other categorised accommodation.  In addition, shopping malls, shops that do not sell food, bookmakers, casinos, children’s playrooms, gyms, fitness centres, indoor spaces for football and other sports will be opened from 6 am to 2 pm for the weekend.  However, sports facilities where competitions have been booked in advance will be available solely for that purpose after 2 pm as well.  The facilities that will keep regular working hours and to which the above-mentioned restrictions do not apply are food stores, pharmacies, petrol stations, doctor’s offices, dental clinics, laboratories, theatres and veterinary clinics.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308031500/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/168513/new-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-for-the-weekend.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308025958/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

On 05 March, country-wide weekend restrictions for 06-07 March were introduced:  A decision was made to transfer high schools to online classes from Monday, 08 March.  Close all restaurants and shops from Saturday midday till Monday morning at 6 am.  Theaters will be able to work, scheduled sporting events can be held, but without an audience.   In the city of Nis, the flea market and car market would be closed for the next two weekends.    On Monday, everything will work as before the measures adopted at today's session.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308033058/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/168853/tightening-anti-epidemic-measures.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308034043/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=05&nav_id=110548  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308033436/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=04&nav_id=110540  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308025958/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Higher (secondary) schools will switch to online lessons from 8 March 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308033058/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/168853/tightening-anti-epidemic-measures.php

From 15 March 2021, higher grades of primary schools will switch to online classes, while secondary schools will continue with online lessons in the next week too.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210315162138/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169201/new-epidemiological-measures-in-force-as-of-tonight-at-9-pm.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315131251/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

From 17 March to 22 March, similar to weekend restrictions, everything will be closed in Serbia, except for food stores, pharmacies and gas stations. There will be no curfew or complete ban on movement.     Kindergartens will stay open, while students in the lower grades of primary schools will probably switch to online classes from Monday for at least a week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210320200635/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169357/tighter-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-until-monday.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320201613/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/business.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=16&nav_id=110567  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320195743/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New epidemiological measures were introduced starting from 22 March 2021 and do not include information about schools. No change to school closure policy was found.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328200027/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169612/new-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-as-of-monday-at-6-am.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

The current measures remain in force until further notice.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194725/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169771/current-measures-against-covid-19-remain-in-force.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New measures were introduced for the upcoming weekend (13-14 March 2021) - from Friday 12 March 9 pm to Monday 15 March 6 am, all cafes and restaurants will be closed, as well as all shops (except grocery stores), beauty parlours, hair salons, bookmakers, casinos, children's playrooms, gyms, sports facilities ...    From Monday 15 March 2021, the measures as before the weekend will apply again, including enabling work from home for all employees wherever possible and limitation of opening hours of services and shops.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210315162138/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169201/new-epidemiological-measures-in-force-as-of-tonight-at-9-pm.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315131251/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New measures were introduced starting from 22 March 2021:  - Cafes, restaurants, night clubs and bars, and shopping malls will remain closed.  - Cafes and restaurants are allowed to sell food and beverages at a counter, and they can also perform delivery 24 hours a day. Hotel restaurants and cafes can only serve hotel guests until 9pm.  - All food sales facilities and cultural institutions (cinemas, theatres, galleries and libraries) can work until 9 pm, and all other facilities up to 8 pm, under the following conditions -  provide at least nine square metres per person or visitor; exceptions are fitness clubs, spas, gyms and the like where sixteen square metres per person must be provided.    Previous measures that remain in place:  - Face coverings are mandatory indoors and on public transport, as well as outdoors if contact with other people cannot be avoided.  - Public transport is limited to half of its declared capacity.  - Public gatherings of more than five people are prohibited indoors and outdoors. Excluded from this measure are work organizations, schools, and similar facilities, which are subject to the prescribed limit on the number of persons within the square footage of the facility (minimum 4 m2 per person).  - Employees should work from home wherever possible.  - Visits to patients in hospitals are banned.  - Visits to elder-care homes are limited to 15 minutes.  - The recommended distance between people outdoors is 1.5 meters.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328200027/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169612/new-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-as-of-monday-at-6-am.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

The current measures remain in force until further notice.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194725/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169771/current-measures-against-covid-19-remain-in-force.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

On Monday, everything will work as before the measures adopted at today's session.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308033058/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/168853/tightening-anti-epidemic-measures.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308034043/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=05&nav_id=110548  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308033436/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=04&nav_id=110540  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308025958/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New measures were introduced for the upcoming weekend (13-14 March 2021) - from Friday 12 March 9 pm to Monday 15 March 6 am, all cafes and restaurants will be closed, as well as all shops (except grocery stores), beauty parlours, hair salons, bookmakers, casinos, children's playrooms, gyms, sports facilities ...    From Monday 15 March 2021, the measures as before the weekend will apply again, including prohibition of public gatherings with presence of more than five people indoors and outdoors. Excluded from this measure are work organizations, schools, stores, shopping malls and similar facilities, which are subject to the prescribed limit on the number of persons within the square footage of the facility (minimum 4 m2 per person).    http://web.archive.org/web/20210315162138/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169201/new-epidemiological-measures-in-force-as-of-tonight-at-9-pm.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315131251/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

From 17 March to 22 March, similar to weekend restrictions, everything will be closed in Serbia, except for food stores, pharmacies and gas stations. There will be no curfew or complete ban on movement.     Kindergartens will stay open, while students in the lower grades of primary schools will probably switch to online classes from Monday for at least a week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210320200635/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169357/tighter-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-until-monday.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320201613/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/business.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=16&nav_id=110567  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320195743/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New measures were introduced starting from 22 March 2021:  - Cafes, restaurants, night clubs and bars, and shopping malls will remain closed.  - Cafes and restaurants are allowed to sell food and beverages at a counter, and they can also perform delivery 24 hours a day. Hotel restaurants and cafes can only serve hotel guests until 9pm.  - All food sales facilities and cultural institutions (cinemas, theatres, galleries and libraries) can work until 9 pm, and all other facilities up to 8 pm, under the following conditions -  provide at least nine square metres per person or visitor; exceptions are fitness clubs, spas, gyms and the like where sixteen square metres per person must be provided.    Previous measures that remain in place:  - Face coverings are mandatory indoors and on public transport, as well as outdoors if contact with other people cannot be avoided.  - Public transport is limited to half of its declared capacity.  - Public gatherings of more than five people are prohibited indoors and outdoors. Excluded from this measure are work organizations, schools, and similar facilities, which are subject to the prescribed limit on the number of persons within the square footage of the facility (minimum 4 m2 per person).  - Employees should work from home wherever possible.  - Visits to patients in hospitals are banned.  - Visits to elder-care homes are limited to 15 minutes.  - The recommended distance between people outdoors is 1.5 meters.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328200027/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169612/new-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-as-of-monday-at-6-am.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

The current measures remain in force until further notice.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194725/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169771/current-measures-against-covid-19-remain-in-force.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

On 26 February, weekend restrictions for 27-28 February were introduced:  Bars and restaurants in the entire country will work tomorrow and the day after tomorrow from 6 am to 2 pm, after which time only food delivery will be allowed.  Food stands at ski slopes will also be opened until 2 pm only, whereas the establishments delivering food and drinks can perform that activity 24 hours a day.  Hotels in the entire country can serve food and drinks in their restaurants and café bars until 2 pm to all citizens, whereas from 2 pm to 10 pm this service will be available exclusively to the guests staying in that hotel or in some other categorised accommodation.  In addition, shopping malls, shops that do not sell food, bookmakers, casinos, children’s playrooms, gyms, fitness centres, indoor spaces for football and other sports will be opened from 6 am to 2 pm for the weekend.  However, sports facilities where competitions have been booked in advance will be available solely for that purpose after 2 pm as well.  The facilities that will keep regular working hours and to which the above-mentioned restrictions do not apply are food stores, pharmacies, petrol stations, doctor’s offices, dental clinics, laboratories, theatres and veterinary clinics.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308031500/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/168513/new-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-for-the-weekend.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308025958/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

On Monday, everything will work as before the measures adopted at today's session.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308033058/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/168853/tightening-anti-epidemic-measures.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308034043/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=05&nav_id=110548  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308033436/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=04&nav_id=110540  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308025958/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

The entry of citizens into Serbia was also analyzed and the decision has been made to allow all citizens of Serbia who are fully immunized to enter Serbia without a PCR test. The same applies to all individuals who are not citizens of Serbia. This means that they received two doses of the Pfizer vaccine, two doses of Chinese Sinopharm, or two Sputnik V vaccines. For Astra Zeneca, the equivalent is one vaccine.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194725/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169771/current-measures-against-covid-19-remain-in-force.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

On 26 February, weekend restrictions for 27-28 February were introduced:  Bars and restaurants in the entire country will work tomorrow and the day after tomorrow from 6 am to 2 pm, after which time only food delivery will be allowed.  Food stands at ski slopes will also be opened until 2 pm only, whereas the establishments delivering food and drinks can perform that activity 24 hours a day.  Hotels in the entire country can serve food and drinks in their restaurants and café bars until 2 pm to all citizens, whereas from 2 pm to 10 pm this service will be available exclusively to the guests staying in that hotel or in some other categorised accommodation.  In addition, shopping malls, shops that do not sell food, bookmakers, casinos, children’s playrooms, gyms, fitness centres, indoor spaces for football and other sports will be opened from 6 am to 2 pm for the weekend.  However, sports facilities where competitions have been booked in advance will be available solely for that purpose after 2 pm as well.  The facilities that will keep regular working hours and to which the above-mentioned restrictions do not apply are food stores, pharmacies, petrol stations, doctor’s offices, dental clinics, laboratories, theatres and veterinary clinics.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308031500/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/168513/new-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-for-the-weekend.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308025958/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

On 05 March, country-wide weekend restrictions for 06-07 March were introduced:  Close all restaurants and shops from Saturday midday till Monday morning at 6 am.  Theaters will be able to work, scheduled sporting events can be held, but without an audience.   In the city of Nis, the flea market and car market would be closed for the next two weekends.    On Monday, everything will work as before the measures adopted at today's session.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308033058/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/168853/tightening-anti-epidemic-measures.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308034043/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=05&nav_id=110548  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308033436/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=04&nav_id=110540  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308025958/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/
http://web.archive.org/web/20210315194903/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/

From 17 March to 22 March, similar to weekend restrictions, everything will be closed in Serbia, except for food stores, pharmacies and gas stations. There will be no curfew or complete ban on movement.     Kindergartens will stay open, while students in the lower grades of primary schools will probably switch to online classes from Monday for at least a week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210320200635/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169357/tighter-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-until-monday.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320201613/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/business.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=16&nav_id=110567  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320195743/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New measures were introduced starting from 22 March 2021:  - Cafes, restaurants, night clubs and bars, and shopping malls will remain closed.  - Cafes and restaurants are allowed to sell food and beverages at a counter, and they can also perform delivery 24 hours a day. Hotel restaurants and cafes can only serve hotel guests until 9pm.  - All food sales facilities and cultural institutions (cinemas, theatres, galleries and libraries) can work until 9 pm, and all other facilities up to 8 pm, under the following conditions -  provide at least nine square metres per person or visitor; exceptions are fitness clubs, spas, gyms and the like where sixteen square metres per person must be provided.    Previous measures that remain in place:  - Face coverings are mandatory indoors and on public transport, as well as outdoors if contact with other people cannot be avoided.  - Public transport is limited to half of its declared capacity.  - Public gatherings of more than five people are prohibited indoors and outdoors. Excluded from this measure are work organizations, schools, and similar facilities, which are subject to the prescribed limit on the number of persons within the square footage of the facility (minimum 4 m2 per person).  - Employees should work from home wherever possible.  - Visits to patients in hospitals are banned.  - Visits to elder-care homes are limited to 15 minutes.  - The recommended distance between people outdoors is 1.5 meters.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328200027/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169612/new-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-as-of-monday-at-6-am.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

The current measures remain in force until further notice.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194725/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169771/current-measures-against-covid-19-remain-in-force.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Kindergartens will stay open, while students in the lower grades of primary schools will probably switch to online classes from Monday for at least a week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210320200635/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169357/tighter-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-until-monday.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320201613/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/business.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=16&nav_id=110567  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320195743/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New measures were introduced starting from 22 March 2021 and bring no change to protection of elderly people:  - Cafes, restaurants, night clubs and bars, and shopping malls will remain closed.  - Cafes and restaurants are allowed to sell food and beverages at a counter, and they can also perform delivery 24 hours a day. Hotel restaurants and cafes can only serve hotel guests until 9pm.  - All food sales facilities and cultural institutions (cinemas, theatres, galleries and libraries) can work until 9 pm, and all other facilities up to 8 pm, under the following conditions -  provide at least nine square metres per person or visitor; exceptions are fitness clubs, spas, gyms and the like where sixteen square metres per person must be provided.    Previous measures that remain in place:  - Face coverings are mandatory indoors and on public transport, as well as outdoors if contact with other people cannot be avoided.  - Public transport is limited to half of its declared capacity.  - Public gatherings of more than five people are prohibited indoors and outdoors. Excluded from this measure are work organizations, schools, and similar facilities, which are subject to the prescribed limit on the number of persons within the square footage of the facility (minimum 4 m2 per person).  - Employees should work from home wherever possible.  - Visits to patients in hospitals are banned.  - Visits to elder-care homes are limited to 15 minutes.  - The recommended distance between people outdoors is 1.5 meters.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328200027/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169612/new-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-as-of-monday-at-6-am.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

The current measures remain in force until further notice.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194725/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169771/current-measures-against-covid-19-remain-in-force.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Opening or closure of maternity and primary schools is under the responsibility of municipalities, opening/closure of secondary schools is under the responsibility of larger administrative units.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210301153734/https://kosice.korzar.sme.sk/c/22604468/otvorenie-kosickych-skol-je-na-spadnutie-posledne-slovo-este-nepadlo.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210301125304/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210301135619/https://sk.usembassy.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/193/Feb-5-Traffic-Light-System.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20210301144631/https://korona.gov.sk/

On 06 March, it was announced that the whole of Slovakia remains in the fourth level of alert according to nationwide COVID AUTOMAT criteria from 08 March. At the level of the regions, 30 districts have reached the IV (black) warning level, there will be 46 districts in level III – bordeaux and three districts will be red in Level II.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308041912/https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanok?covid-19-23-02-2021-okresy-automat  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308040518/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

National indicator remains black (level IV). Regional indicators remain at levels II (pink-red), III (bordeax), and IV (black).  Kindergartens and grades one to four of primary schools are open only for children whose parents need to be present at their workplace.   A parent who will bring a child to kindergarten or school will have to show a negative test not older than seven days, and a confirmation that they need to be present at their work.  Students of final grades of secondary schools and children without access to remote education will be able to attend in-person classes.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210315211555/https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanok?covid-19-02-03-2021-covid-automat-okresy  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315204302/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315205821/https://www.mic.iom.sk/en/news/637-covid-19-measures.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315205416/https://spectator.sme.sk/t/8282/coronavirus  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315210825/https://korona.gov.sk/en/

On Wednesday, 17 March, 2021, the government extended the state of emergency for a further 40 days until April 28, 2021, with effect from March 20. At the same time, on the basis of the recommendations of the Pandemic Commission, it modified the exceptions to the curfew.  Main changes:  From Saturday 20 March there is a ban on traveling abroad for recreation, both individual and group.  Exceptions to the curfew included pathways for medical and pharmaceutical undergraduates to teach.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210327183934/https://www.minv.sk/?tlacove-spravy=&sprava=aktualizovane-pravidla-a-vynimky-zo-zakazu-vychadzania-ucinne-od-soboty-20-marca  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327183038/https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanok?cpvod-19-17-03-2021-nudzovy-stav-zakony  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327180107/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From 22 March, the whole of Slovakia has been in the fourth level of alert according to the nationwide criteria of COVID AUTOMAT. At the level of the regions, 20 districts reached the IV (black) warning level, 55 districts will be bourdeaux in level III and four districts in level II – red.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210327185111/https://korona.gov.sk/tlacove-spravy/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327184943/https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanok?covid-19-16-03-2021-covid-automat-22-03  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327180107/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Slovakia continues to have the highest warning - Warning IV (black) – as a national indicator under the Traffic Light System.  Regional districts continue to have either Warning II (pink), Warning III (red), or Warning IV (black) indicators.   With regard to coding, the restrictions for Warning II, III, and IV phases are similar except for requirements on wearing masks, internal movement, and the period of validity of a PCR test. Current coding (general vs targeted) was therefore kept.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210301125304/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210301135619/https://sk.usembassy.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/193/Feb-5-Traffic-Light-System.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20210301144631/https://korona.gov.sk/
