From Wednesday 03 March to 19 March there is a curfew in Slovakia from 20.00 to 1.00 the following day. There are several exceptions to this ban:  - from 03 March a stay in nature, including individual sport, is allowed only within the district  - from 08 March it will be mandatory to wear an FFP2 respirator in shops and public transport,  - from 08 March positively tested persons will no longer be able to go to or leave the house for various purposes, they will only be able to visit a doctor or pharmacy,  - from 15 March will be obliged respirator in all interiors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308041453/https://korona.gov.sk/zakaz-vychadzania-marec/

Current coding (general vs targeted) was therefore kept.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210301125304/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210301135619/https://sk.usembassy.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/193/Feb-5-Traffic-Light-System.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20210301144631/https://korona.gov.sk/

From Wednesday 03 March to 19 March there is a curfew in Slovakia from 20.00 to 1.00 the following day. There are several exceptions to this ban:  - from 03 March a stay in nature, including individual sport, is allowed only within the district  - from 08 March it will be mandatory to wear an FFP2 respirator in shops and public transport,  - from 08 March positively tested persons will no longer be able to go to or leave the house for various purposes, they will only be able to visit a doctor or pharmacy,  - from 15 March will be obliged respirator in all interiors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308041453/https://korona.gov.sk/zakaz-vychadzania-marec/

The prestigious scientific journal ""Science"" this week published a study of November's nationwide testing. The scientific team that worked on this material was led by Martin Pavelka, an epidemiologist at the Institute of Health Analyses.     The study authors point to the high effectiveness of nationwide testing, which, coupled with the strict measures taken on October 24 last year, contributed to a 58 percent reduction in virus prevalence in the non-isolated part of the population.     ""Taking into account that the epidemic was on a growing trend at the time (4.4% daily growth), the success of this intervention led to a 70% reduction compared to the hypothetical state if the interventions did not occur,"" explained Martin Pavelka of the Institute of Health Analyses of the Ministry of Health of the Slovak Republic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210327182327/https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanok?covid-19-25-03-2021-studia

On Monday 8 March, lessons in all grades of all primary schools in the country will continue just as they have last week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210309051831/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-03-04-minister-kustec-opening-schools-and-vaccinating-teachers-top-priorities-for-the-ministry/

All kindergartens, primary schools, adult education centres and vocational high schools will open for face to face classes. High School senior students will also attend classes in person:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322230743/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/coronavirus

Restaurants and bars are closed, with the exception of those in the Southeastern and Posavje regions that are, from 6 March 2021, allowed to open outdoor services between 0600-1900. Social distancing and hygiene rules apply:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322230743/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/coronavirus
All large gatherings (public and private) are prohibited:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322230743/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/coronavirus

The government extended the ordinances issued on the basis of the Communicable Diseases Act, and thereby the validity of the measures contained in those ordinances. They include the temporary restriction of collective exercising of religious freedom, partial restriction of movement and the restriction of public gatherings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210309051831/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-03-04-minister-kustec-opening-schools-and-vaccinating-teachers-top-priorities-for-the-ministry/

Groups of up to 10 people are permitted to meet indoors and outdoors. There is no limit on the number of different households that can mix within this 10-person limit. Social distancing and mask wearing measures continue to apply:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322230743/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/coronavirus

Public transport (buses and trains) is available across Slovenia but is following a limited timetable. Taxis are still permitted to operate:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322230743/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/coronavirus

A curfew from 10PM to 6AM remains in place in the entire country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210309053014/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

A curfew is in place from 9pm to 6am every day. There are exceptions for access to essential services, protecting life, health and property and for travelling to/from work if you cannot work from home:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322230743/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/coronavirus

The Government adopted a new ordinance under which the restriction on movement in the Coastal-Karst region will be reinstated as of Saturday, 27 February 2021. Since the epidemiological situation is fairly comparable among the municipalities in the Coastal-Karst region, and since there is only one region that has re-entered the red phase, the Government decided that movement would be restricted throughout the entire region, and not just in the individual municipalities within that region.    Therefore, public assembly is prohibited in the Coastal-Karst region, and entry into and departure from the Coastal-Karst region is also prohibited. Schools in the region remain open.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210309052636/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-02-26-restrictions-on-assembly-and-movement-reinstated-in-the-coastal-karst-region-schools-remain-open/

Since 15 February 2021, movement between municipalities and regions has been permitted. However, on 26 February 2021, the region of Obalno-kraška has been re-classified as red, which means that if you are in this region, you cannot travel to other regions:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322230743/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/coronavirus

As of Feb. 12, individuals arriving from most EEA countries or Switzerland must produce proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test result in order to enter the country; alternatively, they can enter self-isolation for 14 days. However, a PCR test may be taken after eight days, and a negative result will end the isolation period.    Individuals arriving from high-risk non-EU countries must register with authorities and self-isolate for at least eight days, after which a COVID-19 test may be taken; those testing positive are required to self-isolate until they have recovered. Cross-border commuters are not required to self-isolate, though they must be in possession of a negative PCR or antigen COVID-19 test result taken within the previous seven days.     In addition, from Feb. 13, international arrivals who can provide evidence that they have been vaccinated against COVID-19 with two doses or have previously recovered from the virus will be permitted to enter without self-isolation or testing.    Individuals arriving from countries designated as low risk may enter without restriction; these countries include Australia, China, Finland, Iceland, New Zealand, Norway, Singapore, South Korea, and Taiwan:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322230743/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/coronavirus

On February 3, 2021, an eight package (EUR 320 mn) was approved, which extends the furlough till April and the short-time work scheme till June. The wage subsidy under the furlough was increased from 80 to 100 percent under certain conditions. In addition, the government will cover part of the minimum wage increase for affected businesses and will pay one-off allowances to certain vulnerable groups:  https://archive.vn/WkKzU

Measures related to public guarantees  - The public guarantee scheme with impact beyond 2020 (loans with maturity up to 5 years).  - The deferral of loans by up to 12 months with impact beyond 2020. The sixth anti-corona package allows for additional deferral of loans for 9 months in 2021 (the applications can be submitted to the bank until end of February 2021) in order to mitigate as much as possible the negative consequences of the second COVID-19 epidemic on the economy.  - State guarantees of EUR 30m for bank loans for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, and the reduction of bank costs and of EUR 100 million to cover the first loss of the financial engineering measure in the field of tourism and catering. The measure is implemented by the Public Fund of the Republic of Slovenia for Entrepreneurship and the SID bank:  https://archive.vn/vYODR

Testing is available for both foreign nationals and Slovenians.  No appointment is required for the rapid antigen tests (RAT), and they are available throughout the country, including Ljubljana airport.  For the PCR test, available at the Ljubljana Clinical Center, an appointment is required, but is usually available within a day.  For foreign nationals, cost for RAT is 25-30 euro; cost for PCR is 93 euro.  Results for both tests will be provided to you electronically within 24 hours:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210318000619/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Contact tracing is happening however the level of cases has exceeded the capacity at which tracing is occurring:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322232211/https://www.total-slovenia-news.com/politics/7151-epidemiologists-abandon-contact-tracing-quarantine-orders

Face masks: Masks are required at all times indoors and any time outdoors when a distance of 3 meters (10 feet) cannot be maintained:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210318000619/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Per Slovenian government announcement, vaccination administration has begun with health care workers and vulnerable populations. According to the announcement, when general distribution is possible, vaccines will be available to all residents of Slovenia (but not visitors), regardless of insurance status:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210318000619/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A curfew from 10PM to 6AM remains in place for the entire population, including the elderly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210309053014/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/
Visits to care homes or hospitals are not allowed:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322230743/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/coronavirus

At the federal level, the Public Health Agency recommends that, for the period of 25 Jan-1 April, upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) conduct their education partially as distance education and partially at school. Whether to switch to distance learning depends on infection rates.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210308153347/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    At the regional level, therefore, several regional 'Infection Control Units' (Smittskyd) have recommended to switch distance learning entirely for the senior level of compulsory school (högstadieskolor) and upper-secondary schools (gymnasieskolor). This concerns in the regions of Gävleborg, Halland, Kalmar, Kronoberg, Skåne, Stockholm, Skellefteå, Västmanland and Västra Götaland.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210308153242/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/regional-information-about-coronavirus

At the federal level, the Public Health Agency recommends that, for the period of 25 Jan-1 April, upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) conduct their education partially as distance education and partially at school. Whether to switch to distance learning depends on infection rates. http://web.archive.org/web/20210311191243/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    At the regional level, therefore, several regional 'Infection Control Units' (Smittskyd) have recommended to switch distance learning entirely for the senior level of compulsory school (högstadieskolor) and upper-secondary schools (gymnasieskolor). This concerns in the regions of Gävleborg, Halland, Kalmar, Kronoberg, Skåne, Stockholm, Skellefteå, Västmanland and Västra Götaland.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210311191515/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset

At the federal level, the Public Health Agency recommends that, for the period of 25 Jan-1 April, upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) conduct their education partially as distance education and partially at school. Whether to switch to distance learning depends on infection rates.     This decision is at the discretion of the school principal, who has a certain flexibility to make decisions about their activities based on the current infection control situation or local needs, which is why this is coded with a Targeted flag.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318185946/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    At the regional level, several regional 'Infection Control Units' (Smittskyd) have made more specific recommendations to schools, such as:   - To switch distance learning entirely for the senior level of compulsory school (högstadieskolor) and upper-secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) in Stockholm: https://web.archive.org/web/20210319183430/https://www.sll.se/verksamhet/halsa-och-vard/nyheter-halsa-och-vard/2021/02/nya-regionala-rekommendationer/   - To only allow 1/3 of students at a time in gymnasieskolor in Västra Götaland: http://web.archive.org/web/20210319183251/https://vgrfokus.se/2021/03/covid-19-fortsatt-hogt-tryck-pa-varden-skarpta-rad-forlangs/

At the federal level, the Public Health Agency recommends that, for the period of 25 Jan-1 April, upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) conduct their education partially as distance education and partially at school. Whether to switch to distance learning depends on infection rates. This decision is at the discretion of the school principal, who has a certain flexibility to make decisions about their activities based on the current infection control situation or local needs, which is why this is coded with a Targeted flag.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210326144452/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    At the regional level, several regional 'Infection Control Units' (Smittskyd) have made more specific recommendations to schools, such as:   - To only allow 1/3 of students at a time in gymnasieskolor in Västra Götaland: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326145222/https://alfresco.vgregion.se/alfresco/service/vgr/storage/node/content/workspace/SpacesStore/a98c8c64-a09b-487a-9b6d-824273810afc/2%20-%20Regionala%20rek%20%C3%B6vers%C3%A4ttningar%20-%20Engelska%20A4%20%28Vecka%2011%29.pdf?a=false&guest=true

Addition:    On 25 March, it was announced that the Swedish Public Health Agency's national recommendation for partial distance education for upper secondary schools, which expires after 1 April, will not be extended.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210326105759/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/ingen-forlangning-av-rekommendation-om-fjarr--och-distansundervisning-pa-gymnasiet/

At the federal level, the Public Health Agency recommends that, for the period of 25 Jan-1 April, upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) conduct their education partially as distance education and partially at school. Whether to switch to distance learning depends on infection rates. This decision is at the discretion of the school principal, who has a certain flexibility to make decisions about their activities based on the current infection control situation or local needs, which is why this is coded with a Targeted flag.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210401164149/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    At the regional level, several regional 'Infection Control Units' (Smittskyd) have made more specific recommendations to schools, such as:   - To only allow 1/3 of students at a time in gymnasieskolor in Västra Götaland: http://web.archive.org/web/20210401164203/https://alfresco.vgregion.se/alfresco/service/vgr/storage/node/content/workspace/SpacesStore/a98c8c64-a09b-487a-9b6d-824273810afc/2%20-%20Regionala%20rek%20%C3%B6vers%C3%A4ttningar%20-%20Engelska%20A4%20%28Vecka%2011%29.pdf?a=false&guest=true

The national recommendation for upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) to partially conduct their education as distance education has not been extended. School principals can still decide to conduct distance education if necessary based on the local conditions.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210402183358/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    The regions of Dalarna and Kalmar län decided to extend the recommendation for partial distance education.  - Dalarna (up until week 15): http://web.archive.org/web/20210401164250/https://www.regiondalarna.se/press/nyheter-och-pressmeddelanden/smittskydd-dalarna-rekommendation-om-fortsatt-distansundervisning-i-dalarna/   - Kalmar län (until 30 April): http://web.archive.org/web/20210401164255/https://www.regionkalmar.se/nyhetslista/rekommendation-om-distansundervisning2/     The recommendation to only allow allow 1/3 of students at a time in gymnasieskolor in Västra Götaland also remains valid until at least 18 April: http://web.archive.org/web/20210401164203/https://alfresco.vgregion.se/alfresco/service/vgr/storage/node/content/workspace/SpacesStore/a98c8c64-a09b-487a-9b6d-824273810afc/2%20-%20Regionala%20rek%20%C3%B6vers%C3%A4ttningar%20-%20Engelska%20A4%20%28Vecka%2011%29.pdf?a=false&guest=true

New rules bring stricter policies into place on businesses, particularly restaurants and cafes. From Monday, March 1:     -""Under the new rules put forward by the Public Health Agency last week, only one person should be served in restaurants and cafés that do not have their own entrances.  This means that you should eat alone at restaurants located in, for example, shopping centres and larger department stores, where the entrances are shared within another space.""     -""All customers at restaurants and cafés should keep at least one metre apart from each other.""     -""All restaurants and cafés in Sweden have to close at 8.30pm and may not open until 5am the next morning.""     https://archive.is/PxBGb#selection-2201.61-2201.225

Most workplaces can open with special measures in place, but a number of workplaces are forced to close in relation to the ban on public gatherings of over 8 people, such as fairground amusements and parades, and markets and fairs.     Restaurants and cafés must be closed for consumption on site between 20.30 and 05.00. The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to four people. If a party is larger than eight people, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.    Shops, gym and sports facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². The maximum number of visitors is 500. They must have clear signs about how many are allowed to stay in the room at the same time. Department stores and shops must take appropriate measures for people to visit the business one by one, without company.   Shopping centres are an exception because they may house workplaces, care facilities and public transport services that cannot be accessed in any other way.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210311194528/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    http://web.archive.org/web/20210312090016/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-gallande-restauranger-och-krogar/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210312090222/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/coronapandemin-detta-galler-just-nu    http://web.archive.org/web/20210312090534/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/news/2021/mars/limited-number-of-visitors-to-stores-shops-swimming-centres-gyms-and-sports-facilities

**Changed back to 2G after incorrect interpretation of new rules for amusement parks by other coder. The new rules do not allow amusement parks to reopen. Currently, 'permanent amusement parks' ('stadigvarande tivolinöje') are not covered by the new rules (re maximum numbers of visitors), as they are deemed a 'public event' under ch 3, s 1 of the Restriction Regulation (begränsningsförordningen), i.e. the 8-people gathering limit.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210401150004/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/  (under the heading ""Nöjesparker, djurparker, temaparker eller andra liknande anläggningar"")

New rules on sports come into place from Monday, March 1. ""no competitive sport below elite level will be allowed to take place. This includes single matches for children born in 2005 or later, which were previously exempt.""     https://archive.is/PxBGb#selection-2201.61-2201.225

No change:     The government has introduced a number of restrictions in connection with the pandemic law.    Until further notice, no more than eight people may be present at a public gathering or public event. The police has the right to cancel or dissolve an event that has more than eight attendees.    If a private gathering is held at an event venue, in a meeting room and at other rented premises, a maximum of eight people are allowed to attend. An exception is made for funerals, where up to 20 participants are allowed.     If you organise an event in violation of the ban, you may face a fine or prison sentence of up to six months.    Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person is given ten square meters of space. The companies must display clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210311194528/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change:   The government has introduced a number of restrictions in connection with the pandemic law. Until further notice, no more than 8 people may be present at a public gathering or public event. The police has the right to cancel or dissolve an event that has more than 8 attendees.   If a private gathering is held at an event venue, in a meeting room and at other rented premises, a maximum of eight people are allowed to attend. An exception is made for funerals, where up to 20 participants are allowed. If you organise an event in violation of the ban, you may face a fine or prison sentence of up to six months.   Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person is given ten square meters of space. The companies must display clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210326151033/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Several regions have issued a recommendation to avoid unnecessary travel within the region and to other parts of Sweden. These currently include Sörmland, Uppsala, Västerbotten, Västmanland, Västra Götaland.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210308153242/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/regional-information-about-coronavirus    The nation-wide recommendation for in-country travel is still:   You have the personal responsibility to travel in a way that minimizes the spread of infection. ... Keep in mind that the spread of covid-19 is difficult to predict and can change in the place you travel to. Therefore, local restrictions may be imposed at short notice. It can affect your ability to travel home. If you need to stay away longer than planned, you may need to arrange accommodation during the extended stay and transport home.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210308162404/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/

No change: non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU is banned until March 31; temporary ban on entry to Sweden for nationals from the UK, Denmark and Norway (with exceptions); all foreign nationals need to present a negative Covid-19 test result no older than 48h in order to travel into Sweden.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210308162414/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

No change: non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU is banned until March 31; temporary ban on entry to Sweden for nationals from the UK, Denmark and Norway (with exceptions); all foreign nationals need to present a negative Covid-19 test result no older than 48h in order to travel into Sweden.     In addition, the following recommendation applies to everyone, including Swedes:   The Public Health Agency recommends everyone who travels into Sweden , regardless of citizenship, to test themselves upon entry and to avoid contacts for seven days. Five days after arriving from abroad, the traveler should take a second test. This applies regardless of whether you are covered by the requirement to present a negative covid-19 test before entry.  Stay home for at least seven days.  Avoid contact with others as much as possible.  Test yourself as soon as possible after arrival in Sweden with a follow-up test after five days.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210312194210/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

No change:  Short-time working means that an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. This means that employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. ... The government extends support for short-time working until June 2021. ... The support for short-time work allowance has been extended and the working hours can be reduced up to 80% for the months: May, June and July.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210308165141/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/gathered-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/for-employers

The government extends support for short-time working until June 2021. ... The support for short-time work allowance has been extended and the working hours can be reduced up to 80% for the months: May, June and July.     The government has decided to temporarily suspend the deduction from sick pay for the qualifying period from 11 March 2020 to 30 April 2021.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210312194533/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/gathered-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/for-employers

The Public Health Agency recommends everyone over 6 years old gets tested if they have symptoms. In addition, people who have travelled to Sweden from abroad can get tested.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210308165342/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/

No change: testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad.    If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210312195310/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210312194210/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

No change:   The treating physician or other health care personnel with special competence perform the infection tracking. The person with covid-19 is contacted and has to answer questions about who they have met and where they have been since the first signs of symptoms and 48 hours before. ... In the next step, contact is made with those who may have been exposed to infection. This is done either by the infected person himself, in dialogue with an infection tracker, or by an infection tracker in the responsible region. Anyone who is contacted in an infection tracker receives information about what this means and what measures may need to be taken.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210308165425/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/testning-och-smittsparning/smittsparning/

Several regions have introduced more extensive mask recommendations: the use of masks on public transport at all times, not only during rush hours, and when there is prolonged (15+ min) close contact with other people indoors.      Although these are technically recommendations, they are much stronger than the federal government's mask recommendation which is limited to rush hours on public transport, so I have coded it as 2T to reflect the policy change as a result of which in practice, in these regions, people will be wearing masks much more often than before. The wording of the recommendation is strong, e.g. for Stockholm: ""Monouse masks must always be worn in public transport and indoor environments where there is prolonged contact with other people.""    http://web.archive.org/web/20210308153242/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/regional-information-about-coronavirus

No change: several regions have introduced more extensive mask recommendations: the use of masks on public transport at all times, not only during rush hours, and when there is prolonged (15+ min) close contact with other people indoors.      This is coded as 2T to reflect the broader scope of application and stronger language (""must always be worn"") of this recommendation compared to the national-level recommendation for rush hour mask use in public transport.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210308153242/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/regional-information-about-coronavirus    However, important to note is that compliance with the recommendation appears to be limited. According to a Dutch newspaper's Sweden correspondent, many people do not wear masks on public transport in Stockholm, while the recommendation for region Stockholm is one of the most strongly worded ones compared to the rest of the country: http://web.archive.org/web/20210312195107/https://myprivacy.dpgmedia.nl/consent?siteKey=PUBX2BuuZfEPJ6vF&callbackUrl=https%3a%2f%2fwww.volkskrant.nl%2fprivacy-wall%2faccept%3fredirectUri%3d%252fkijkverder%252fv%252f2021%252fhet-land-van-pippi-nationalisme-zoekt-zondebok%257ev426968%252f

***Recoded from 3G to 2G. As these measures are in place regionally, there is no evidence that at the national level all three groups are being vaccinated. Rather, two groups seems more accurate at the naional level as an average.     Previous coding note:   A,B,C:   Phase 1: The first group to be offered vaccination will be those living in nursing homes or receiving home care, members of the same household and staff who work with them.  Phase 2: Next, vaccination will be offered to those 65 years old and above. This includes adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226205411/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn    The vaccinations are carried out by the regions, so the phase of the vaccination programme can differ from region to region. Some regions are still at the stage of vaccinating only people in nursing homes, some regions vaccinate 80+, some 70+, some 65+. From 2 March onwards, several regions have started announcing that they are in phase 2, which includes a few clinically vulnerable groups: adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308222627/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset    Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca   https://web.archive.org/web/20210219214611/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/tredje-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-har-godkants    Vaccinations are still taking place: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308223138/https://www.thelocal.se/20210129/charts-how-is-swedens-vaccination-programme-going/

***Recoded from 3G to 2G. As these measures are in place regionally, there is no evidence that at the national level all three groups are being vaccinated. Rather, two groups seems more accurate at the naional level as an average.     A,B,C:   Several regions are now in Phase 2, which includes anyone 65+ (though implementation differs from region to region) as well as a few clinically vulnerable groups: adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment.  Information on which groups are included the different phases of the vaccination strategy: http://web.archive.org/web/20210311193915/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn  Information on stages of vaccination campaign in different regions: http://web.archive.org/web/20210311191515/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset    Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca https://web.archive.org/web/20210219214611/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/tredje-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-har-godkants    The Janssen vaccin was approved on 11 March, but delivery to Sweden is expected only next month:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210311192846/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/fjarde-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-godkant/     Vaccinations are still taking place: http://web.archive.org/web/20210311194318/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/statistik/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

A,C:   Several regions have entered Phase 2, which includes anyone 65+ (though implementation differs from region to region) as well as a few clinically vulnerable groups (B): adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment. Information on which groups are included the different phases of the vaccination strategy: http://web.archive.org/web/20210319191115/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn    Information on stages of vaccination campaign in different regions:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210319191447/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset    Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna  - The Janssen vaccin was approved on 11 March, but delivery to Sweden is expected only in April:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210311192846/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/fjarde-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-godkant/   - On 16 March, the use of AstraZeneca was suspended until the European Medicines Agency (EMA) had completed its investigation of suspected side effects such as bleeding and blood clots.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210319191331/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/astra-zenecas-vaccin-pausas-som-en-forsiktighetsatgard-i-vantan-pa-emas-utredning/      Vaccinations are still taking place:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210319191720/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

In addition to the note added to the entry for 16 March:  On 18 March, the European Medicines Agency announced that the benefits outweigh the risks fort he use of AstraZeneca, but Sweden continued to halt the use of AstraZeneca because the Swedish Public Health Agency had not yet taken position.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210319190317/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/fortsatt-paus-for-vaccinationerna-med-astra-zenecas-vaccin-i-avvaktan-pa-beslut/

A,C:   Most regions are still in Phase 1: ""Phase 1: The first group to be offered vaccination will be those living in nursing homes or receiving home care, members of the same household and staff who work with them."" Several regions have entered Phase 2, which includes anyone 65+ (though implementation differs from region to region) as well as a few clinically vulnerable groups (B): adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment. Information on which groups are included the different phases of the vaccination strategy.   The Public Health Agency has announced that the elderly should be clearly prioritized over the younger: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326110350/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/skarpt-prioritering-av-aldre-vid-vaccination/     Information on phases: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326104758/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn     Information on stages of vaccination campaign in different regions: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326104641/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset     Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca   - From 25 March, the use of AstraZeneca was continued for people over 65, but remained suspended for younger people: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326104151/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/vaccinationerna-med-astra-zenecas-vaccin-kan-fortsatta-for-personer-som-ar-65-ar-och-aldre/   - The Janssen vaccin was approved on 11 March, but delivery to Sweden is expected only in April: http://web.archive.org/web/20210311192846/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/fjarde-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-godkant/     Vaccinations are still taking place: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326104818/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

There is still 1 municipality with a visiting ban in place for elderly homes.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308224020/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/information-till-varden/personal-inom-aldreomsorg/lokala-besoksforbud-pa-aldreboenden/    The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include:   - Do not visit if you have symptoms of covid-19, even mild symptoms.  - Before the visit - talk to the staff about what applies to the specific nursing home.  - During the visit - wash your hands, and even if the person you are visiting is vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other residents, and also from the staff.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308224233/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/fragor-och-svar/?exp=80974

Ban is up so switch from 3T to 2G https://web.archive.org/web/20210226210115/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/information-till-varden/personal-inom-aldreomsorg/lokala-besoksforbud-pa-aldreboenden/lista-pa-kommuner/  The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include:  - Do not visit if you have symptoms of covid-19, even mild symptoms. - Before the visit - talk to the staff about what applies to the specific nursing home. - During the visit - wash your hands, and even if the person you are visiting is vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other residents, and also from the staff. http://web.archive.org/web/20210312201038/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/f/forebygg-smittspridning-av-covid-19-vid-besok-pa-sarskilda-boenden-for-aldre/

There are no municipal-level visiting bans for elderly homes in place anymore.    The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include: - Do not visit if you have symptoms of covid-19, even mild symptoms. - Before the visit - talk to the staff about what applies to the specific nursing home. - During the visit - wash your hands, and even if the person you are visiting is vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other residents, and also from the staff.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210319190950/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/f/forebygg-smittspridning-av-covid-19-vid-besok-pa-sarskilda-boenden-for-aldre/

The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include:   - Stay at home if you feel ill. Cancel the visit even in case of mild symptoms.   - Wash your hands before, during and after the visit.   - Even if the person you are visiting has been vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other people during the visit, both indoors and outdoors.   - There are local procedures for visits. Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210326105242/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/

Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210402184228/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/

Quote from article 1:  ""The Government is providing VAT exemptions on essential imports, lump-sum assistance equivalent to minimum wage to vulnerable households and other socially disadvantaged groups. Health workers are to receive supplemental pay, while tariff increases on electricity, water, and communal services have been postponed until end of 2020. Government is providing free medical care to citizens placed under medical care and COVID-19 patients, as well as sick leave and compensation benefits. Government is providing grain, seed and fuel to farms to boost food security, and time-bound tax holidays and relief to targeted industries and small businesses until September 1, 2020. Anti-COVID measures also include financial support to SMEs and subsidizing food for population. Recently, Tajikistan was granted a debt relief around USD50 million under G20 DSSI initiative. These funds were also included to anti-COVID envelop under supplementary budget currently being discussed in the Parliament.""      Archived link 1:  http://archive.today/2021.03.22-042110/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

A: healthcare workers.  Oxford/Astrazeneca    Dushanbe, Tajikistan, 09 March 2021 – Today Tajikistan received via the COVAX Facility, 192,000 doses of the AstraZeneca/Oxford COVID-19 vaccine. This is the first shipment of COVID-19 vaccines from the COVAX Facility to arrive in Central Asia and the second such shipment to the WHO European Region.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210316210247/https://www.unicef.org/tajikistan/press-releases/tajikistan-becomes-first-country-central-asia-receive-covid-19-vaccine-through-0

Plans for vaccination campaigns have been announced and doses have been received by Tajikistan but are only supposed to begin in mid-2021.    ______________________________________  Quote from article 1:  ""Dushanbe, Tajikistan, 09 March 2021 – Today Tajikistan received via the COVAX Facility, 192,000 doses of the AstraZeneca/Oxford COVID-19 vaccine.""    Archived link 1:  http://archive.today/2021.03.22-134037/https://www.unicef.org/tajikistan/press-releases/tajikistan-becomes-first-country-central-asia-receive-covid-19-vaccine-through-0    ______________________________________  Quote from article 2:  ""The COVID-19 vaccines will be provided through the Gavi-COVAX Advanced Market Commitment Global Financing Mechanism (for about 16 percent of the population) and through this project (4 percent). The procurement and delivery of vaccines will be undertaken by UNICEF. The Ministry of Health and Social Protection of the Population of Tajikistan (MoHSP) has identified the segments of the populations that will be included in the first stage of the vaccination program, including health and social care workers, the population over 50 years of age, people with underlying health conditions, as well as teachers and employees of educational institutions.    The exact number of people to be vaccinated under this additional financing and in collaboration with COVAX, will depend on final vaccine prices negotiated between COVAX and manufacturers.""    Archived link 2:  http://archive.today/2021.03.22-134057/https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2021/02/11/world-bank-supports-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-tajikistan    ____________________________________    Quote from article 3:  ""the Minister of Health said that the distribution of the first vaccines would begin by mid-2021.    According to him, following the instructions of the COVAX mechanism, first, it is necessary to ensure the vaccination of:    The healthcare and social workers who are at a high risk of infection,  The elderly and persons suffering from chronic non-contagious diseases, such as cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, diseases associated with metabolic disorders, or have a high risk of death.  The target group from the population to be vaccinated against COVID-19 is already determined: it is 1.8 million people or 20% of the population of Tajikistan. This group includes healthcare and education workers, persons over 50 and persons with chronic non-contagious diseases.    The vaccination will be voluntary and free of charge. After the vaccine is delivered to Tajikistan, the Ministry of Health of the country will announce the locations and the process of registering for vaccination.""    Archived link 3:  http://archive.today/2021.03.22-134842/https://www.intellinews.com/tajikistan-receives-first-batch-of-covid-19-vaccines-205134/
No changes found

Turkmenistan is not on the first round of COVAX allocations.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210303153745/https://www.gavi.org/sites/default/files/covid/covax/COVAX-First-round-allocation-of-AZ-and-SII.pdf    Turkmenistan has registered the EpiCoronaVac and Sputnik V vaccines for approval but does not appear to be administering them.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210309192254/https://turkmenistan.gov.tm/ru/post/52661/session-government-outcomes-two-months-and-preparation-celebration-dates

Interest in joining the COVAX programme has been stated by the government of Turkmenistan but no actual vaccination campaigns seen being done yet.    Chinese made vaccines have arrived in Turkmenistan, and the Russian vaccine has been registered in the country as well, however, there is no stated policy (at this current point in time) to dictate how the vaccines will be used.    There is one article found that the government of Turkmenistan intends to vaccinate foreign athletes competing in the tennis' Davis Cup and the Track Cycling World Championships in October. all of which for free.    _______________________________________  Quote from article 1:  ""Turkmenistan plans to vaccinate foreign athletes competing in the isolated Central Asian state, one of the few countries in the world yet to declare a coronavirus case, state media said on Thursday (Jan 21).  The former Soviet state is set to hold qualifying events for tennis' Davis Cup and will host the Track Cycling World Championships in October.""    ""we must provide this vaccination for free""    ""Mr Berdymukhamedov has said the Turkmen government is in talks with other companies over importing their vaccines.""    Web archived link 1:  http://archive.today/2021.03.14-152735/https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/coronavirus-virus-free-turkmenistan-to-vaccinate-foreign-athletes-due-for-davis-cup-cycling    ________________________________________  Quote from link 2:  ""Currently Turkmenistan expressed its willingness to participate in the global COVAX facility. COVAX is a global initiative aimed at working with vaccine manufacturers to provide countries all around the world with equitable access to safe and effective vaccines against COVID-19, once they are licensed and approved.""    Web archived link 2:  http://archive.today/2021.03.14-153139/https://www.unicef.org/turkmenistan/press-releases/unicef-and-turkmenistan-sign-new-plan-procure-vaccines-next-five-years""    _________________________________________  Quote from link 3:  ""A batch of Chinese-made COVID-19 vaccines arrived in Turkmenistan on Saturday morning.""    Web archived link 3:  http://archive.today/2021.03.14-151657/https://news.cgtn.com/news/2021-03-06/Turkmenistan-receives-Chinese-made-COVID-19-vaccines-YpT1xZUdm8/index.html    ___________________________________________  Quote from link 4:  ""The Russian Direct Investment Fund (RDIF) says Turkmenistan has registered Russia's Sputnik-V vaccine against COVID-19 even though the country claims to have no cases of the coronavirus.    ""Turkmenistan became the first country in Central Asia that officially approved the use of the Sputnik-V vaccine on its territory,"" the RDIF, which helped develop the vaccine, said in a statement on January 18, adding that the vaccine had been registered thanks to an emergency-use authorization without additional clinical research.    Turkmenistan is the only nation in Central Asia that has yet to report officially on a single coronavirus infection to the World Health Organization (WHO).""    Web archived link 4:  http://archive.today/2021.03.14-152154/https://www.rferl.org/a/turkmenistan-covis-19-sputnik-vaccination-russian-authorities/31051162.html

On 2 March, face-to-face education was initiated across the country in all pre-school education institutions, primary schools, 8th, and 12th grades.        Face-to-face education is also provided in all pre-school education institutions, primary schools, secondary schools and high schools in provinces defined as low and medium risk.     Face-to-face training in provinces defined as low and medium risk:  Full-time in pre-school education institutions  2 days a week in diluted classes in primary schools  2 days a week in diluted classes in 5th, 6th, and 7th grades   12-22 hours per week in diluted classes in 8th grade  2 days a week in diluted classes in 9th, 10th, 11th grades  16-24 hours a week in diluted classes in 12th grade      Face to face training in provinces defined as high and very high risk:  Full-time in pre-school education institutions  2 days a week in diluted clases in primary schools  12-22 hours per week in diluted classes in 8th grade  16-24 hours per week in diluted classes in 12th grade    Special education schools and classes serving for students with special needs began full-time face-to-face education throughout the country.    Distance education will be continued in applications outside the scope of face-to-face education.     Participation in face-to-face training will be carried out in all provinces subject to the consent of the parents.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210308165904/http://www.meb.gov.tr/basin-aciklamasi/haber/22651/tr

According to the Turkey's Ministry of Education official Twitter account (@tcmeb), predetermined exam dates of High School preps, 9., 10., and 11. grades have been postponed from 29th March 2021 to March 3rd. 12th grades' exams will keep going as determined which is planned to finish on 16th April 2021.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210324095706/https://twitter.com/tcmeb/status/1374421758695018501?s=20

On 1 March, President Erdogan announced a new ""controlled normalization process"", which includes a four-tier system on local COVID-19 related restrictions.    Based on infection and vaccination rates, provinces are now divided into 4 different risk groups: low, medium, high, and very high. The level of measures in combating the epidemic will be determined according to these risk groups.    In low, medium, and high risk provinces: Restaurants, internet cafes, billiard halls, amusement parks, baths, saunas, and massage parlors are able to operate between 07:00 and 19:00, at a maximum of 50% capacity. These same establishments remain closed in very high risk provinces.      In low and medium risk provinces: football fields, swimming pools and similar facilities are allowed to operate between 09:00 and 19:00. No spectators or guests will be allowed. These establishments will remain closed in high and very high risk provinces.    Dining establishments and fitness facilities are mandated to ask for Hayat Eve Sigar (HES) codes at the entrance. HES codes are used by the Health Ministry to trace COVID-19 positive people.    Bars, casinos, taverns, and hookah lounges will remain closed in all provinces.     The current risk groups are as follows.     Low risk:  Agri, Batman, Bingöl, Bitlis, Diyarbakir, Hakkari, Igdir, Mardin, Mus, Siirt, Sanliurfa, Sirnak, Usak, Van.    Medium risk:  Adana, Afyonkarahisar, Ankara, Aydin, Bartin, Bayburt, Bursa, Çankiri, Çorum, Denizli, Elazig, Erzincan, Erzurum, Eskisehir, Gaziantep, Hatay, Isparta, Kahramanmaras, Karabük, Kars, Kastamonu, Kirsehir, Malatya, Manisa, Nevsehir, Sivas, Tunceli, Yozgat.      High risk:  Antalya, Ardahan, Artvin, Bilecik, Bolu, Çanakkale, Düzce, Istanbul, Izmir, Karaman, Kayseri, Kirikkale, Kirklareli, Kilis, Kocaeli, Kütahya, Mersin, Mugla, Nigde, Tekirdag, Yalova, Zonguldak.      Very high risk:   Adiyaman, Aksaray, Amasya, Balikesir, Burdur, Edirne, Giresun, Gümüshane, Konya, Ordu, Osmaniye, Rize, Sakarya, Samsun, Sinop, Tokat, Trabzon.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210302093030/https://www.tccb.gov.tr/en/news/542/125091/-we-are-starting-the-new-controlled-normalization-process-today-    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308194008/https://www.icisleri.gov.tr/koronavirus-ile-mucadelede-kontrollu-normallesme-sureci    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308200841/https://www.icisleri.gov.tr/kontrollu-normallesme-sureci-ile-ilgili-sikca-sorulan-sorular

According to the 03/29/2021 Cabinet meeting, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced that all red color cities will have weekend lockdown (normally it was only Sunday but now it is also Saturday).     Also, in the whole country, during Ramadan, all cafes and restaurants will only work as take-away, weekend lockdown will be held domestically, and publicly held iftars and sahurs are banned.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210329195019/https://www.sabah.com.tr/gundem/2021/03/29/son-dakika-kisitlamalar-geri-mi-gelecek-risk-haritasi-nasil-olacak-kabine-toplantisi-basladi

On 1 March, President Erdogan announced a new ""controlled normalization process"", which includes a four-tier system on local COVID-19 related restrictions.    Based on infection and vaccination rates, provinces are now divided into 4 different risk groups: low, medium, high, and very high. The level of measures in combating the epidemic will be determined according to these risk groups.    In low, medium, and high risk provinces: Public events are allowed, but are limited to 300 people and must allow for a minimum of 8m² per person.     In very high risk provinces, all public events will be postponed.     The current risk groups are as follows.     Low risk:  Agri, Batman, Bingöl, Bitlis, Diyarbakir, Hakkari, Igdir, Mardin, Mus, Siirt, Sanliurfa, Sirnak, Usak, Van. High risk:  Antalya, Ardahan, Artvin, Bilecik, Bolu, Çanakkale, Düzce, Istanbul, Izmir, Karaman, Kayseri, Kirikkale, Kirklareli, Kilis, Kocaeli, Kütahya, Mersin, Mugla, Nigde, Tekirdag, Yalova, Zonguldak.      Very high risk:   Adiyaman, Aksaray, Amasya, Balikesir, Burdur, Edirne, Giresun, Gümüshane, Konya, Ordu, Osmaniye, Rize, Sakarya, Samsun, Sinop, Tokat, Trabzon.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210302093030/https://www.tccb.gov.tr/en/news/542/125091/-we-are-starting-the-new-controlled-normalization-process-today-    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308194008/https://www.icisleri.gov.tr/koronavirus-ile-mucadelede-kontrollu-normallesme-sureci

On 1 March, President Erdogan announced a new ""controlled normalization process"", which includes a four-tier system on local COVID-19 related restrictions.    Based on infection and vaccination rates, provinces are now divided into 4 different risk groups: low, medium, high, and very high. The level of measures in combating the epidemic will be determined according to these risk groups.    In low and medium risk provinces: Wedding ceremonies can be held with a minimum of 8m² per person, not exceeding 100 participants and limited to 1 hour. No restrictions are applied on funeral attendance.      In high and very high risk provinces: Wedding ceremonies can be held with a minimum area of ??8m² per person, not exceeding 50 participants and limited to 1 hour. Attendance at funerals is limited to 30 people.     The current risk groups are as follows.     Low risk:  Agri, Batman, Bingöl, Bitlis, Diyarbakir, Hakkari, Igdir, Mardin, Mus, Siirt, Sanliurfa, Sirnak, Usak, Van.    Medium risk:  Adana, Afyonkarahisar, Ankara, Aydin, Bartin, Bayburt, Bursa, Çankiri, Çorum, Denizli, Elazig, Erzincan, Erzurum, Eskisehir, Gaziantep, Hatay, Isparta, Kahramanmaras, Karabük, Kars, Kastamonu, Kirsehir, Malatya, Manisa, Nevsehir, Sivas, Tunceli, Yozgat.      High risk:  Antalya, Ardahan, Artvin, Bilecik, Bolu, Çanakkale, Düzce, Istanbul, Izmir, Karaman, Kayseri, Kirikkale, Kirklareli, Kilis, Kocaeli, Kütahya, Mersin, Mugla, Nigde, Tekirdag, Yalova, Zonguldak.      Very high risk:   Adiyaman, Aksaray, Amasya, Balikesir, Burdur, Edirne, Giresun, Gümüshane, Konya, Ordu, Osmaniye, Rize, Sakarya, Samsun, Sinop, Tokat, Trabzon.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210302093030/https://www.tccb.gov.tr/en/news/542/125091/-we-are-starting-the-new-controlled-normalization-process-today-    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308194008/https://www.icisleri.gov.tr/koronavirus-ile-mucadelede-kontrollu-normallesme-sureci    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308200841/https://www.icisleri.gov.tr/kontrollu-normallesme-sureci-ile-ilgili-sikca-sorulan-sorular

According to the new Covid-19 gradual normalization plan of Turkey, By March 1, in low-risk (blue color in risk map )and middle-risk ( yellow color in risk map) cities, weddings can be established with a restriction of, 8 square meters per person, max 100 people and max 1 hour. In the high-risk (orange color in risk map) and very-high risk (red color in risk map) cities, weddings can be established with a restriction of, 8 square meters per person, max 50 people, and max 1 hour. Other gatherings which exceed 100 people limits are dependent upon governorship approval.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210310065230/https://www.dw.com/tr/kontroll%C3%BC-normalle%C5%9Fmenin-ayr%C4%B1nt%C4%B1lar%C4%B1/a-56742269

Very high risk:   Adiyaman, Aksaray, Amasya, Balikesir, Burdur, Edirne, Giresun, Gümüshane, Konya, Ordu, Osmaniye, Rize, Sakarya, Samsun, Sinop, Tokat, Trabzon.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210302093030/https://www.tccb.gov.tr/en/news/542/125091/-we-are-starting-the-new-controlled-normalization-process-today-    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308194008/https://www.icisleri.gov.tr/koronavirus-ile-mucadelede-kontrollu-normallesme-sureci    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308200841/https://www.icisleri.gov.tr/kontrollu-normallesme-sureci-ile-ilgili-sikca-sorulan-sorular

On 1 March, President Erdogan announced a new ""controlled normalization process"", which includes a four-tier system on local COVID-19 related restrictions.    Based on infection and vaccination rates, provinces are now divided into 4 different risk groups: low, medium, high, and very high. The level of measures in combating the epidemic will be determined according to these risk groups.    The weeknight curfew during the hours of 21:00 to 5:00 remains in all provinces, Monday through Friday.      On weekends in low and medium risk provinces, there is a nightly curfew between 21:00-05:00, just like during the week.    On weekends in high and very high risk provinces, there is a curfew starting at 21:00 on Saturday and covering the whole Sunday and ending at 05:00 on Monday.    The current risk groups are as follows.     Low risk:  Agri, Batman, Bingöl, Bitlis, Diyarbakir, Hakkari, Igdir, Mardin, Mus, Siirt, Sanliurfa, Sirnak, Usak, Van.    Medium risk:  Adana, Afyonkarahisar, Ankara, Aydin, Bartin, Bayburt, Bursa, Çankiri, Çorum, Denizli, Elazig, Erzincan, Erzurum, Eskisehir, Gaziantep, Hatay, Isparta, Kahramanmaras, Karabük, Kars, Kastamonu, Kirsehir, Malatya, Manisa, Nevsehir, Sivas, Tunceli, Yozgat.      High risk:  Antalya, Ardahan, Artvin, Bilecik, Bolu, Çanakkale, Düzce, Istanbul, Izmir, Karaman, Kayseri, Kirikkale, Kirklareli, Kilis, Kocaeli, Kütahya, Mersin, Mugla, Nigde, Tekirdag, Yalova, Zonguldak. Turkish citizens and residents are subject to a weekend curfew (Friday, 9 PM- Monday, 5 AM). In Istanbul, the use of all means of public mass transport has been banned for persons under 20 and over 65 part of COVID-19 restrictions. The Government of Turkey announced a four-tier system on local COVID-19 related restrictions. Each province is categorized as being low, middle, high or very high risk based on infection and vaccination rates. Daily curfews between 9 PM and 5 AM remain in effect nationwide regardless of the locality’s risk category.   Link: https://archive.fo/QTiA9

According to the 03/29/2021 Cabinet meeting, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced that all red color cities will have weekend lockdown (normally it was only Sunday but now it is also Saturday).     Also, in the whole country, during Ramadan, all cafes and restaurants will only work as take-away, weekend lockdown will be held domestically, and publicly held iftars and sahurs are banned.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210329195019/https://www.sabah.com.tr/gundem/2021/03/29/son-dakika-kisitlamalar-geri-mi-gelecek-risk-haritasi-nasil-olacak-kabine-toplantisi-basladi

On 1 March, President Erdogan announced a new ""controlled normalization process"", which includes a four-tier system on local COVID-19 related restrictions.    Based on infection and vaccination rates, provinces are now divided into 4 different risk groups: low, medium, high, and very high. The level of measures in combating the epidemic will be determined according to these risk groups.    Intercity travel permits are required for citizens under age 20 and those age 65 and older, if any of the provinces included in the trip (departure, arrival, or route) are high or very high risk.    No permission for intercity travel is required for these age groups if the provinces are low or medium risk.     Coded as 1 because the majority of citizens participating in intercity travel are likely outside of these age groups regardless.     The current risk groups are as follows.     Low risk:  Agri, Batman, Bingöl, Bitlis, Diyarbakir, Hakkari, Igdir, Mardin, Mus, Siirt, Sanliurfa, Sirnak, Usak, Van.    Medium risk:  Adana, Afyonkarahisar, Ankara, Aydin, Bartin, Bayburt, Bursa, Çankiri, Çorum, Denizli, Elazig, Erzincan, Erzurum, Eskisehir, Gaziantep, Hatay, Isparta, Kahramanmaras, Karabük, Kars, Kastamonu, Kirsehir, Malatya, Manisa, Nevsehir, Sivas, Tunceli, Yozgat.      High risk:  Antalya, Ardahan, Artvin, Bilecik, Bolu, Çanakkale, Düzce, Istanbul, Izmir, Karaman, Kayseri, Kirikkale, Kirklareli, Kilis, Kocaeli, Kütahya, Mersin, Mugla, Nigde, Tekirdag, Yalova, Zonguldak.      Very high risk:   Adiyaman, Aksaray, Amasya, Balikesir, Burdur, Edirne, Giresun, Gümüshane, Konya, Ordu, Osmaniye, Rize, Sakarya, Samsun, Sinop, Tokat, Trabzon.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210302093030/https://www.tccb.gov.tr/en/news/542/125091/-we-are-starting-the-new-controlled-normalization-process-today-    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308194008/https://www.icisleri.gov.tr/koronavirus-ile-mucadelede-kontrollu-normallesme-sureci    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308200841/https://www.icisleri.gov.tr/kontrollu-normallesme-sureci-ile-ilgili-sikca-sorulan-sorular

After the new Covid-19 gradual normalization plan of Turkey announced, on 03/03/2021, the Istanbul Provincial Sanitation Board (which is the decision-maker in charge of any public health issue in Istanbul) stated that in the hours that people under 20 and over 65 can go outside, the restrictions over transportation for these people are removed.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210304153114/https://www.ibb.istanbul/News/Detail/37671

Arrivals to Turkey from Brazil, United Kingdom, Denmark, and South Africa are suspended.     All passengers arriving Turkey from other countries who visited Brazil, United Kingdom, Denmark and South Africa within the last 10 days will be quarantined for 14 days at places selected by the Turkish official authorities following their arrival. On the 10th day of the quarantine period, passengers are required to undergo a second PCR test and if the test result is negative, the isolation period will end.    Passengers of 6 years and older who visited the aforementioned countries and arriving Turkey are required, before boarding, to submit a negative PCR test result with a sample collected within the last 72-hours prior to departure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210304044018/https://www.turkishairlines.com/en-int/announcements/coronavirus-outbreak/travel-restrictions/

In terms of economic support, the government doesn't give any support to those who lost their jobs. But those who normally work but because of the covid-19, the firms cannot pay them, for those people there is two options.     First is Cash payment support which is given to workers who are currently in unpaid time-off (due to covid-19, firms cannot fire the employers, so they are sending their workers to unpaid time-off). In one month its max pay time is 30 days and the daily wage is 47.70 TRY (The currency is changing rapidly in these weeks, so to avoid the wrong amount, I didn't write in USD form).  This support is ending on 05/17/2021 if there won't be any extension.    The second way is a short-time working allowance/work. In this payment, the workers who are currently working (who are not in time-off or any other absence situation) and be approved by the Turkish Employment Agency are getting %60 of their daily gross earnings. This support is ending on 03/31/2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210122131003/https://www.iskur.gov.tr/isveren/kisa-calisma-odenegi/genel-bilgiler/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210122191037/https://www.iskur.gov.tr/is-arayan/issizlik-sigortasi/nakdi-ucret-destegi/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210325135853/https://www.cnnturk.com/ekonomi/nakdi-ucret-destegi-ne-zaman-bitiyor-ucretsiz-izin-maas-destegi-ne-zaman-bitecek    https://web.archive.org/web/20210304013926/https://www.hurriyet.com.tr/ekonomi/kisa-calisma-odenegi-ne-zaman-bitecek-uzatildi-mi-kisa-calisma-odenegi-icin-son-tarih-belli-oldu-41754473

Individuals with COVID-19 symptoms (fever, cough, difficulty breathing, etc.), should apply to the nearest health facility. If the doctor suspects COVID-19, he or she will request a test.    For foreigners staying in Turkey, PCR testing is limited to those who have symptoms, or those who may have an entry requirement back to their home country. Testing is paid for by the traveler. A,C:     On 25 February, Health Minister Dr. Fahrettin Koca made a statement at the press conference held after the Coronavirus Scientific Committee meeting.    Minister Koca stated that 8 million doses of vaccination had been administered so far and that “We are approaching the end of the first phase in the vaccination plan.""    The first phase included healthcare workers and people over age 65.     The second phase will include essential workers and people between the ages of 50 and 64.     As of 1 March, it is unclear whether the second phase has begun.    Currently, CoronaVac is the only vaccine being administered. The Health Ministry plans to diversify the vaccines by acquiring from other companies abroad, while trials continue for locally-made vaccines.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210309045419/https://covid19asi.saglik.gov.tr/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210309060458/https://covid19asi.saglik.gov.tr/TR-78296/asi-uygulanacak-grup-siralamasi.html

On 1 March, President Erdogan announced a new ""controlled normalization process"", which includes a four-tier system on local COVID-19 related restrictions.    Based on infection and vaccination rates, provinces are now divided into 4 different risk groups: low, medium, high, and very high. The level of measures in combating the epidemic will be determined according to these risk groups.    In low and medium risk provinces, the curfew is lifted for citizens age 65 and over.     In high and very high risk provinces, the curfew for citizens age 65 and over is between 10:00 and 14:00.     The current risk groups are as follows.     Low risk:  Agri, Batman, Bingöl, Bitlis, Diyarbakir, Hakkari, Igdir, Mardin, Mus, Siirt, Sanliurfa, Sirnak, Usak, Van.    Medium risk:  Adana, Afyonkarahisar, Ankara, Aydin, Bartin, Bayburt, Bursa, Çankiri, Çorum, Denizli, Elazig, Erzincan, Erzurum, Eskisehir, Gaziantep, Hatay, Isparta, Kahramanmaras, Karabük, Kars, Kastamonu, Kirsehir, Malatya, Manisa, Nevsehir, Sivas, Tunceli, Yozgat.      High risk:  Antalya, Ardahan, Artvin, Bilecik, Bolu, Çanakkale, Düzce, Istanbul, Izmir, Karaman, Kayseri, Kirikkale, Kirklareli, Kilis, Kocaeli, Kütahya, Mersin, Mugla, Nigde, Tekirdag, Yalova, Zonguldak.      Very high risk:   Adiyaman, Aksaray, Amasya, Balikesir, Burdur, Edirne, Giresun, Gümüshane, Konya, Ordu, Osmaniye, Rize, Sakarya, Samsun, Sinop, Tokat, Trabzon.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210302093030/https://www.tccb.gov.tr/en/news/542/125091/-we-are-starting-the-new-controlled-normalization-process-today-    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308194008/https://www.icisleri.gov.tr/koronavirus-ile-mucadelede-kontrollu-normallesme-sureci

Adaptive quarantaine is in place until 30 April 2021.  ""Red zone"" and tough lockdown restrictions have already been introduced in the Ivano-Frankivsk, Chernivtsi and Zhytomyr regions. According to the prime minister Denys Shmyhal,  lockdown may also be introduced in the Vinnytsia, Zakarpattia, Ternopil regions and a number of other regions in which ""orange zone"" restrictions are currently in place. All regions continue to be in yellow, orange and red zones (thereby coding G for certain indicators). From 20 March to 09 April, Kyiv has introduced further restrictions (similar to the “red” level of quarantine), which include:    - Closure of cinemas, theaters, museums, and other cultural establishments  - Closure of shopping malls and stores except for grocery stores, pharmacies, pet stores, shops selling hygiene products and household chemicals  - No religious services, public and sport events  - Limitation of restaurant, cafes, and catering establishments’ operations to “takeaway” mode only  - Beauty salons will operate by appointment only  - Spring break starts early in schools, kindergartens will continue to operate as usual  - Public transportation will work as usual – but with max 50% of seat occupancy    https://web.archive.org/web/20210320185538/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/premyer-ministr-misceva-vlada-maye-vsi-povnovazhennya-dlya-posilennya-karantinnih-obmezhen  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320185733/https://covid19.gov.ua/karantynni-zakhody  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320185346/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/timeline?type=posts&tag=Healthcare  https://web.archive.org/web/20210320183515/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Ukraine is under an adaptive quarantine until April 30, 2021.  As of March 29, Kyiv city, Zhytomyr, Ivano-Frankivsk, Zakarpattia, Kyiv, Lviv, Mykolaiv, Odesa, Sumy, Chernihiv and Chernivtsi regions are in the red zone.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210329193514/https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3217075-kyiv-city-10-regions-included-in-red-zone-ministry-of-health.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210329190658/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
A  vaccines used: Astra Zeneca    http://web.archive.org/web/20210308140341/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/viktor-lyashko-rozpoviv-pro-vakcinaciyu-proti-covid-19-v-oblastyah

A:  AstraZeneca (Covishield)    Sinovac (CoronaVac) and Pfizer/BioNTech are also approved for use but no evidence they have been used to date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210320184350/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/moz-dozvoliv-do-vikoristannja-v-ukraini-sche-odnu-vakcinu-proti-covid-19

A  vaccines currently used: Astra Zeneca     From March 29, more than 2,500 vaccination points will be opened for immunization, which will start operating if a new batch of vaccines is received. As soon as a new batch of vaccines arrives, people over the age of 80 who will also be vaccinated in the second stage of the roadmap will get vaccines.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210329195335/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/565-stacionarnih-punktiv-vakcinaciyi-proti-covid-19-zapracyuyut-z-22-bereznya

Adaptive quarantaine is in place until 30 April 2021.  ""Red zone"" and tough lockdown restrictions have already been introduced in the Ivano-Frankivsk, Chernivtsi and Zhytomyr regions. According to the prime minister Denys Shmyhal,  lockdown may also be introduced in the Vinnytsia, Zakarpattia, Ternopil regions and a number of other regions in which ""orange zone"" restrictions are currently in place. All regions continue to be in yellow, orange and red zones (thereby coding G for certain indicators).    http://web.archive.org/web/20210308123851/https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-polytics/3202145-shmyhal-declares-third-wave-of-coronavirus-in-ukraine-lockdown-possible.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210227184208/https://covid19.gov.ua/karantynni-zakhody

Schools continue to operate in-person with measurements against covid (such as hand sanitisation, facial coverings and social distancing)  in place.  ____________________________  Quote (1):  ""Currently, schools continue to operate in-person, groceries and household supplies are readily available with good distribution and open stores. ""    Archived link (1):  http://archive.today/2021.03.29-032337/https://uz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  ___________________________  Quote (2):  ""UNICEF, the MoH and NAEMM produced and broadcast a TV programme on pre-school reopening during COVID-19. The programme highlighted the importance ensuring a safe school environment, provided information on measures taken to reduce infection and spread of COVID-19 at school facilities, and highlighted the importance of hygiene and physical distancing.""    Link (2):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210329042521/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/COVID19%20SitRep%20Uzbekistan%2028-01-2021_Final.pdf  _________________________  Quote (3):  "" To help children better understand COVID-19, USAID and the Ministry of Education partnered with Sesame Workshop, the non-profit educational organization behind Sesame Street, to produce the Caring for Each Other media package.    The package, adapted for Uzbek audiences both in English and Uzbek languages, consists of 11 videos about proper handwashing, sneezing, coping with illness(link is external), stress, and adjusting to a new reality(link is external). Since September, the videos have been broadcast on national TV and disseminated on the Ministry’s online educational platforms and social media channels with a “Learn English with Sesame Street” theme.     In addition, posters, billboards, coloring and activity sheets that accompany the package, were shared with schools and retraining centers across the country. By partnering with Sesame Workshop, USAID has provided children and families in Uzbekistan with resources to learn and play together during the health crisis.""    Link (3):  http://archive.today/2021.03.29-032804/https://www.usaid.gov/uzbekistan/program-updates/jan-2021-elmo-explains-covid-19-children-uzbekistan
